When Philosophy with its abstractions paints grey in grey, the freshness and life of youth has gone, the reconciliation is not a reconciliation in the actual, but in the ideal world. 
 - HoP 1

Thus the Greek philosophers held themselves far removed from the business of the State and were called by the people idlers, because they withdrew themselves within the world of thought. 
 - HoP 1

This holds good throughout all the history of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

It was so with Ionic Philosophy in the decline of the Ionic States in Asia Minor. 
 - HoP 1

Socrates and Plato had no more pleasure in the life of the State in Athens, which was in the course of its decline; Plato tried to bring about something better with Dionysius. 
 - HoP 1

Thus in Athens, with the ruin of the Athenian people, the period was reached when Philosophy appeared. 
 - HoP 1

With the decline of the Roman Empire, which was so great, rich and glorious, and yet inwardly dead, the height and indeed the zenith of ancient Philosophy is associated through the Neo-Platonists at Alexandria. 
 - HoP 1

It was also in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, when the Teutonic life of the Middle Ages acquired another form, that Philosophy first became taught, though it was later on that it attained to independence. 
 - HoP 1

Before that, political life still existed in unity with Religion, or if the State fought against the Church, the Church still kept the foremost place, but now the gulf between Church and State came into existence. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy thus comes in at a certain epoch only in the development of the whole. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy as the thought of its time. 
 - HoP 1

Mind in each case has elaborated and expanded in the whole domain of its manifold nature the principle of the particular stage of self-consciousness to which it has attained. 
 - HoP 1

Thus the Mind of a people in its richness is an organization, and, like a Cathedral, is divided into numerous vaults, passages, pillars and vestibules, all of which have proceeded out of one whole and are directed to one end. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy is one form of these many aspects. 
 - HoP 1

And which is it? It is the fullest blossom, the Notion of Mind in its entire form, the consciousness and spiritual essence of all things, the spirit of the time as spirit present in itself. 
 - HoP 1

The multifarious whole is reflected in it as in the single focus, in the Notion which knows itself. 
 - HoP 1

The Philosophy which is essential within Christianity could not be found in Rome, for all the various forms of the whole are only the expression of one and the same determinate character. 
 - HoP 1

This particular stage is the product of the one preceding. 
 - HoP 1

Those forms alone concern us which express the principle of the Mind in a spiritual element related to Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

This is the position of Philosophy amongst its varying forms, from which it follows that it is entirely identical with its time. 
 - HoP 1

But if Philosophy does not stand above its time in content, it does so in form, because, as the thought and knowledge of that which is the substantial spirit of its time, it makes that spirit its object. 
 - HoP 1

In as far as Philosophy is in the spirit of its time, the latter is its determined content in the world, although as knowledge, Philosophy is above it, since it places it in the relation of object. 
 - HoP 1

But this is in form alone, for Philosophy really has no other content. 
 - HoP 1

This knowledge itself undoubtedly is the actuality of Mind, the self-knowledge of Mind which previously was not present: thus the formal difference is also a real and actual difference. 
 - HoP 1

Through knowledge, Mind makes manifest a distinction between knowledge and that which is; this knowledge is thus what produces a new form of development. 
 - HoP 1

We shall deal further with this in the concrete below, and we shall then see that what the Greek Philosophy was, entered, in the Christian world, into actuality. 
 - HoP 1

The history of the other Sciences, of culture and above all the history of art and of religion are, partly in regard to the elements contained in them, and partly to their particular objects, related to the history of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

It is through this relationship that the treatment of the history of Philosophy has been so confused. 
 - HoP 1

This is so, partly on account of the amount of material itself and the labour required in working it up and preparing it, and partly because it is in immediate connection with so much else. 
 - HoP 1

But the separation must not be made arbitrarily or as by chance, but must be derived from fundamental determinations. 
 - HoP 1

If we merely look at the name of Philosophy, all this matter will pertain to its history. 
 - HoP 1

I shall speak of this material from three points of view, for three related aspects are to be eliminated and separated from Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

The first of these is that which is generally considered to be the domain of science, and in which are found the beginnings of understanding thought. 
 - HoP 1

The second region is that of mythology and religion; the relation of Philosophy to them seems often to be inimical both in the time of the Greeks and of the Christians. 
 - HoP 1

The third is that of philosophizing and the metaphysics of the understanding. 
 - HoP 1

Relation of Philosophy to Scientific Knowledge. 
 - HoP 1

Knowledge and thought certainly form the element of whatever has to do with particular sciences as they form the element of Philosophy; but their subjects are mainly finite subjects and appearance. 
 - HoP 1

A collection of facts known about this content is by its nature excluded from Philosophy: neither this content nor such a form has anything to do with it. 
 - HoP 1

But even if the sciences are systematic and contain universal principles and laws from which they proceed, they are still related to a limited circle of objects. 
 - HoP 1

The ultimate principles are assumed as are the objects themselves; that is, the outward experience or the feelings of the heart, natural or educated sense of right and duty, constitute the source from which they are created. 
 - HoP 1

Logic and the determinations and principles of thought in general are in their methods assumed. 
 - HoP 1

This culture consists mainly in the general ideas and aims, in the whole extent of the particular intellectual powers dominating consciousness and life. 
 - HoP 1

Our consciousness has these ideas and allows them to be considered ultimate determinations; it makes use of them as guiding and connecting links, but does not know them and does not even make them the objects of its consideration. 
 - HoP 1

To give an abstract example, each act of consciousness has and requires the whole abstract thought-determination of Being. 
 - HoP 1

The sun is in the heavens, the bunch of grapes is ripe,  and so on into infinitude. 
 - HoP 1

Again, in a higher culture, such relations as those of cause and effect are involved, as also those of force and its manifestation. 
 - HoP 1

All its knowledge and ideas are permeated and governed by a metaphysic such as this; it is the net in which all the concrete matter which occupies mankind in action and in impulses, is grasped. 
 - HoP 1

But this web and its knots in our ordinary consciousness are sunk into a manifold material, for it contains the objects and interests which we know and which we have before us. 
 - HoP 1

These common threads are not drawn up and made explicitly the objects of our reflection. 
 - HoP 1

We Germans seldom now count general scientific knowledge as Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

And yet traces of this are found, as for instance, in the fact that the philosophic Faculty contains all the Sciences which have not as their immediate aim the Church and State. 
 - HoP 1

In connection with this, the significance of the name of Philosophy, which is even now an important matter of discussion in England, comes in question. 
 - HoP 1

Natural Sciences are in England called Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

A Philosophic Journal  in England, edited by Thompson, treats of Chemistry, Agriculture, Manuring, Husbandry, Technology, like HermbstÃ¤dts Journal, and gives inventions connected therewith. 
 - HoP 1

The English call physical instruments, such as the barometer and thermometer, philosophical instruments. 
 - HoP 1

And thus at least in England, is the name of Philosophy respected. 
 - HoP 1

Some time ago a banquet took place under the presidency of Lord Liverpool, at which the minister Canning was also present. 
 - HoP 1

The latter in returning thanks congratulated England in having philosophic principles of government there brought into operation. 
 - HoP 1

There, at least, Philosophy is no by-word. 
 - HoP 1

In the first beginnings of culture, however, we are more often met by this admixture of Philosophy and general knowledge. 
 - HoP 1

There comes a time to a nation when mind applies itself to universal objects, when, for example, in seeking to bring natural things under general modes of understanding, it tries to learn their causes. 
 - HoP 1

Then it is said that a people begins to philosophize, for this content has thought in common with Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Thus in the beginnings of Greek Philosophy we find the seven sages and the Ionic Philosophers. 
 - HoP 1

From them a number of ideas and discoveries are conveyed to us which seem like philosophic propositions. 
 - HoP 1

Thus Thales, amongst others, has explained that the eclipse of sun and moon is due to the intervention of the moon or earth. 
 - HoP 1

This is called a theorem. 
 - HoP 1

Pythagoras found out the principle of the harmony of sounds. 
 - HoP 1

Others have had ideas about the stars: the heavens were supposed to be composed of perforated metal, by which we see throughout the empyrean region, the eternal fire which surrounds the world. 
 - HoP 1

Earth and heaven thus become unpeopled with gods, because the understanding distinguishes things in their outward and natural qualities from Mind. 
 - HoP 1

In a later time the epoch of the revival in the sciences is as noteworthy in this respect. 
 - HoP 1

General principles regarding the state, &c, were given expression to, and in them a philosophic side cannot be mistaken. 
 - HoP 1

To this place the philosophic systems of Hobbes and Descartes belong: the writings of the latter contain philosophic principles, but his Philosophy of Nature is quite empirical. 
 - HoP 1

Hugo Grotius composed an international law in which what was historically held by the people as law, the consensus gentium, was a main element. 
 - HoP 1

The Ã  priori reasoning regarding natural things, according to the metaphysics of the Scholastic Philosophy or to Religion, has now been given up. 
 - HoP 1

The Philosophy of Newton contains nothing but Natural Science, that is, the knowledge of the laws, forces, and general constitution of Nature, derived from observation and from experience. 
 - HoP 1

This form is in its general aspect antagonistic to the positive, and has come forward as particularly opposed to Religion and to that which is positive in it. 
 - HoP 1

If, in the Middle Ages, the Church had its dogmas as universal truths, man, on the contrary, has now obtained from the testimony of his own thought,  feeling and ideas, a mistrust of these. 
 - HoP 1

It is merely to be remarked of this that my own thought  is in itself a pleonasm, because each individual must think for himself, and no one can do so for another. 
 - HoP 1

Similarly this principle has turned against the recognized constitutions and has sought different principles instead, by them to correct the former. 
 - HoP 1

Universal principles of the State have now been laid down, while earlier, because religion was positive, the ground of obedience of subjects to princes and of all authority were also so. 
 - HoP 1

Kings, as the anointed of the Lord, in the sense that Jewish kings were so, derived their power from God, and had to give account to Him alone, because all authority is given by God. 
 - HoP 1

So far theology and jurisprudence were on the whole fixed and positive sciences, wherever this positive character might have been derived. 
 - HoP 1

Against this external authority reflection has been brought to bear, and thus, especially in England, the source of public and civil law became no longer mere authority derived from God like the Mosaic Law. 
 - HoP 1

For the authority of kings other justification was sought, such as the end implied in the State, the good of the people. 
 - HoP 1

This forms quite another source of truth, and it is opposed to that which is revealed, given and positive. 
 - HoP 1

This substitution of another ground than that of authority has been called philosophizing. 
 - HoP 1

The knowledge was then a knowledge of what is finite-the world of the content of knowledge. 
 - HoP 1

Because this content proceeded through the personal insight of human reason, man has become independent in his actions. 
 - HoP 1

This independence of the Mind is the true moment of Philosophy, although the Notion of Philosophy through this formal determination, which limits it to finite objects, has not yet been exhausted. 
 - HoP 1

This independent thought is respected, has been called human wisdom or worldly wisdom, for it has had what is earthly as its object, and it took its origin in the world. 
 - HoP 1

This was the meaning of Philosophy, and men did rightly to call it worldly wisdom. 
 - HoP 1

Frederick von Schlegel revived this by-name for Philosophy, and desired to indicate by it that what concerns higher spheres, such as religion, must be kept apart; and he had many followers. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy, indeed, occupies itself with finite things, but, according to Spinoza, as resting in the divine Idea: it has thus the same end as religion. 
 - HoP 1

To the finite sciences which are now separated also from Philosophy, the Churches objected that they led men away from God, since they have as objects only what is finite. 
 - HoP 1

This defect in them, conceived of from the point of view of content, leads us to the second department allied to Philosophy,-that is, to Religion. 
 - HoP 1

Relation of Philosophy to Religion. 
 - HoP 1

Its object is not the earthly and worldly, but the infinite. 
 - HoP 1

In Religion, races of men have undoubtedly expressed their idea of the nature of the world, the substance of nature and of intellect and the relation of man thereto. 
 - HoP 1

Absolute Being is here the object of their consciousness; and as such, is for them pre-eminently the other,  a beyond,  nearer or further off, more or less friendly or frightful and alarming. 
 - HoP 1

In conception, with the Greeks, for instance, this existence is to man one which is already in and for itself and friendly, and thus worship is but the enjoyment of this unity. 
 - HoP 1

We must, therefore, comprehend Religion, as Philosophy, before everything else, which means to know and apprehend it in reason; for it is the work of self-revealing reason and is the highest form of reason. 
 - HoP 1

Such ideas as that priests have framed a peoples Religion in fraud and self-interest are consequently absurd; to regard Religion as an arbitrary matter or a deception is as foolish as it is perverted. 
 - HoP 1

Priests have often profaned Religion-the possibility of which is a consequence of the external relations and temporal existence of Religion. 
 - HoP 1

This region of Mind is really the Holy place of Truth itself, the Holy place in which are dissolved the remaining illusions of the sensuous world, of finite ideas and ends, and of the sphere of opinion and caprice. 
 - HoP 1

Inasmuch as it really is the content of religions, this rational matter might now seem to be capable of being abstracted and expressed as a number of historical theorems. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy stands on the same basis as Religion and has the same object-the universal reason existing in and for itself; Mind desires to make this object its own, as is done with Religion in the act and form of worship. 
 - HoP 1

But the form, as it is present in Religion, is different from what is found to be contained in Philosophy, and on this account a history of Philosophy is different from a history of Religion. 
 - HoP 1

Worship is only the operation of reflection; Philosophy attempts to bring about the reconciliation by means of thinking knowledge, because Mind desires to take up its Being into itself. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy is related in the form of thinking consciousness to its object; with Religion it is different. 
 - HoP 1

But the distinction between the two should not be conceived of so abstractly as to make it seem that thought is only in Philosophy and not in Religion. 
 - HoP 1

The latter has likewise ideas and universal thoughts. 
 - HoP 1

Because both are so nearly related, it is an old tradition in the history of Philosophy to deduce Philosophy from Persian, Indian, or similar philosophy, a custom which is still partly retained in all histories of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

The Oriental ideas and religious worship which prevailed throughout the West up to the time of the Roman Empire, likewise bear the name of Oriental Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

In the Persian and Indian Religions very deep, sublime and speculative thoughts are even expressed. 
 - HoP 1

Indeed, in Religion we even meet philosophies directly expressed, as in the Philosophy of the Fathers. 
 - HoP 1

The scholastic Philosophy really was Theology; there is found in it a union or, if you will, a mixture of Theology and Philosophy which may very well puzzle us. 
 - HoP 1

Difference between Philosophy and Religion. 
 - HoP 1

The consideration of the mythical aspect of Religion or the historical and positive side generally, is interesting, because from it the difference in respect of form will show in what this content is antagonistic to Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Indeed, taken in its connections, its difference passes into apparent inconsistency. 
 - HoP 1

This diversity is not only found in our contemplation but forms a very definite element in history. 
 - HoP 1

It is required by Philosophy that it should justify its beginning and its manner of knowledge, and Philosophy has thus placed itself in opposition to Religion. 
 - HoP 1

On the other hand Philosophy is combated and condemned by Religion and by the Churches. 
 - HoP 1

The Greek popular religion indeed, proscribed several philosophers; but the opposition is even more apparent in the Christian Church. 
 - HoP 1

The question is thus not only whether regard is to be paid to Religion in the history of Philosophy, for it has been the case that Philosophy has paid attention to Religion, and the latter to the former. 
 - HoP 1

Since neither of the two has allowed the other to rest undisturbed, we are not permitted to do so either. 
 - HoP 1

Of their relations, therefore, we must speak definitely, openly and honestly-aborder la question, as the French say. 
 - HoP 1

We must not hesitate, as if such a discussion were too delicate, nor try to help ourselves out by beating about the bush; nor must we seek to find evasions or shifts, so that in the end no one can tell what we mean. 
 - HoP 1

We must not seem to wish to leave Religion alone. 
 - HoP 1

This is nothing else than to appear to wish to conceal the fact that Philosophy has directed its efforts against Religion. 
 - HoP 1

Religion, that is, the theologians, are indeed the cause of this; they ignore Philosophy, but only in order that they may not be contradicted in their arbitrary reasoning. 
 - HoP 1

It may appear as if Religion demanded that man should abstain from thinking of universal matters and Philosophy because they are merely worldly wisdom and represent human operations. 
 - HoP 1

Human reason is here opposed to the divine. 
 - HoP 1

Thus what is external and accidental is regarded as emphatically the work of God, and what has its root in will and conscience, as the work of man. 
 - HoP 1

But the productions of human reason might, at least, be esteemed as much as Nature. 
 - HoP 1

In so doing, however, we cede less to reason than is permitted to us. 
 - HoP 1

If the life and the action of animals be divine, human action must stand much higher, and must be worthy to be called divine in an infinitely higher sense. 
 - HoP 1

The preeminence of human thought must forthwith be avowed. 
 - HoP 1

Spirit is infinitely high above Nature, in it the Divine Nature manifests itself more than in Nature. 
 - HoP 1

But the form in which the universal content which is in and for itself, first belongs to Philosophy is the form of Thought, the form of the universal itself. 
 - HoP 1

In Religion, however, this content is for immediate and outward perception, and further for idea and sensation through art. 
 - HoP 1

The import is for the sensuous nature; it is the evidence of the Mind which comprehends that content. 
 - HoP 1

To make this clearer, the difference must be recollected between that which we are and have, and how we know the same-that is, in what manner we know it and have it as our object. 
 - HoP 1

This distinction is an infinitely important matter, and it alone is concerned in the culture of races and of individuals. 
 - HoP 1

We are men and have reason; what is human, or above all, what is rational vibrates within us, both in our feelings, mind and heart and in our subjective nature generally. 
 - HoP 1

It is in this corresponding vibration and in the corresponding motion effected that a particular content becomes our own and is like our own. 
 - HoP 1

The manifold nature of the determinations which it contains is concentrated and wrapt up within this inward nature-an obscure motion of Mind in itself and in universal substantiality. 
 - HoP 1

The content is thus directly identical with the simple abstract certainty of ourselves and with self-consciousness. 
 - HoP 1

But Mind, because it is Mind, is as truly consciousness. 
 - HoP 1

What is confined within itself in its simplicity must be objective to itself and must come to be known. 
 - HoP 1

The whole difference lies in the manner and method of this objectivity, and hence in the manner and method of consciousness. 
 - HoP 1

This method and manner extends from the simple expression of the dulness of mere feeling to the most objective form, to that which is in and for itself objective, to Thought. 
 - HoP 1

This object, however, comprehending in itself the whole substantial content, is itself still undeveloped and entirely undetermined. 
 - HoP 1

To develop that content, to comprehend, express and bring to consciousness its relations, is the commencement, creation and manifestation of Religion. 
 - HoP 1

The form in which this developed content first possesses objectivity is that of immediate perception, of sensuous idea or of a more defined idea deduced from natural, physical or mental manifestations and conditions. 
 - HoP 1

Art brings about this consciousness, in that it gives permanence and cohesion to the fleeting visible appearance through which objectivity passes in sensation. 
 - HoP 1

Art has thus become the instructress of the people. 
 - HoP 1

The consciousness of this Religion is rather the product of thinking imagination, or of thought which comprehends through the organ of imagination alone and finds expression in its forms. 
 - HoP 1

If the infinite Thought, the absolute Mind, has revealed and does reveal itself in true Religion, that in which it reveals itself is the heart, the representing consciousness and the understanding of what is finite. 
 - HoP 1

Religion is not merely directed to every sort of culture. 
 - HoP 1

To the poor is the Gospel preached,  but it must as being Religion expressly directed towards heart and mind, enter into the sphere of subjectivity and consequently into the region of finite methods of representation. 
 - HoP 1

To make this clearer, something must be said as to what is the meaning of comprehension. 
 - HoP 1

This is the first absolute condition necessary to comprehension; what is not implicitly there cannot come within it or be for it-that is, a content which is infinite and eternal. 
 - HoP 1

For the substantial as infinite, is just that which has no limitations in that to which it is related, for else it would be limited and not the true substantial. 
 - HoP 1

And Mind is that alone which is not implicit, which is finite and external; for what is finite and external is no longer what is implicit but what is for another, what has entered into a relation. 
 - HoP 1

The assertion of positive Religion is that its truths exist without having their source known, so that the content as given, is one which is above and beyond reason. 
 - HoP 1

Through whatever individual the Truth may have been given, the external matter is historical, and this is indifferent to the absolute content and to itself, since the person is not the import of the doctrine. 
 - HoP 1

But the Christian Religion has this characteristic that the Person of Christ in His character of the Son of God, Himself partakes of the nature of God. 
 - HoP 1

But there is the further fact, that neither in Religion nor in Philosophy does this external form remain, nor can it so remain. 
 - HoP 1

A form of the imagination or an historical form, such as Christ, must for the spirit be spiritual; and thus it ceases to be an external matter, seeing that the form of externality is dead. 
 - HoP 1

We must know God in Spirit and in Truth. 
 - HoP 1

He is the absolute and actual Spirit. 
 - HoP 1

The relation borne by the human spirit to this Spirit involves the following considerations. 
 - HoP 1

When man determines to adopt a Religion he asks himself, What is the ground of my faith?  The Christian Religion replies-The Spirits witness to its content. 
 - HoP 1

Spirit in itself is merely this comprehension of itself. 
 - HoP 1

There is only one Spirit, the universal divine Spirit. 
 - HoP 1

As universal, it is object to itself, and thus determined as a particular, it is this individual: but as universal it reaches over this its other,  so that its other  and itself are comprised in one. 
 - HoP 1

The true universality seems, popularly expressed, to be two-what is common to the universal itself and to the particular. 
 - HoP 1

A division is formed in the understanding of itself, and the Spirit is the unity of what is understood and the understanding person. 
 - HoP 1

The divine Spirit which is comprehended, is objective; the subjective Spirit comprehends. 
 - HoP 1

But Spirit is not passive, or else the passivity can be momentary only; there is one spiritual substantial unity. 
 - HoP 1

The subjective Spirit is the active, but the objective Spirit is itself this activity; the active subjective Spirit is that which comprehends the divine, and in its comprehension of it it is itself the divine Spirit. 
 - HoP 1

The relation of Spirit to self alone is the absolute determination; the divine Spirit lives in its own communion and presence. 
 - HoP 1

This comprehension has been called Faith, but it is not an historical faith; we Lutherans-I am a Lutheran and will remain the same-have only this original faith. 
 - HoP 1

This unity is not the Substance of Spinoza, but the apprehending Substance in self-consciousness which makes itself eternal and relates to universality. 
 - HoP 1

The talk about the limitations of human thought is futile; to know God is the only end of Religion. 
 - HoP 1

The testimony of the Spirit to the content of Religion is itself Religion; it is a testimony that both bears witness and at the same time is that witness. 
 - HoP 1

The Spirit proves itself, and does so first in the proof; it is only proved because it proves itself and shows or manifests itself. 
 - HoP 1

This permeating and permeated Spirit now enters into conception; God goes forth into the other  and makes Himself objective. 
 - HoP 1

All that pertains to revelation and its reception, and which comes before us in mythology, here appears; everything which is historical and which belongs to what is positive has here its proper place. 
 - HoP 1

To speak more definitely, we now have the Christ who came into the world nearly two thousand years ago. 
 - HoP 1

But He says, I am with you even unto the ends of the earth; where two or three are gathered together in My Name, there will I be in the midst. 
 - HoP 1

I shall not be seen of you in the flesh, but The Spirit of Truth will guide you into all Truth. 
 - HoP 1

The external is not the true relation; it will disappear. 
 - HoP 1

The two stages have here been given, the first of which is the stage of devotion, of worship, such as that reached in partaking of the Communion. 
 - HoP 1

That is the perception of the divine Spirit in the community in which the present, indwelling, living Christ as self-consciousness has attained to actuality. 
 - HoP 1

It is the same thing in the Greek Religion where the god present in devotion changes into prosaic statues and marble; or in painting, where this externality is likewise arrived at, when the god becomes mere canvas or wood. 
 - HoP 1

The Supper is, according to the Lutheran conception, of Faith alone; it is a divine satisfaction, and is not adored as if it were the Host. 
 - HoP 1

Thus a sacred image is no more to us than is a stone or thing. 
 - HoP 1

The second point of view must indeed be that with which consciousness begins; it must start from the external comprehension of this form: it must passively accept report and take it up into memory. 
 - HoP 1

But if it remain where it is, that is the unspiritual point of view; to remain fixed in this second standpoint in this dead far-away historic distance, is to reject the Spirit. 
 - HoP 1

The sins of him who lies against the Holy Ghost cannot be forgiven. 
 - HoP 1

It has nothing to do with this, for it comprehends itself within itself alone, in its infinitude. 
 - HoP 1

If it be said of Philosophy that it makes reality the subject of its knowledge, the principal point is that the reality should not be one outside of that of which it is the reality. 
 - HoP 1

For example, if from the real content of a book, I abstract the binding, paper, ink, language, the many thousand letters that are contained in it, the simple universal content as reality, is not outside of the book. 
 - HoP 1

Similarly law is not outside of the individual, but it constitutes the true Being of the individual. 
 - HoP 1

The reality of my Mind is thus in my Mind itself and not outside of it; it is my real Being, my own substance, without which I am without existence. 
 - HoP 1

Feeling, anticipation, knowledge of God, are only thus in men; without such, the divine Mind would not be the in and for itself Universal. 
 - HoP 1

Since reality is itself Spirit and not an abstraction, God is not a God for the dead but for the living,  and indeed for living spirits. 
 - HoP 1

The great Creator was alone   And experienced desire,   Therefore He created Spirits,   Holy mirrors of His holiness. 
 - HoP 1

The noblest Being He found no equal;   From out the bowl of all the spiritual world,   There sparkled up to Him infinitude. 
 - HoP 1

Religion is also the point of view from which this existence is known. 
 - HoP 1

Worship, commencing with the external, then turns against and abrogates it as has just been said, and thus Philosophy is justified through the acts and forms of worship, and only does what they do. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy thinks and conceives of that which Religion represents as the object of consciousness, whether it is as the work of the imagination or as existent facts in history. 
 - HoP 1

The form of the knowledge of the object is, in religious consciousness, such as pertains to the ordinary idea, and is thus more or less sensuous in nature. 
 - HoP 1

In Philosophy we do not say that God begot a Son, which is a relation derived from natural life. 
 - HoP 1

Thought, or the substance of such a relation, is therefore still recognized in Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Since Philosophy thinks its object, it has the advantage of uniting the two stages of religious consciousness-which in Religion are different moments-into one unity in philosophic thought. 
 - HoP 1

The first stage in the order of manifestation is definite existence, or a determinate Being-for-self as opposed to the other. 
 - HoP 1

The later form is that Thought embraces itself in the concrete, immerses itself in itself, and Mind, as such, comes in it to consciousness. 
 - HoP 1

In the earlier stage, Mind is abstract, and in this constraint it knows itself to be different, and in opposition to the other. 
 - HoP 1

Generally speaking, the course of this antithesis in history is that Thought first of all comes forth within Religion, as not free and in separate manifestations. 
 - HoP 1

Secondly, it strengthens itself, feels itself to be resting upon itself, holds and conducts itself inimically towards the other form, and does not recognize itself therein. 
 - HoP 1

In the third place, it concludes by acknowledging itself as in this other. 
 - HoP 1

Thus the ancient Greek philosophers generally respected the popular religion, or at least they did not oppose it, or reflect upon it. 
 - HoP 1

Those coming later, including even Xenophanes, handled popular ideas most severely, and thus many so-called atheists made their appearance. 
 - HoP 1

Plato declaimed against the poets and their gods. 
 - HoP 1

Latest of all Philosophy permits full justice to be done to the content of Religion through the speculative Notion, which is through Thought itself. 
 - HoP 1

For this end the Notion must have grasped itself in the concrete and penetrated to concrete spirituality. 
 - HoP 1

This must be the standpoint of the Philosophy of the present time; it has begun within Christianity and can have no other content than the world-spirit. 
 - HoP 1

When that spirit comprehends itself in Philosophy, it also comprehends itself in that form which formerly was inimical to Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Thus Religion has a content in common with Philosophy the forms alone being different; and the only essential point is that the form of the Notion should be so far perfected as to be able to grasp the content of Religion. 
 - HoP 1

The Truth is just that which has been called the mysteries of Religion. 
 - HoP 1

These constitute the speculative element in Religion such as were called by the Neo-platonists Î¼ÏÎµá¿Î½, Î¼ÏÎµá¿ÏÎ¸Î±Î¹ , or being occupied with speculative Notions. 
 - HoP 1

By mysteries is meant, superficially speaking, the secret, what remains such and does not arrive at being known. 
 - HoP 1

But in the Eleusinian mysteries there was nothing unknown; all Athenians were initiated into them, Socrates alone shut himself out. 
 - HoP 1

Openly to make them known to strangers was the one thing forbidden, as indeed it was made a crime in the case of certain people. 
 - HoP 1

Such matters however, as being holy, were not to be spoken of. 
 - HoP 1

Herodotus often expressly says  that he would speak of the Egyptian Divinities and mysteries in as far as it was pious so to do: he knew more, but it would be impious to speak of them. 
 - HoP 1

In the Christian Religion dogmas are called mysteries. 
 - HoP 1

They are that which man knows about the Nature of God. 
 - HoP 1

Neither is there anything mysterious in this; it is known by all those who are partakers in that Religion, and these are thus distinguished from the followers of other Religions. 
 - HoP 1

Hence mystery here signifies nothing unknown, since all Christians are in the secret. 
 - HoP 1

Mysteries are in their nature speculative, mysterious certainly to the understanding, but not to reason; they are rational, just in the sense of being speculative. 
 - HoP 1

When the understanding which does not comprehend the truths of Religion, calls itself the illuminating reason and plays the lord and master, it goes astray. 
 - HoP 1

The scholastics were not supernaturalists in this sense; they knew the dogmas of the Church in thought and in conception. 
 - HoP 1

But this is not the case on the other side. 
 - HoP 1

Religion from the standpoint of idea, comprehends only what stands on the same platform as itself, and not Philosophy, the Notion, the universal thought determinations. 
 - HoP 1

Often no injustice is done to a Philosophy when its opposition to Religion has been made matter of reproach; but often, too, a wrong has been inflicted where this is done from the religious point of view. 
 - HoP 1

The form of Religion is necessary to Mind as it is in and for itself; it is the form of truth as it is for all men, and for every mode of consciousness. 
 - HoP 1

There is the question still confronting us as to what attitude we must take in reference to this matter in the history of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

The religious element to be excluded from the content of the History of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Mythology first meets us, and it seems as if it might be drawn within the history of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

It is indeed a product of the imagination, but not of caprice, although that also has its place here. 
 - HoP 1

Mythology can now be studied for art, &c But the thinking mind must seek out the substantial content, the thought and the theory implicitly contained therein, as reason is sought in Nature. 
 - HoP 1

This mode of treating mythology was that of the Neo-platonists; in recent times it has for the most part become the work of my friend Creuzer in symbolism. 
 - HoP 1

This method of treatment is combated and condemned by others. 
 - HoP 1

Man, it is said, must set to work historically alone, and it is not historic when a theory unthought of by the ancients, is read into a myth, or brought out of it. 
 - HoP 1

In one light, this is quite correct, for it points to a method adopted by Creuzer, and also by the Alexandrians who acted in a similar way. 
 - HoP 1

In conscious thought the ancients had not such theories before them, nor did anyone maintain them, yet to say that such content was not implicitly present, is an absurd contention. 
 - HoP 1

This sensuous form produced as it is by an historic or natural method, must be determined on many sides, and this external determination must, more or less, be of such a nature as not to express the Idea. 
 - HoP 1

But that there is a Reason there, must certainly be recognized, and it is essential so to comprehend and grasp mythology. 
 - HoP 1

But Mythology must remain excluded from our history of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

And this is just what forms the immense distinction which we saw above, between capacity and actuality. 
 - HoP 1

The theorems which are implicite contained within Religion do not concern us; they must be in the form of thoughts, since Thought alone is the absolute form of the Idea. 
 - HoP 1

In many mythologies, images are certainly used along with their significance, or else the images are closely attended by their interpretation. 
 - HoP 1

The ancient Persians worshipped the sun, or fire, as being the highest existence; the first cause in the Persian Religion is Zervane Akerene-unlimited time, eternity. 
 - HoP 1

This simple eternal existence possesses according to Diogenes LÃ¦rtius , the two principles Ormuzd  and Ahriman , the rulers over good and evil. 
 - HoP 1

But through two opposed and inimical principles of which the one impels towards what is right, and the other in the opposite direction, if not the whole world, at least this earth is influenced in different ways. 
 - HoP 1

Zoroaster has thus emphatically set up the one principle  as being the Light, and the other  as the Darkness. 
 - HoP 1

Between the two  is Mithra, hence called by the Persians the Mediator. 
 - HoP 1

Mithra is then likewise substance, the universal existence, the sun raised to a totality. 
 - HoP 1

Ahriman is sometimes called the first-born son of the Light, but Ormuzd only remained within the Light. 
 - HoP 1

At the creation of the visible world, Ormuzd places on the earth in his incomprehensible kingdom of Light, the firm arches of the heavens which are above yet surrounded on every side with the first original Light. 
 - HoP 1

Midway to the earth is the high hill Albordi, which reaches into the source of Light. 
 - HoP 1

Ormuzds empire of Light extended uninterruptedly over the firm vault of the heavens and the hill Albordi, and over the earth too, until the third age was reached. 
 - HoP 1

Then Ahriman, whose kingdom of night was formerly bound beneath the earth, broke in upon Ormuzds corporeal world and ruled in common with him. 
 - HoP 1

Now the space between heaven and earth was divided into light and night. 
 - HoP 1

As Ormuzd had formerly only a spiritual kingdom of light, Ahriman had only one of night, but now that they were intermingled he placed the terrestrial light thus created in opposition to the terrestrial night. 
 - HoP 1

From this time on, two corporeal worlds stand opposed, one pure and good, and one impure and evil, and this opposition permeates all nature. 
 - HoP 1

On Albordi, Ormuzd created Mithra as mediator for the earth. 
 - HoP 1

The end of the creation of the bodily world is none other than to reinstate existence, fallen from its creator, to make it good again, and thus to make the evil disappear for ever. 
 - HoP 1

Because properly the Light principle is the only existence of both, and the principle of Darkness is the null and void,-the principle of Light identifies itself with Mithra, which was before called the highest existence. 
 - HoP 1

The opposition has laid aside the appearance of contingency, but the spiritual principle is not separate from the physical, because the good and evil are both determined as Light and Darkness. 
 - HoP 1

These determinations lie much nearer to Thought; they are not mere images or symbols, but yet these myths do not concern Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

In them Thought does not take the first place, for the myth-form remains predominant. 
 - HoP 1

In all religions this oscillation between form and thought is found, and such a combination still lies outside Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

This is also so in the Sanchuniathonic Cosmogony of the Phnicians. 
 - HoP 1

These fragments, which are found in Eusebius , are taken from the translation of the Sanchuniathon from Phnician into Greek made by a Grammarian named Philo from Biblus. 
 - HoP 1

Philo lived in the time of Vespasian and ascribes great antiquity to the Sanchuniathon. 
 - HoP 1

It is there said, The principles of things are found in Chaos, in which the elements exist undeveloped and confused, and in a Spirit of Air. 
 - HoP 1

The latter permeated the chaos, and with it engendered a slimy matter or mud  which contained within it the living forces and the germs of animals. 
 - HoP 1

By mingling this mud with the component matter of chaos and the resulting fermentation, the elements separated themselves. 
 - HoP 1

The fire elements ascended into the heights and formed the stars. 
 - HoP 1

Through their influence in the air, clouds were formed and the earth was made fruitful. 
 - HoP 1

From the mingling of water and earth, through the mud converted into putrefying matter, animals took their origin as imperfect and senseless. 
 - HoP 1

These again begot other animals perfect and endowed with senses. 
 - HoP 1

It was the crash of thunder in a thunder-storm that caused the first animals still sleeping in their husks to waken up to life. 
 - HoP 1

Berosus lived in the time of Alexander, is said to have been a Priest of Bel and to have drawn upon the archives of the temple at Babylon. 
 - HoP 1

He says, The original god is Bel and the goddess Omoroka , but beside them there were yet other gods. 
 - HoP 1

Bel divided Omoroka in two, in order to create from her parts heaven and earth. 
 - HoP 1

Hereupon he cut off his own head and the human race originated from the drops of his divine blood. 
 - HoP 1

After the creation of man, Bel banished the darkness, divided heaven and earth, and formed the world into its natural shape. 
 - HoP 1

Since certain parts of the earth seemed to him to be insufficiently populated, he compelled another god to lay hands upon himself, and from his blood more men and more kinds of animals were created. 
 - HoP 1

At first the men lived a wild and uncultivated life, until a monster   joined them into a state, taught them arts and sciences, and in a word brought Humanity into existence. 
 - HoP 1

The monster set about this end with the rising of the sun out of the sea, and with its setting he again hid himself under the waves. 
 - HoP 1

What belongs to Mythology may in the second place make a pretence of being a kind of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

It has produced philosophers who availed themselves of the mythical form in order to bring their theories and systems more prominently before the imagination, for they made the thoughts the content of the myth. 
 - HoP 1

But the myth is not a mere cloak in the ancient myths; it is not merely that the thoughts were there and were concealed. 
 - HoP 1

This may happen in our reflecting times; but the first poetry does not start from a separation of prose and poetry. 
 - HoP 1

If philosophers used myths, it was usually the case that they had the thoughts and then sought for images appropriate to them; Plato has many beautiful myths of this kind. 
 - HoP 1

Others likewise have spoken in myths, as for example, Jacobi, whose Philosophy took the form of the Christian Religion, through which he gave utterance to matter of a highly speculative nature. 
 - HoP 1

But this form is not suitable to Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Thought which has itself as object, must have raised itself to its own form, to the form of thought. 
 - HoP 1

Plato is often esteemed on account of his myths; he is supposed to have evinced by their means greater genius than other philosophers were capable of. 
 - HoP 1

It is contended here that the myths of Plato are superior to the abstract form of expression, and Platos method of representation is certainly a wonderful one. 
 - HoP 1

When he comes to the matter in point, Plato expresses himself otherwise, as we see in the Parmenides, where simple thought determinations are used without imagery. 
 - HoP 1

Externally these myths may certainly serve when the heights of speculative thought are left behind, in order to present the matter in an easier form, but the real value of Plato does not rest in his myths. 
 - HoP 1

If thought once attains power sufficient to give existence to itself within itself and in its element, the myth becomes a superfluous adornment, by which Philosophy is not advanced. 
 - HoP 1

Men often lay hold of nothing but these myths. 
 - HoP 1

Hence Aristotle has been misunderstood just because he intersperses similes here and there; the simile can never be entirely in accord with thought, for it always carries with it something more. 
 - HoP 1

The difficulty of representing thoughts as thoughts always attaches to the expedient of expression in sensuous form. 
 - HoP 1

Thought, too, ought not to be concealed by means of the myth, for the object of the mythical is just to give expression to and to reveal thought. 
 - HoP 1

The symbol is undoubtedly insufficient for this expression; thought concealed in symbols is not yet possessed, for thought is self-revealing, and hence the myth does not form a medium adequate for its conveyance. 
 - HoP 1

Aristotle  says, It is not worth while to treat seriously of those whose philosophy takes a mythical form. 
 - HoP 1

Such is not the form in which thought allows itself to be stated, but only is a subordinate mode. 
 - HoP 1

Connected with this, there is a similar method of representing the universal content by means of numbers, lines and geometric figures. 
 - HoP 1

These are figurative, but not concretely so, as in the case of myths. 
 - HoP 1

Thus it may be said that eternity is a circle, the snake that bites its own tail. 
 - HoP 1

This is only an image, but Mind does not require such a symbol. 
 - HoP 1

There are people who value such methods of representation, but these forms do not go far. 
 - HoP 1

The most abstract determinations can indeed be thus expressed, but any further progress brings about confusion. 
 - HoP 1

Just as the freemasons have symbols which are esteemed for their depth of wisdom-depth as a brook is deep when one cannot see the bottom-that which is hidden very easily seems to men deep, or as if depth were concealed beneath. 
 - HoP 1

But when it is hidden, it may possibly prove to be the case that there is nothing behind. 
 - HoP 1

This is so in freemasonry, in which everything is concealed to those outside and also to many people within, and where nothing remarkable is possessed in learning or in science, and least of all in Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Thought is, on the contrary, simply its manifestation; clearness is its nature and itself. 
 - HoP 1

The act of manifestation is not a condition which may be or may not be equally, so that thought may remain as thought when it is not manifested, but its manifestation is itself, its Being. 
 - HoP 1

The two first of the three are certainly united by addition; this kind of union is, however, the worst form of unity. 
 - HoP 1

In Religion the three make their appearance in a deeper sense as the Trinity, and in Philosophy as the Notion, but enumeration forms a bad method of expression. 
 - HoP 1

There is the same objection to it as would exist to making the mensuration of space the medium for expressing the absolute. 
 - HoP 1

People also quote the Philosophy of the Chinese, of the FoÃ¯, in which it is said that thoughts are represented by numbers. 
 - HoP 1

Yet the Chinese have explained their symbols and hence have made their meaning evident. 
 - HoP 1

Universal simple abstractions have been present to all people who have arrived at any decree of culture. 
 - HoP 1

We have still to remark in the third place, that Religion, as such, does not merely form its representations after the manner of art; and also that Poetry likewise contains actual thoughts. 
 - HoP 1

In the case of the poets whose art has speech as medium, we find all through deep universal thought regarding reality; these are more explicitly expressed in the Indian Religion, but with the Indians everything is mixed up. 
 - HoP 1

The story of the Phnix is well known as an example of this; it is one which took its origin in the East. 
 - HoP 1

We are able similarly to find thoughts about life and death and of the transition of Being into passing away; from life comes death and from death comes life; even in Being, in what is positive, the negation is already present. 
 - HoP 1

The negative side must indeed contain within it the positive, for all change, all the process of life is founded on this. 
 - HoP 1

But such reflections only occasionally come forth; they are not to be taken as being proper philosophic utterances. 
 - HoP 1

For Philosophy is only present when thought, as such, is made the absolute ground and root of everything else, and in these modes of representation this is not so. 
 - HoP 1

In the Greek Religion we find the thought-determination eternal necessity;  which means an absolute and clearly universal relation. 
 - HoP 1

But such thought has other subjects besides; it only expresses a relation, the necessity to be the true and all-embracing Being. 
 - HoP 1

Thus neither must we take this form into our consideration. 
 - HoP 1

We might speak in that way of a philosophy of Euripides, Schiller or Goethe. 
 - HoP 1

Particular theories found in Religion. 
 - HoP 1

In conclusion, the philosophy which we find within Religion does not concern us. 
 - HoP 1

We find deep, speculative thoughts regarding the nature of God not only in the Indian Religions, but also in the Fathers and the Schoolmen. 
 - HoP 1

In the history of dogmatism there is a real interest in becoming acquainted with these thoughts, but they do not belong to the history of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Nevertheless more notice must be taken of the Schoolmen than of the Fathers, for they were certainly great philosophers to whom the culture of Christendom owes much. 
 - HoP 1

Thought in this manner does not represent and know itself as the ultimate and absolute culmination of the content, or as the inwardly self-determining Thought. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophic teaching here finds itself within a strongly bound system and not as thought which emanates freely from itself. 
 - HoP 1

Thus with the scholastics, too, Thought does not construct itself out of itself, but depends upon hypotheses; and although it ever rests more and more upon itself, it never does so in opposition to the doctrine of the Church. 
 - HoP 1

Both must and do agree, since Thought has to prove from itself what the Church has already verified. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy proper distinguished from Popular Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

The second sphere, Religion, is deficient in that it only had the content or the objective moment in common with Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

In it independent thought was an essential moment, since the subject had an imaginary or historical form. 
 - HoP 1

A third point of view seems to unite both elements, and that is popular Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

It deals with universal objects and philosophizes as to God and the world; and thought is likewise occupied in learning about these matters. 
 - HoP 1

Yet this Philosophy must also be cast aside. 
 - HoP 1

The writings of Cicero may be put under this category; they contain a kind of philosophy that has its own place and in which excellent things are said. 
 - HoP 1

Cicero formed many experiences both in the affairs of life and mind, and from them and after observing what takes place in the world, he deduced the truth. 
 - HoP 1

He expresses himself with culture on the concerns most important to man, and hence his great popularity. 
 - HoP 1

Fanatics and mystics may from another point of view be reckoned as in this category. 
 - HoP 1

They give expression to a deep sense of devotion, and have had experiences in the higher regions. 
 - HoP 1

They are able to express the highest content, and the result is attractive. 
 - HoP 1

We thus find the brightest gleams of thought in the writings of a Pascal-as we do in his PensÃ©es. 
 - HoP 1

But the drawback that attaches to this Philosophy is that the ultimate appeal-even in modern times-is made to the fact that men are constituted such as they are by nature, and with this Cicero is very free. 
 - HoP 1

A second matter of remark is that the Chinese have also taken up their attention with abstract thoughts and with pure categories. 
 - HoP 1

The old book Y-king, or the Book of Principles, serves as the foundation for such; it contains the wisdom of the Chinese, and its origin is attributed to Fohi. 
 - HoP 1

That which is there by him related passes into what is quite mythological, fabulous and even senseless. 
 - HoP 1

The main point in it is the ascription to him of the discovery of a table with certain signs or figures  which he saw on the back of a horse-dragon as it rose out of the river. 
 - HoP 1

This table contains parallel lines above one another, which have a symbolical signification; and the Chinese say that these lines are the foundation of their characters as also of their philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

These symbols are quite abstract categories, and consequently the most superficial determinations of the understanding. 
 - HoP 1

It must certainly be considered that pure thoughts are brought to consciousness, but in this case we make no advance, merely remaining stationary so far as they are concerned. 
 - HoP 1

The concrete is not conceived of speculatively, but is simply taken from ordinary ideas, inasmuch as it is expressed in accordance with their forms of representation and of perception. 
 - HoP 1

Hence in this collection of concrete principles there is not to be found in one single instance a sensuous conception of universal natural or spiritual powers. 
 - HoP 1

To satisfy the curious, I will give these principles in greater detail. 
 - HoP 1

The two fundamental, figures are a horizontal line  and the one which is broken into two equal parts. 
 - HoP 1

The first which is the perfect, the father, the manlike, the unity, such as is represented by the Pythagoreans, represents the affirmative; the second is the imperfect, the mother, the womanly, the duality and the negation. 
 - HoP 1

These signs are held in high esteem, for they are considered to be the Principles of things. 
 - HoP 1

First of all they are placed in combination of two from which four figures result: â, â, â, â, or the great Yang, the little Yang, the little Yin, and the great Yin. 
 - HoP 1

The signification of these four representations is matter as perfect and imperfect. 
 - HoP 1

The two Yangs are perfect matter: the first is in the category of youth and power; the second is the same matter, but as old and powerless. 
 - HoP 1

The third and fourth images, where Yin constitutes the basis, are imperfect matter, which has again the two determinations of youth and age, strength and weakness. 
 - HoP 1

These lines are further united in sets of three, and thus eight figures result, which are called Kua, â°, â±, â², â³, â´, âµ, â¶, â·. 
 - HoP 1

I will give the interpretation of these Kua just to show how superficial it is. 
 - HoP 1

The first sign, containing the great Yang and the Yang is the Heavens  or the all-pervading ether. 
 - HoP 1

The Heavens to the Chinese means what is highest, and it has been a great source of division amongst the missionaries whether they ought to call the Christian God, Tien, or not. 
 - HoP 1

The second sign is pure water , the third pure fire , the fourth thunder , the fifth wind , the sixth common water , the seventh mountains , the eighth the earth. 
 - HoP 1

We should not place heaven, thunder, wind and mountains on the same footing. 
 - HoP 1

We may thus obtain a philosophic origin for everything out of these abstract thoughts of absolute unity and duality. 
 - HoP 1

All symbols have the advantage of indicating thoughts and of calling up significations, and in this way such are likewise present there. 
 - HoP 1

Thought thus forms the first beginning, but afterwards it goes into the clouds, and Philosophy does likewise. 
 - HoP 1

Therefore if Windischmann11 in his commentary recognizes in this system of Confucius, a thorough interconnection between all Kua in the whole series,  it should be remembered that not a particle of the Notion is to be found in it. 
 - HoP 1

In Schuking there is also a chapter on Chinese wisdom, where the five elements from which everything is made make their appearance. 
 - HoP 1

These are fire, water, wood, metal and earth, which exist all in confusion, and which we should no more than we did before, allow to be principles. 
 - HoP 1

The first canon in the law is found in the Schuking, as the naming of the five elements; the second, considerations upon the last, and so it goes on. 
 - HoP 1

Universal abstraction with the Chinese thus goes on to what is concrete, although in accordance with an external kind of order only, and without containing anything that is sensuous. 
 - HoP 1

This is the principle of all Chinese wisdom and of all the objects of study in China. 
 - HoP 1

There is yet another separate sect, that of the Tao-See, the followers of which are not mandarins and attached to the state religion, nor are they Buddhists or Lamaics. 
 - HoP 1

His followers say of Lao-TsÃ¶ himself that he is Buddha who as man became the ever-existent God. 
 - HoP 1

We still have his principal writings; they have been taken to Vienna, and I have seen them there myself. 
 - HoP 1

One special passage is frequently taken from them: Without a name Tao14 is the beginning of Heaven and Earth, and with a name she is the Mother of the Universe. 
 - HoP 1

It is only in her imperfect state that she is considered with affection; who desires to know her must be devoid of passions. 
 - HoP 1
