 - HoP 1

The celebrated passage which is often quoted by the ancients is this,15 Reason has brought forth the one; the one has brought forth the two; the two have brought forth the three; and the three have produced the whole world. 
 - HoP 1

In this men have tried to find a reference to the Trinity. 
 - HoP 1

Thou meetest him and seest not his head; thou goest behind him and seest not his back. 
 - HoP 1

These contradictory expressions are called the chain of reason. 
 - HoP 1

One naturally thinks in quoting these passages of ×××¨× and of the African kingly name of Juba and also of Jovis. 
 - HoP 1

But if Philosophy has got no further than to such expression, it still stands on its most elementary stage. 
 - HoP 1

What is there to be found in all this learning?   B. 
 - HoP 1

It was believed that such was to be had in the time of Wikramaditya, who was supposed to have lived about 50 B. 
 - HoP 1

But further research discovered half a dozen Wikramadityas and careful investigation has placed this epoch in our eleventh century. 
 - HoP 1

The Indians have lines of kings and an enormous quantity of names, but everything is vague. 
 - HoP 1

Hence the holy books or Vedas also form the general groundwork for Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

The Vedas even constitute the basis for the atheistical Indian philosophies; these, too, are not wanting in gods, and they pay genuine attention to the Vedas. 
 - HoP 1

Indian Philosophy thus stands within Religion just as scholastic Philosophy stands within Christian dogmatism, having at its basis and presupposing the doctrines of the church. 
 - HoP 1

The idea of the Indians more appropriately expressed, is that there is one universal substance which may be laid hold of in the abstract or in the concrete, and out of which everything takes its origin. 
 - HoP 1

It is quite recently that we first obtained a definite knowledge of Indian Philosophy; in the main we understand by it religious ideas, but in modern times men have learned to recognize real philosophic writings. 
 - HoP 1

Colebrooke,17 in particular, communicated abstracts to us from two Indian philosophic works, and this forms the first contribution we have had in reference to Indian Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

What Frederick von Schlegel says about the wisdom of the Indians is taken from their religious ideas only. 
 - HoP 1

He is one of the first Germans who took up his attention with Indian philosophy, yet his work bore little fruit because he himself read no more than the index to the Ramayana. 
 - HoP 1

The one part, which really is orthodox, has no other purpose than to make the deliverances of the Vedas clearer, or to derive from the text of these original treatises an ingeniously thought-out Psychology. 
 - HoP 1

This system is called Mimansa, and two schools proceed from it. 
 - HoP 1

Distinguished from these there are other systems, amongst which the two chief are those of the Sanchya and Nyaya. 
 - HoP 1

The former again divides into two parts which are, however, different in form only. 
 - HoP 1

The Nyaya is the most developed; it more particularly gives the rules for reasoning, and may be compared to the Logic of Aristotle. 
 - HoP 1

Colebrooke has made abstracts from both of these systems, and he says that there are many ancient treatises upon them, and that the versus memoriales from them are very extensive. 
 - HoP 1

As to the age of the Aphorisms  of Capila, Colebrooke can say nothing; he merely mentions that they were already mentioned in other very ancient books, but he does not feel able to say anything definite in the matter. 
 - HoP 1

The Sanchya is divided into different schools, of which there are two or three, which, however, differ from one another only in a few particulars. 
 - HoP 1

It is held to be partly heterodox and partly orthodox. 
 - HoP 1

The real aim of all Indian schools and systems of Philosophy, whether atheistic or theistic, is to teach the means whereby eternal happiness can be attained before, as well as after, death. 
 - HoP 1

The Vedas say, What has to be known is the Soul; it must be distinguished from nature, and hence it will never come again. 
 - HoP 1

That means that it is exempt from metempsychosis and likewise from bodily form, so that it does not after death make its appearance in another body. 
 - HoP 1

This blessed condition therefore is, according to the Sanchya, a perfect and eternal release from every kind of ill. 
 - HoP 1

Other methods of deliverance from evil are in the excessive acts of penance performed by the Indians, to which a retreat within themselves is added. 
 - HoP 1

When this is so with me, then am I Brahma. 
 - HoP 1

Indra, for example, the god of the visible heavens, is much lower than the soul in this life of internal contemplation; many thousand Indras have passed away, but the soul is exempt from every change. 
 - HoP 1

The Sanchya only differs from Religion in that it has a complete system of thought or logic, and that the abstraction is not made a reduction to what is empty, but is raised up into the significance of a determinate thought. 
 - HoP 1

This science is stated to subsist in the correct knowledge of the principles-which may be outwardly perceptible or not-of the material and of the immaterial world. 
 - HoP 1

The Sanchya system separates itself into three parts: the method of knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the determinate form of the knowledge of principles. 
 - HoP 1

Perception is said to require no explanation. 
 - HoP 1

Inference is a conclusion arrived at from the operation of cause and effect, by which one determination merely passes over into a second. 
 - HoP 1

There are three forms, because inferences are made either from cause to effect, from effect to cause, or in accordance with different relations of cause and effect. 
 - HoP 1

Rain, we may say, is foretold when a cloud is seen to be gathering; fire, when a hill is seen to be smoking; or the movement of the moon is inferred when, at different times, it is observed to be in different places. 
 - HoP 1

These are simple, dry relations, originating from the understanding. 
 - HoP 1

Of objects of knowledge or of principles, the Sanchya gives five-and-twenty; and these I will mention to show the want of order that is in them. 
 - HoP 1

Nature, as the origin of everything, is said to be the universal, the material cause, eternal matter, undistinguished and undistinguishable, without parts, productive but without production, absolute substance. 
 - HoP 1

Intelligence, the first production of Nature and itself producing other principles, distinguishable as three gods through the efficacy of three qualities, which are Goodness, Foulness and Darkness. 
 - HoP 1

These form one person and three gods, namely, Brahma, Vishnu, and Maheswara. 
 - HoP 1

Consciousness, personality, the belief that in all perceptions and meditations I am present, that the objects of sense, as well as of intelligence, concern me, in short that I am I. 
 - HoP 1

It issues from the power of intelligence, and itself brings forth the following principles. 
 - HoP 1

The eleven succeeding principles are the organs of feeling, which are produced by the personality. 
 - HoP 1

There are ten external organs, comprising the five senses and five active organs-the organs of the voice, hands and feet, the excretory and genital organs. 
 - HoP 1

The eleventh organ is that of the inward sense. 
 - HoP 1

These principles are the five elements brought forth from the earlier-named rudiments-the ether which takes possession of space, air, fire, water and earth. 
 - HoP 1

In this very unsystematic form we see only the first beginnings of reflection, which seem to be put together as a universal. 
 - HoP 1

But this arrangement is, to say nothing of being unsystematic, not even intelligent. 
 - HoP 1

Formerly the principles were outside of and successive to one another; their unity is found in the Soul. 
 - HoP 1

It is said of the latter that it is not produced, and is not productive; it is individual, and hence there are many souls; it is sentient, eternal, immaterial and unchangeable. 
 - HoP 1

Colebrooke here distinguishes between the theistic and atheistic systems of the Sanchya, since the former not only admits of individual souls, but also upholds God  as the ruler of the world. 
 - HoP 1

The knowledge of the soul still remains the principal point. 
 - HoP 1

Through the union of Soul and Nature, the creation is effected, and this consists in the development of intelligence and of other principles. 
 - HoP 1

This unity is the actual support for that which is, and the means by which it is so maintained. 
 - HoP 1

The view is superficial and perverted which maintains the Easterns to have lived in unity with nature; the soul in its activity, mind, is indeed undoubtedly in relation with nature and in unity with the truth of nature. 
 - HoP 1

But this true unity essentially contains the moment of the negation of nature as it is in its immediacy; such an immediate unity is merely the life of animals, the life and perception of the senses. 
 - HoP 1

The idea which is present to the Indians is thus indeed the unity of nature and of soul, but the spiritual is only one with nature in so far as it is within itself, and at the same time manifests the natural as negative. 
 - HoP 1

As regards the creation, this is further signified. 
 - HoP 1

The souls desire and end is for satisfaction and freedom, and with this view it is endowed with a subtle environment, in which all the above-mentioned principles are contained, but only in their elementary development. 
 - HoP 1

Something of our ideal, or of the implicit is present in this idea; it is like the blossom which is ideally in the bud, and yet is not actual and real. 
 - HoP 1

The expression for this is Lingam, the generative power of nature, which holds a high place in the estimation of all Indians. 
 - HoP 1

This subtle form, says the Sanchya, also assumes a coarse bodily shape, and clothes itself in several garbs; and as a means of preventing the descent into a coarse materiality, philosophic contemplation is recommended. 
 - HoP 1

Hitherto we have observed the abstract principles; the following is to be noticed regarding the creation of the concrete actuality of the universe. 
 - HoP 1

The first eight orders have appellations which appear in Indian mythology, viz. 
 - HoP 1

Brahma, Prajapatis, Indra, &c; there are both gods and demi-gods, and Brahma himself is represented here as if he were created. 
 - HoP 1

The five lower orders are composed of animals: the four-footed animals are in two classes, birds come third, reptiles, fishes, and insects fourth, and, finally, vegetable and inorganic nature comes fifth. 
 - HoP 1

Against these three worlds, which have their place in the material creation, the system places yet another creation, and that is the Intellectual, consisting of the powers of understanding and the senses. 
 - HoP 1

These last are again divided into four classes, viz. 
 - HoP 1

Sixty-two of the impeding determinations are adduced; eight kinds of error, as many of opinion or of illusion, ten of passion as being illusion carried to extremity, eighteen of hate or sullenness, and the same of grief. 
 - HoP 1

Here there is shown somewhat of an empirical, psychological, and observing mode of treatment. 
 - HoP 1

Satisfaction is either inward or outward. 
 - HoP 1

The second satisfaction is in the belief of securing liberty through ascetic exercises, pains, torments, and penances. 
 - HoP 1

The third has to do with time-the idea that liberty will come in the course of time and without study. 
 - HoP 1

The fourth satisfaction is obtained in a belief in luck-in believing that liberty depends on fate. 
 - HoP 1

The external mode of obtaining satisfaction relates to continence from enjoyment, but continence from sensuous motives, such as dislike to the unrest of acquisition, and fear of the evil consequences of enjoyment. 
 - HoP 1

There are, again, several means of perfecting the intelligence adduced, and, amongst others, there is the direct psychological mode of perfecting mind, as is seen in the act of reasoning, in friendly converse, and so on. 
 - HoP 1

This we may find, indeed, in our applied logic. 
 - HoP 1

There is still somewhat to be remarked as to the main points of the system. 
 - HoP 1

The Sanchya, and likewise the other Indian systems of Philosophy, occupy themselves particularly with the three qualities  of the absolute Idea, which are represented as substances and as modifications of nature. 
 - HoP 1

It is noteworthy that in the observing consciousness of the Indians it struck them that what is true and in and for itself contains three determinations, and the Notion of the Idea is perfected in three moments. 
 - HoP 1

This sublime consciousness of the trinity, which we find again in Plato and others, then went astray in the region of thinking contemplation, and retains its place only in Religion, and there but as a Beyond. 
 - HoP 1

Then the understanding penetrated through it, declaring it to be senseless; and it was Kant who broke open the road once more to its comprehension. 
 - HoP 1

The reality and totality of the Notion of everything, considered in its substance, is absorbed by the triad of determinations; and it has become the business of our times to bring this to consciousness. 
 - HoP 1

It prevails in fire, and therefore flames rise up and sparks fly upwards; if it has ascendency in men, as it does have in the eight higher orders, it is the origin of virtue. 
 - HoP 1

This also is the universal-throughout and in every aspect the affirmative-in abstract form. 
 - HoP 1

The third and last quality is darkness ; it is inert and obstructive, allied to care, dullness, and disappointment, predominating in earth and water, and hence these fall down and tend ever downwards. 
 - HoP 1

With living beings stupidity takes its origin in this. 
 - HoP 1

With the Indians the third is still change and negation. 
 - HoP 1

These three qualities are represented as the essential being of nature. 
 - HoP 1

The Sanchya says, We speak of them as we do of the trees in a wood. 
 - HoP 1

Yet this is a bad simile, for the wood is but an abstract universal, in which the individuals are independent. 
 - HoP 1

Further determinations of the intelligence in respect of these qualities follow. 
 - HoP 1

This last is eight-fold, and hence eight special qualities are given as being present; viz. 
 - HoP 1

The Sanchya ascribes this power to man, in so far as he elevates himself through the working of his thought into inward subjectivity. 
 - HoP 1

But the quickest mode of reaching happiness through deep contemplation is that worship of God which consists in ever murmuring the mystic name of God, Om. 
 - HoP 1

This idea is a very general one. 
 - HoP 1

Colebrooke deals more particularly with the theistic and atheistic divisions of the Sanchya as distinguished. 
 - HoP 1

But, he says, the existence of effects depends on the soul, on consciousness, and not on Iswara. 
 - HoP 1

Everything proceeds from the great Principle, which is Intelligence;  to this the individual soul belongs, and through this it is brought about. 
 - HoP 1

As to the third division of the Sanchya, the more particular consideration of the forms of knowledge as regards the principle, I shall make a few more remarks, which may perhaps have some interest. 
 - HoP 1

The understanding and all other principles derived from it are to them effects, and from these they reason to their causes; in one respect this is analogous to our inference, but in another different. 
 - HoP 1

They perceive that effects exist even before the operation of the causes; for what does not exist cannot be made explicit in existence through causality. 
 - HoP 1

Colebrooke says, This means that effects are educts rather than products. 
 - HoP 1

But the question is just what products are. 
 - HoP 1

Cause and effect are in reality the same; a piece of a dress is not really different from the yarn from which it is woven, for the material is the same. 
 - HoP 1

This is how this relation is understood. 
 - HoP 1

As a matter of fact, it must also be said, God creates the world not out of nothing, but out of Himself; it is His own determination, by Him brought into existence. 
 - HoP 1

The distinction between cause and effect is only a formal distinction; it is the understanding that keeps them separate, and not reason. 
 - HoP 1

Moisture is the same as rain; or again we speak in mechanics of different movements, whereas motion has the same velocity before as after impact. 
 - HoP 1

The ordinary consciousness cannot comprehend the fact that there is no real distinction between cause and effect. 
 - HoP 1

The Indians infer the existence of a universal cause which is undistinguishable, while determinate things are finite,  and on this account there must be a cause permeating through them. 
 - HoP 1

Even intelligence is an effect of this cause, which is the soul in so far as it is creative in this identity with nature after its abstraction from it. 
 - HoP 1

Effect proceeds from cause, yet, on the other hand, this last is not independent, but goes back into universal cause. 
 - HoP 1

General destruction is postulated along with what is called the creation of the three worlds. 
 - HoP 1

To this the three qualities, goodness, passion, and darkness, are attributed; the further attributes of these determinations may be very interesting, but they are understood in a very superficial way. 
 - HoP 1

There are hence only the categories of admixture and of modification present. 
 - HoP 1

The Indians say:-Nature has these three qualities in her own right as her forms and characteristics; other things have them only because they are present in them as effects of the former. 
 - HoP 1

We still have to consider the relation of nature to spirit. 
 - HoP 1

Nature, although it is quite inanimate, performs the office of preparing the soul for its freedom, just as it is the function of milk-of a substance having no sensation-to nourish the calf. 
 - HoP 1

The Sanchya makes the following simile. 
 - HoP 1

Nature is like a bajadere showing herself to the soul as to an audience; she is abused for her impudence in exposing herself too often to the rude gaze of the spectators. 
 - HoP 1

But she retires when she has shown herself sufficiently; she does so because she has been seen, and the audience retires because it has seen. 
 - HoP 1

Nature has no further use as regards the soul, and yet the union remains a lasting one. 
 - HoP 1

With the attainment of intellectual knowledge through the study of principles, the final, incontrovertible, single truth is learnt, that I neither am, nor is anything mine, nor do I exist. 
 - HoP 1

That is, the personality is still distinguished from the soul, and finally personality and self-consciousness disappear for the Indian. 
 - HoP 1

Everything that comes forth in consciousness is reflected by the soul, but like an image which does not dull the crystal of the soul, and does not belong to it. 
 - HoP 1

This is a mediate spiritual knowledge of the likewise spiritualized content-a knowledge without personality and consciousness. 
 - HoP 1

The soul still indeed remains for some time in bodily garb, but this is only so after the same manner as the potters wheel, when the jar is perfected, still turns round from the effect of the previously given impulse. 
 - HoP 1

The soul thus has, according to the Indians, nothing further to do with the body, and its connection therewith is therefore a superfluous one. 
 - HoP 1

But when the separation of the already prepared soul from its body at length comes to pass, and nature is done with soul, the absolute and final liberation is accomplished. 
 - HoP 1

Here we find the crowning moments in the Sanchya philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

The philosophy of Gotama and that of Canade belong to one another. 
 - HoP 1

The philosophy of Gotama is called Nyaya , and that of Canade, Vaiseshica. 
 - HoP 1

The first is a specially perfect dialectic, and the second, on the other hand, occupies itself with physics, that is, with particular or sensuous objects. 
 - HoP 1

The system which Gotama and Canade observe is that indicated in one part of the Vedas as being the path which must be trodden in the pursuit of learning and study; viz. 
 - HoP 1

Enunciation is the specification of a thing by its name, that is, by the expression denoting it, as revelation directs; for language is considered as revealed to man. 
 - HoP 1

Definition sets forth the particular quality which constitutes the real character of a thing. 
 - HoP 1

Investigation consists in an inquiry into the adequacy and sufficiency of the definition. 
 - HoP 1

In conformity with this, the teachers of philosophy presuppose scientific terms, proceed to definitions and then come to the investigation of the thus premised subjects. 
 - HoP 1

By the name, the ordinary conception is indicated, and with it what is given in definition is compared in investigation. 
 - HoP 1

What comes next is the object to be contemplated. 
 - HoP 1

Gotama here adduces sixteen points, amongst which proof, evidence  , and what has to be proved, are the principal; the others are merely subsidiary and accessory, as contributing to the knowledge and confirmation of the truth. 
 - HoP 1

Soul then is itself the object which is to be known and proved. 
 - HoP 1

This has still to be shown more particularly. 
 - HoP 1

The first point of importance, the evidence brought forth as proof, is said to be divided into four kinds:-first of all, perception; secondly, inference, of which there are three kinds, viz. 
 - HoP 1

The third kind of evidence is comparison, the fourth, trustworthy authority, including both tradition and the revelation implied in it. 
 - HoP 1

These kinds of proof are much brought forward, both in the ancient Treatise ascribed to Gotama and in innumerable commentaries. 
 - HoP 1

The second point of importance is found in the subjects which have to be proved, and which have to be made evident; and of these twelve are here given. 
 - HoP 1

We see in this first commencement of reflection, which is quite without order, neither connection nor any totality of determinations. 
 - HoP 1

The second object of knowledge is body; the third, the organs of sensation, as the five outward senses are called. 
 - HoP 1

These are not modifications of consciousness, as the Sanchya asserts, but matter constructed out of the elements, which respectively consist of earth, water, light, air, and ether. 
 - HoP 1

The ray of light is usually invisible, just as a light is not seen at mid-day, but in certain circumstances it is visible. 
 - HoP 1

In taste, a watery substance like saliva is the organ, and so on. 
 - HoP 1

We find something similar to what is here said about sight in Platos TimÃ¦us ; there are interesting remarks upon the phosphorus of the eyes in a paper by Schultz, contained in Goethes Morphology. 
 - HoP 1

Examples of men seeing at night, so that their eyes lighted up the object, are brought forward in numbers, but the demonstration certainly demands particular conditions. 
 - HoP 1

The objects of sense form the fourth subject. 
 - HoP 1

Here Cesava, a commentator, inserts the categories of Canade, of which there are six. 
 - HoP 1

The first of these is substance, and of this there are nine kinds: earth, water, light, air, ether, time, space, soul, understanding. 
 - HoP 1

The second category is that of Quality, and of it there are twenty-four kinds, viz. 
 - HoP 1

The third category is action; the fourth, association of qualities; the fifth, distinction; the sixth, is aggregation, and, according to Canade, this is the last; other writers add negation as the seventh. 
 - HoP 1

This is the manner in which philosophy is regarded by the Indians. 
 - HoP 1

The philosophy of Gotama makes doubt the third topic, succeeding those of the evidence of knowledge, and the subjects of interest to knowledge. 
 - HoP 1

Another topic is regular proof, formal reasoning, or the perfect syllogism , which consists of five propositions:-1, the proposition; 2, the reason; 3, the instance; 4, the application; 5, the conclusion. 
 - HoP 1

This hill is burning; 2, because it smokes; 3, what smokes is burning, like a kitchen fire; 4, accordingly the hill smokes; 5, therefore it is on fire. 
 - HoP 1

This is propounded as syllogisms are with us, but in the manner adopted, the matter which is in point is propounded first. 
 - HoP 1

We should, on the contrary, begin with the general. 
 - HoP 1

This is the ordinary form, and these examples may satisfy us, yet we shall recapitulate the matter once more. 
 - HoP 1

We have seen that in India the point of main importance is the souls drawing itself within itself, raising itself up into liberty, or thought, which constitutes itself for itself. 
 - HoP 1

This becoming explicit of soul in the most abstract mode may be called intellectual substantiality, but here it is not the unity of mind and nature that is present, but directly the opposite. 
 - HoP 1

To mind, the consideration of nature is only the vehicle of thought or its exercise, which has as its aim the liberation of mind. 
 - HoP 1

Intellectual substantiality is in India the end, while in Philosophy it is in general the true commencement; to philosophize is the idealism of making thought, in its own right, the principle of truth. 
 - HoP 1

Intellectual substantiality is the opposite of the reflection, understanding, and the subjective individuality of the European. 
 - HoP 1

With us it is of importance that I will, know, believe, think this particular thing according to the grounds that I have for so doing, and in accordance with my own free will; and upon this an infinite value is set. 
 - HoP 1

The point of interest is to reach intellectual substantiality in order to drown in it that subjective vanity with all its cleverness and reflection. 
 - HoP 1

This is the advantage of arriving at this point of view. 
 - HoP 1

That intellectual substantiality that thus remaining in abstraction, has as its existence the subjective soul alone. 
 - HoP 1

Therefore what remains to be done is to force forward the real ground of the inwardly self-forming and determining objectivity-the eternal form within itself, which is what men call Thought. 
 - HoP 1

This higher kind of objectivity that unfolds itself, alone gives a place to the particular content, allows it to have free scope and receives it into itself. 
 - HoP 1

If in the Oriental view, the particular shakes and is destined to fall, it still has its place grounded on thought. 
 - HoP 1

It is able to root itself in itself, it is able to stand firm, and this is the hard European understanding. 
 - HoP 1

Such Eastern ideas tend to destroy it, but it is preserved active in the soil of thought; it cannot exist when regarded as independent, but must exist only as a moment in the whole system. 
 - HoP 1

In the Eastern Philosophy we have also discovered a definite content, which is brought under our consideration; but the consideration is destitute of thought or system because it comes from above and is outside of the unity. 
 - HoP 1

On that side there stands intellectual substantiality, on this side it appears dry and barren; the particular thus only has the dead form of simple reason and conclusion, such as we find in the Scholastics. 
 - HoP 1

Based on the ground of thought, on the other hand, the particular may receive its dues; it may be regarded and grasped as a moment in the whole organization. 
 - HoP 1

The Idea has not become objective in the Indian Philosophy; hence the external and objective has not been comprehended in accordance with the Idea. 
 - HoP 1

This is the deficiency in Orientalism. 
 - HoP 1

The true, objective ground of thought finds its basis in the real freedom of the subject; the universal or substantial must itself have objectivity. 
 - HoP 1

It is this principle that we find in the Greek world, and the object of our further consideration is its development. 
 - HoP 1

The universal first appears as quite abstract, and as such it confronts the concrete world; but its value is both for the ground of the concrete world and for that which is implicit. 
 - HoP 1

It is not a beyond, for the value of the present lies in the fact that it exists in the implicit; or that which is implicit, the universal, is the truth of present objects. 
 - HoP 1

PART ONE  GREEK PHILOSOPHY     INTRODUCTION   THE name of Greece strikes home to the hearts of men of education in Europe, and more particularly is this so with us Germans. 
 - HoP 1

Europeans have taken their religion, the life to come, the far-off land, from a point somewhat further off than Greece-they took it from the East, and more especially from Syria. 
 - HoP 1

The latter of these two ways was the earlier form in which this culture came to us; it also came from the formerly universal church which derived its origin as such from Rome, and has retained its speech even until now. 
 - HoP 1

The sources of authority in addition to the Latin Gospels have been the Fathers. 
 - HoP 1

Our law, too, boasts of deriving its most perfect forms from Rome. 
 - HoP 1

Thus it was after European manhood came to be at home with itself and to look upon the present, that the historical and that which is of foreign derivation was given. 
 - HoP 1

When man began to be at home with himself, he turned to the Greeks to find enjoyment in it. 
 - HoP 1

Let us leave the Latin and the Roman to the church and to jurisprudence. 
 - HoP 1

Higher, freer philosophic science, as also the beauty of our untrammelled art, the taste for, and love of the same, we know to have taken their root in Greek life and to have created therefrom their spirit. 
 - HoP 1

If we were to have an aspiration, it would be for such a land and such conditions. 
 - HoP 1

But what makes us specially at home with the Greeks is that they made their world their home; the common spirit of homeliness unites us both. 
 - HoP 1

In ordinary life we like best the men and families that are homely and contented in themselves, not desiring what is outside and above them, and so it is with the Greeks. 
 - HoP 1

For their spiritual development requires that which is received or foreign, as matter or stimulus only; in such they have known and borne themselves as men that were free. 
 - HoP 1

They have thus not only themselves created the substantial in their culture and made their existence their own, but they have also held in reverence this their spiritual rebirth, which is their real birth. 
 - HoP 1

The foreign origin they have so to speak thanklessly forgotten, putting it in the background-perhaps burying it in the darkness of the mysteries which they have kept secret from themselves. 
 - HoP 1

For their mind, when transformed in this spiritual new birth, is just the living in their life, and also the becoming conscious of that life as it has become actual. 
 - HoP 1

Philosophy is being at home with self, just like the homeliness of the Greek; it is mans being at home in his mind, at home with himself. 
 - HoP 1

The development and unfolding of thought has taken place with them from its earliest beginning, and in order to comprehend their Philosophy we may remain with them without requiring to seek for further and external influences. 
 - HoP 1

But we must specify more particularly their character and point of view. 
 - HoP 1

To start from the self, to live in the self, is the other extreme of abstract subjectivity, when it is still empty, or rather has made itself to be empty; such is pure formalism, the abstract principle of the modern world. 
 - HoP 1

The Greeks stand between both these extremes in the happy medium; this therefore is the medium of beauty, seeing that it is both natural and spiritual, but yet that the spiritual still remains the governing, determining subject. 
 - HoP 1

Mind immersed in nature is in substantial unity with it, and in so far as it is consciousness, it is essentially sensuous perception: as subjective consciousness it is certainly form-giving though it is devoid of measure. 
 - HoP 1

Thus it is a free subject which still possesses that original unity in content, essence and substratum, and fashions its object into beauty. 
 - HoP 1

The stage reached by Greek consciousness is the stage of beauty. 
 - HoP 1

What is natural and sensuous still pertains to this subjectivity, but yet the natural form has not equal dignity and rank with the other, nor is it predominant as is the case in the East. 
 - HoP 1

Mind, however, has not yet got itself as a medium whereby it can represent itself in itself, and from which it can form its world. 
 - HoP 1

Thus free morality could and necessarily did find a place in Greece, for the spiritual substance of freedom was here the principle of morals, laws and constitutions. 
 - HoP 1

Since the universal does not exist in independent freedom, that which is spiritual still is limited. 
 - HoP 1

From out of thy passions, oh, man,  exclaimed an ancient, thou hast derived the materials for thy gods,  just as the Easterns, and especially the Indians, did from the elements, powers and forms of Nature. 
 - HoP 1

One may add, out of Thought thou takest the element and material for God. 
 - HoP 1

Thus Thought is the ground from which God comes forth, but it is not Thought in its commencement that constitutes the first principle from which all culture must be grasped. 
 - HoP 1

It is quite the other way. 
 - HoP 1

Thus Thought is the Absolute, though not as Thought. 
 - HoP 1

That is, we have always two things to distinguish, the universal or the Notion, and the reality of this universal, for the question here arises as to whether the reality is itself Thought or Nature. 
 - HoP 1

We find in the fact that reality at first has still the immediate form and is only Thought potentially, the reason for commencing with the Greeks and from the natural philosophy of the Ionic school. 
 - HoP 1

As regards the external and historical condition of Greece at this time, Greek philosophy commences in the sixth century before Christ in the time of Cyrus, and in the period of decline in the Ionic republics in Asia Minor. 
 - HoP 1

Just because this world of beauty which raised itself into a higher kind of culture went to pieces, Philosophy arose. 
 - HoP 1

At the time of the decline in Ionic towns, the other Greece ceased to be under its ancient lines of kings; the Pelopideans and the other, and for the most part foreign, princely races had passed away. 
 - HoP 1

Greece had in many ways come into touch with the outside world and the Greek inhabitants likewise sought within themselves for a bond of fellowship. 
 - HoP 1

The patriarchal life was past, and in many states it came to be a necessity that they should constitute themselves as free, organized and regulated by law. 
 - HoP 1

Amongst these men just characterized, the seven sages-in modern times excluded from the history of Philosophy-take their place. 
 - HoP 1

In as far as they may be reckoned as milestones in the history of Philosophy, something about their character should, in the commencement of Philosophy, be shortly said. 
 - HoP 1

They came into prominence, partly as taking part in the battles of the Ionic towns, partly as expatriated, and partly as individuals of distinction in Greece. 
 - HoP 1

The names of the seven are given differently: usually, however, as Thales, Solon, Periander, Cleobulus, Chilon, Bias, Pittacus. 
 - HoP 1

Hermippus in Diogenes Laertius  specifies seventeen, and, amongst these, various people pick out seven in various ways. 
 - HoP 1

According to Diogenes Laertius  DicÃ¦archus, who came still earlier in history, only names four, and these are placed amongst the seven by all; they are Thales, Bias, Pittacus and Solon. 
 - HoP 1

Besides these, Myson, Anacharsis, Acusilaus, Epimenides, Pherecydes, &c, are mentioned. 
 - HoP 1

DicÃ¦archus in Diogenes , says of them that they are neither wise men  nor philosophers, but men of understanding  and law-givers; this judgment has become the universal one and is held to be just. 
 - HoP 1

They come in a period of transition amongst the Greeks-a transition from a patriarchal system of kings into one of law or force. 
 - HoP 1

These men have not really made science and Philosophy their aim; it is expressly said of Thales that it was in the latter part of his life that he first took to Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

Thales and Bias thus appear as the representatives of the Ionic towns. 
 - HoP 1

However, they did not follow this advice, and this isolated and weakened them, and the result was their conquest; it has always been a difficult thing for the Greeks to give up their individuality. 
 - HoP 1

By so doing they would escape servitude, be happy, and, inhabiting the largest island, subdue the others. 
 - HoP 1

But if they remained in Ionia there was no hope of liberty to be seen for them. 
 - HoP 1

Herodotus gives his corroboration to this advice-If they had followed him they would have been the happiest of Greeks. 
 - HoP 1

Such things take place, but through force and not voluntarily. 
 - HoP 1

We find the other sages under similar conditions. 
 - HoP 1

Solon was an administrator in Athens, and thereby became famous; few men have attained the honourable position of being a law-giver. 
 - HoP 1

Solon shares it with Moses, Lycurgus, Zaleucus, Numa, &c, alone. 
 - HoP 1

No individuals can be found amongst Teutonic peoples who possess the distinction of being the law-givers of their people. 
 - HoP 1

Solon was thus not a perfect statesman; this is manifest from the sequel of his history. 
 - HoP 1

This may seem strange, for a constitution must be able to afford resistance to such an attack. 
 - HoP 1

But let us see what Pisistratus did. 
 - HoP 1

What the so-called tyrants really were, is most clearly shown by the relation borne by Solon to Pisistratus. 
 - HoP 1

When orderly institutions and laws were necessary to the Greeks, we find law-givers and regents of states appearing, who laid down laws, and ruled accordingly. 
 - HoP 1

Most of the law-givers and administrators of states undertook themselves to constrain the people and to be their tyrants. 
 - HoP 1

In states where they did not undertake it, it had to be done by other individuals, for it was essential. 
 - HoP 1

He said, Men of Athens, I am wiser than some and braver than others: I am wiser than those who do not see the deceit of Pisistratus, braver than those who certainly see it, but say nothing from fear. 
 - HoP 1

As he could not do anything, he left Athens. 
 - HoP 1

Pisistratus is said to have then written a most honourable letter to Solon in his absence, which Diogenes  has preserved for us, inviting him to return to Athens, and live with him as a free citizen. 
 - HoP 1

Not only am I not the only one of the Greeks to have seized the tyranny, but I have not taken anything which was not my due, for I am of the race of Codrus. 
 - HoP 1

I have only taken back to myself what the Athenians swore they would preserve to Codrus and his race, and yet took from them. 
 - HoP 1

Moreover I am doing no evil toward gods and men, but as thou hast given laws to the Athenians, I take care  that in civil life they shall carry them out  His son Hippias did the same. 
 - HoP 1

Every Athenian gives the tenth part of his revenue, not to me, but towards the cost of the public offering, and besides for the commonwealth, and for use in case of war. 
 - HoP 1

I am not angry that thou hast disclosed my project. 
 - HoP 1

For thou didst it more out of love to the people than hate against me, and because thou didst not know how I would conduct my rule. 
 - HoP 1

For if thou hadst known this, thou wouldst have submitted to it willingly, and wouldst not have taken flight;  and so he goes on. 
 - HoP 1

Solon, in the answer given by Diogenes,  says, that he has not a personal grudge against Pisistratus, and he must call him the best of tyrants; but to turn back does not befit him. 
 - HoP 1

For he made equality of rights essential in the Athenian constitution, and himself refused the tyranny. 
 - HoP 1

By his return he would condone what was done by Pisistratus. 
 - HoP 1

Solon undoubtedly gave the laws, but it is another thing to make such regulations effectual in the manners, habits and life of a people. 
 - HoP 1

What was separate in Solon and Pisistratus, we find united in Periander in Corinth, and Pittacus in Mitilene. 
 - HoP 1

This may be enough about the outward life of the seven sages. 
 - HoP 1

They are also famed for the wisdom of the sayings which have been preserved to us; these sayings seem in great measure, however, to be superficial and hackneyed. 
 - HoP 1

The reason for this is found in the fact that, to our reflection, general propositions are quite usual; much in the Proverbs of Solomon seems to us to be superficial and commonplace for the same reason. 
 - HoP 1

But it is quite another thing to bring to the ordinary conception for the first time this same universal in the form of universality. 
 - HoP 1

Many distichs are ascribed to Solon which we still retain; their object is to express in maxims general obligations towards the gods, the family and the country. 
 - HoP 1

The wisdom of the sages is of this kind; many sayings are insignificant, but many seem to be more insignificant than they are. 
 - HoP 1

For instance, Chilon says: Stand surety, and evil awaits thee. 
 - HoP 1

On the one hand this is quite a common rule of life and prudence, but the sceptics gave to this proposition a much higher universal significance, which is also accredited to Chilon. 
 - HoP 1

This sense is, Ally thyself closely to any particular thing, and unhappiness will fall upon thee. 
 - HoP 1

The sceptics adduced this proposition independently, as demonstrating the principle of scepticism, which is that nothing is finite and definite in and for itself, being only a fleeting, vacillating phase which does not last. 
 - HoP 1

One of the most celebrated sayings is that of Solon in his conversation with Crsus, which Herodotus  has in his own way given us very fully. 
 - HoP 1

The result arrived at is this:-Nobody is to be esteemed happy before his death. 
 - HoP 1

But the noteworthy point in this narrative is that from it we can get a better idea of the standpoint of Greek reflection in the time of Solon. 
 - HoP 1

We see that happiness is put forward as the highest aim, that which is most to be desired and which is the end of man; before Kant, morality, as eudÃ¦monism, was based on the determination of happiness. 
 - HoP 1

In Solons sayings there is an advance over the sensuous enjoyment which is merely pleasant to the feelings. 
 - HoP 1

If we contrast it with Indian philosophy, we find eudÃ¦monism to be antagonistic to it. 
 - HoP 1

There the liberation of the soul from what is corporeal, the perfect abstraction, the necessity that the soul shall, in its simplicity, be at home with itself, is the final end of man. 
 - HoP 1

The stage of reflection that we reach in happiness, stands midway between mere desire and the other extreme, which is right as right and duty as duty. 
 - HoP 1

In happiness, the individual enjoyment has disappeared; the form of universality is there, but the universal does not yet come forth on its own account, and this is the issue of the conversation between Crsus and Solon. 
 - HoP 1

Man as thinking, is not solely engrossed with present enjoyment, but also with the means for obtaining that to come. 
 - HoP 1

Crsus points out to him these means, but Solon still objects to the statement of the question of Crsus. 
 - HoP 1

Because the life of Crsus had not yet expired, Solon could not deem him happy. 
 - HoP 1

And the history of Crsus bears evidence that no momentary state deserves the name of happiness. 
 - HoP 1

This edifying history holds in its embrace the whole standpoint of the reflection of that time. 
 - HoP 1

We begin with thought, as it is in a quite abstract, natural or sensuous form, and we proceed from this to the Idea as determined. 
 - HoP 1

This first period shows the beginning of philosophic thought, and goes on to its development and perfection as a totality of knowledge in itself; this takes place in Aristotle as representing the unity of what has come before. 
 - HoP 1

In Plato there is just such a union of what came earlier, but it is not worked out, for he only represents the Idea generally. 
 - HoP 1

The Neo-platonists have been called eclectics, and Plato was said to have brought about the unity; they were not, however, eclectics, but they had a conscious insight into the necessity for uniting these philosophies. 
 - HoP 1

After the concrete Idea was reached, it came forth as if in opposites, perfecting and developing itself. 
 - HoP 1

The second period is that in which science breaks itself up into different systems. 
 - HoP 1

A one-sided principle is carried through the whole conception of the world; each side is in itself formed into a totality, and stands in the relation of one extreme to another. 
 - HoP 1

The philosophical systems of Stoicism and Epicureanism are such; scepticism forms the negative to their dogmatism, while the other philosophies disappear. 
 - HoP 1

The third period is the affirmative, the withdrawal of the opposition into an ideal world or a world of thought, a divine world. 
 - HoP 1

This is the Idea developed into totality, which yet lacks subjectivity as the infinite being-for-self. 
 - HoP 1

The first extends from Thales to Anaxagoras, from abstract thought which is in immediate determinateness to the thought of the self-determining Thought. 
 - HoP 1

The second division comprises the Sophists, Socrates, and the followers of Socrates. 
 - HoP 1

The third division, which deals with Plato and Aristotle, is found in Greek science where objective thought, the Idea, forms itself into a whole. 
 - HoP 1

HALES TO ANAXAGORAS   SINCE we possess only traditions and fragments of this epoch, we may speak here of the sources of these. 
 - HoP 1

The first source is found in Plato, who makes copious reference to the older philosophers. 
 - HoP 1

Plato was willing to spend much money in procuring the writings of the older philosophers, and, from his profound study of these, his conclusions have much weight. 
 - HoP 1

In the Parmenides, for instance, we have the Eleatic philosophy, and yet the working out of this doctrine belongs peculiarly to Plato. 
 - HoP 1

We can do no better in Greek philosophy than study the first book of his Metaphysics. 
 - HoP 1

His information bears principally on later philosophers-the Stoics, Epicureans, the new Academy, and the Peripatetics. 
 - HoP 1

He saw what was ancient through their medium, and, generally speaking, through a medium of reasoning and not of speculation. 
 - HoP 1

Sextus Empiricus, a later sceptic, has importance through his writings, Hypotyposes PyrrhonicÃ¦ and adversus Mathematicos. 
 - HoP 1

The book of Diogenes Laertius  is an important compilation, and yet it brings forward copious evidence without much discrimination. 
 - HoP 1

A philosophic spirit cannot be ascribed to it; it rambles about amongst bad anecdotes extraneous to the matter in hand. 
 - HoP 1

For the lives of philosophers, and here and there for their tenets, it is useful. 
 - HoP 1

Finally, we must speak of Simplicius, a later Greek, from Cilicia, living under Justinian, in the middle of the sixth century. 
 - HoP 1

He is the most learned and acute of the Greek commentators of Aristotle, and of his writings there is much still unpublished: to him we certainly owe our thanks. 
 - HoP 1

I need give no more references, for they may be found without trouble in any compendium. 
 - HoP 1

But such a connection is in part defective in itself, and in part it is merely external. 
 - HoP 1

The one set of philosophic sects, or of philosophers classed together, which is considered as belonging to a system-that which proceeds from Thales-pursues its course in time and mind far separate from the other. 
 - HoP 1

These successive series are interwoven in spirit just as much as in their particular content. 
 - HoP 1

We come across Thales first amongst the Ionic people, to whom the Athenians belonged, or from whom the Ionians of Asia Minor, as a whole, derived their origin. 
 - HoP 1

The Ionic race appears earlier in Peloponnesus, but seems to have been removed from thence. 
 - HoP 1

It is, however, not known what nations belonged to it, for, according to Herodotus , the other Ionians, and even the Athenians, laid aside the name. 
 - HoP 1

According to Thucydides , the Ionic colonies in Asia Minor and the islands proceeded principally from Athens, because the Athenians, on account of the over-population of Attica, migrated there. 
 - HoP 1

Those spots were also the seat of early commerce and of an early culture, while Greece itself, so far as these are concerned, followed later. 
 - HoP 1

On the Asia Minor side, and also in the islands, we find Thales, Anaximander, Anaximenes, Heraclitus, Leucippus, Democritus, Anaxagoras, and Diogenes from Crete. 
 - HoP 1

On the other side are the inhabitants of Italy: Pythagoras from Samos, who lived in Italy, however; Xenophanes, Parmenides, Zeno, Empedocles; and several of the Sophists also lived in Italy. 
 - HoP 1

Anaxagoras was the first to come to Athens, and thus his science takes a middle place between both extremes, and Athens was made its centre. 
 - HoP 1

Those philosophers who turned to the east knew the absolute in a real determination of nature, while towards Italy there is the ideal determination of the absolute. 
 - HoP 1

These explanations will be sufficient for us here; but Empedocles, whom we find in Sicily, is somewhat of a natural philosopher, while Gorgias, the Sicilian sophist, remains faithful to the ideal side. 
 - HoP 1

We now have to consider further:-1, The Ionians, viz. 
 - HoP 1

Thales, Anaximander, Anaximenes; 2, Pythagoras and his followers; 3, the Eleatics, viz. 
 - HoP 1

Xenophanes, Parmenides, &c; 4, Heraclitus; 5, Empedocles, Leucippus and Democritus; 6, Anaxagoras. 
 - HoP 1

We have to trace and point out the progression of this philosophy also. 
 - HoP 1

The first and altogether abstract determinations are found with Thales and the other Ionians; they grasped the universal in the form of a natural determination, as water and air. 
 - HoP 1

Progression must thus take place by leaving behind the merely natural determination; and we find that this is so with the Pythagoreans. 
 - HoP 1

They say that number is the substance or the essence of things; number is not sensuous, nor is it pure thought, but it is a non-sensuous object of sense. 
 - HoP 1

Heraclitus declares the Absolute to be this very process, which, according to the Eleatics, was still subjective; he arrived at objective consciousness, since in it the Absolute is that which moves or changes. 
 - HoP 1

With Anaxagoras it is the moving, self-determining thought itself that is then known as existence, and this is a great step forward. 
 - HoP 1

Here we have the earlier Ionic philosophy, which we desire to treat as shortly as possible; and this is so much the easier, that the thought contained in it is very abstract and barren. 
 - HoP 1

Other philosophers than Thales, Anaximander, and Anaximenes, only come under our consideration as names. 
 - HoP 1

We have no more than half a dozen passages in the whole of the early Ionic philosophy, and that makes it an easy study. 
 - HoP 1

Yet learning prides itself most upon the ancients, for we may be most learned about that of which we know the least. 
 - HoP 1

With Thales we, properly speaking, first begin the history of Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

The life of Thales occurred at the time when the Ionic towns were under the dominion of Crsus. 
 - HoP 1

Through his overthrow , an appearance of freedom was produced, yet the most of these towns were conquered by the Persians, and Thales survived the catastrophe only a few years. 
 - HoP 1

Thales lived as a statesman partly with Crsus and partly in Miletus. 
 - HoP 1

Diogenes records, moreover , that he soon withdrew his attention from the affairs of the State and devoted himself entirely to science. 
 - HoP 1

Voyages to Phnicia are recorded of him, which, however, rest on vague tradition; but that he was in Egypt in his old age seems undoubted. 
 - HoP 1

There he was said to have learned geometry, but this would appear not to have been much, judging from the anecdote, which Diogenes  retails from a certain Hieronymus. 
 - HoP 1

It was to the effect that Thales taught the Egyptians to measure the height of their pyramids by shadow-by taking the relation borne by the height of a man to his shadow. 
 - HoP 1

The terms of the proportion are: as the shadow of a man is to the height of a man, so is the shadow of a pyramid to its height. 
 - HoP 1

If this were something new to the Egyptians, they must have been very far back in the theory of geometry. 
 - HoP 1

We have some further isolated instances of, and anecdotes about his astronomical knowledge and works. 
 - HoP 1

In gazing at and making observations on the stars, he fell into a ditch, and the people mocked him as one who had knowledge of heavenly objects and yet could not see what lay at his own feet. 
 - HoP 1

He also showed, according to Diogenes , that a wise man, if he wishes, can easily acquire riches. 
 - HoP 1

It is more important that he fixed that the year, as solar year, should have 365 days. 
 - HoP 1

The anecdote of the golden tripod to be given to the wisest man, is recorded by Diogenes ; and it carries with it considerable weight, because he combines all the different versions of the story. 
 - HoP 1

Thales died, according to Diogenes , aged seventy-eight or ninety, in the 58th Olympiad; according to Tennemann , it was in Olympiad 59, 2 , when Pythagoras came to Crotona. 
 - HoP 1

Diogenes relates that he died at one of the games, overcome by heat and thirst. 
 - HoP 1

We have no writings by Thales, and we do not know whether he was in the habit of writing. 
 - HoP 1

Diogenes Laertius  speaks of two hundred verses on astronomy, and some maxims, such as It is not the many words that have most meaning. 
 - HoP 1

As to his philosophy, he is universally recognized as the first natural philosopher, but all one knows of him is little, and yet we seem to know the most of what there is. 
 - HoP 1

We must listen to Aristotle as regards these ancient philosophers, for he speaks most sympathetically of them. 
 - HoP 1

Hence we would make mention of those who have undertaken the investigation of Being before us, and have speculated regarding the Truth, for they openly advance certain principles and first causes. 
 - HoP 1

On this account they maintain that nothing arises or passes away, because the same nature always remains. 
 - HoP 1

For instance, we say that, absolutely speaking, Socrates neither originates if he becomes beautiful or musical, nor does he pass away if he loses these qualities, because the subject , Socrates, remains the same. 
 - HoP 1

And so it is with all else. 
 - HoP 1

For there must be one nature, or more than one, from which all else arises, because it maintains its existence  , that means that in its change there is no reality or truth. 
 - HoP 1

All do not coincide as to the number of this principle or as to its description ; Thales, the founder of this philosophy,  , says that it is water. 
 - HoP 1

Hence he likewise asserts the earth to be founded on water. 
 - HoP 1

We might first of all expect some explanation of the application of these principles, as, for example, how it is to be proved that water is the universal substance, and in what way particular forms are deduced from it. 
 - HoP 1

But as to this we must say that of Thales in particular, we know nothing more than his principle, which is that water is the god over all. 
 - HoP 1

No more do we know anything further of Anaximander, Anaximenes and Diogenes than their principles. 
 - HoP 1

But that from which anything generates is the principle of all things. 
 - HoP 1

This was one reason for holding this theory, and another reason is contained in the fact that all germs are moist in character, and water is the principle of what is moist. 
 - HoP 1

And furthermore, they can hardly be called grounds, for what Aristotle does is rather to establish, as we would say from actuality, that the latter corresponds to the universal idea of water. 
 - HoP 1

His successors, as for instance Pseudo-Plutarch , have taken Thales assertion as positive and not hypothetical; Tiedmann  remarks with great reason that Plutarch omits the perhaps. 
 - HoP 1

Aristotle is contented with simply showing in regard to moisture that, at least, it is everywhere to be found. 
 - HoP 1

If, with plants, water may be regarded as for their nourishment, nourishment is still only the being of a thing as formless substance that first becomes individualized by individuality, and thus succeeds in obtaining form. 
 - HoP 1

To make sun, moon and the whole world arise through evaporation, like the food of plants, certainly approximates to the idea of the ancients, who did not allow the sun and moon to have obtained independence as we do. 
 - HoP 1

There are also some,  continues Aristotle, who hold that all the ancients who, at the first and long before the present generation, made theology their study, understood Nature thus. 
 - HoP 1

They made Oceanus and Tethys the producers of all origination , and water, which by the poets is called Styx, the oath of the gods. 
 - HoP 1

For what is most ancient is most revered, and the oath is that most held in reverence. 
 - HoP 1

This old tradition has within it speculative significance. 
 - HoP 1

The closer consideration of this principle in its bearings would have no interest. 
 - HoP 1

For since the whole philosophy of Thales lies in the fact that water is this principle, the only point of interest can be to ask how far that principle is important and speculative. 
 - HoP 1

For no evil fate has led thee into this path,      But Themis and Dice.

For there lacks but desire on your way.

To human ideas, now this is held to be reality and now its opposite, and then again a mixture of both.

Thus origination has disappeared, and decease is incredible.

Thought, and that on account of which thought is, are the same.

That is the main point. 
 - HoP 1

In Simplicius  we have further metaphorical images from Parmenides. 
 - HoP 1

Since the utmost limit of Being is perfect, it resembles on every side the form of a well rounded sphere, which from its centre extends in all directions equally, for it can be neither larger or smaller in one part or another.

There is no non-being which prevents it from attaining to the like -from coming into unity with itself-and there is no Being where it was devoid of Being, here more and there less.

Because the all is without defect, it is in all places in the same way like itself in its determinations.

And Simplicius says: We must not wonder at him, for on account of the poetic form, he adopts a mythological fiction.

 - HoP 1

By the former, warmth, softness, lightness is expressed, and by the latter, cold. 
 - HoP 1

But since everything is called light and night, and their qualities are suited both to the one kind of things and the other, everything alike is filled with light and dark night; both are alike since nothing exists without both.

In regard to his philosophy, too, there is little to say.

Aristotle, where he mentions him, places him always with Parmenides, as resembling him in mode of thought.

Since the beginning, in which we are told whose reasoning it is, is wanting, conjecture only applies it to Xenophanes.

The writing begins with the words He says,  without any name being given.

Indeed, there is in this work  an opinion of Xenophanes mentioned in such a way that it appears as though had what was previously quoted by Aristotle been by him ascribed to Xenophanes, the expression would have been different.

We find it said:-  If anything is, it is eternal.

 - HoP 1

It is impossible that anything should arise from the nothing.

If everything could have arisen, or could it merely not have been everything eternally, it would equally have arisen out of nothing.

For, if everything had arisen, nothing would once have existed. 
 - HoP 1

If some were alone the existent out of which the rest sprang, the one would be more and greater.

But the more and greater would thus have arisen out of the nothing of itself, for in the less there is not its more, nor in the smaller its greater.

Simplicius makes this note to the Physics of Aristotle : No more can anything arise out of the existent, for the existent already is, and thus does not first arise from the existent.

The infinite all is one, for, if there were two or more, they would limit one another,  and thus have a beginning and end.

The one would be the nothing of the other and come forth from this nothing.

This one is like itself; for if it were unlike it would no longer be the one that was posited, but many.

This one is likewise immovable, inasmuch as it does not move itself, since it does not pass out into anything.

In passing out, it would require to do so into what is full or what is empty; it could not be into the full, for that is an impossibility, and just as little could it be into what is empty, for that is the nothing.

The one, therefore, is in this way devoid of pain or suffering, not changing in position or form, or mingling with what is different.

For all these determinations involve the origination of non-being and passing away of Being, which is impossible.

Thus here again the contradiction which takes place when origination and passing away are spoken of, is revealed.

Now Melissus places opinion in opposition to this truth. 
 - HoP 1

In sensuous perception the opposite is present for us; that is to say, a number of things, their change, their origination and passing away, and their intermingling.

Thus that first knowledge must take its place beside this second, which has as much certainty for ordinary consciousness as the first. 
 - HoP 1

This is what Aristotle says of him. 
 - HoP 1

But when Parmenides speaks of limit, we see that his poetic language is not altogether exact; limit, however, as pure limit, is just simple Being and absolute negativity, in which all else said and set forth is sublated.

Necessity, as this pure negativity and movement within itself, although impassive thought, is absolutely bound to its opposite.

In the third place it may be said that Parmenides set forth a concomitant philosophy of opinion or reality, to which Being as existence for thought was thus more opposed than was the case with Melissus.

That is to say, in the Eleatics hitherto considered, we only have the proposition: The nothing has no reality and is not at all, and thus what is called origin and decease disappears.

Parmenides asserts that The all is immutable, for, in change, the non-being of that which is would be asserted, but Being only is; in saying that non-being is, the subject and the predicate contradict themselves.

Zeno, on the other hand, says: Assert your change; in it as change there is the negation to it, or it is nothing.

To the former change existed as motion, definite and complete. 
 - HoP 1

Zeno protested against motion as such, or pure motion. 
 - HoP 1

Pure Being is not motion; it is rather the negation of motion. 
 - HoP 1

Zeno anticipated this, and because he foresaw that Being is the opposite of nothing, he denied of the One what must be said of the nothing. 
 - HoP 1

But the same thing must occur with all the rest.

We find this higher dialectic in Platos Parmenides; here it only breaks forth in respect to some determinations, and not to the determination of the One and of Being.

According to Diogenes Laertius,  Zeno was likewise an Eleat; he is the youngest, and lived most in company with Parmenides. 
 - HoP 1

The latter became very fond of him and adopted him as a son; his own father was called Telentagoras. 
 - HoP 1

Not in his State alone was his conduct held in high respect, for his fame was universal, and he was esteemed particularly as a teacher. 
 - HoP 1

Plato mentions that men came to him from Athens and other places, in order to profit from his learning. 
 - HoP 1

Proud self-sufficiency is ascribed to him by Diogenes  because he-with the exception of a journey made to Athens-continued to reside in Elea, and did not stay a longer time in the great, mighty Athens, and there attain to fame.

In very various narratives his death was made for ever celebrated for the strength of his mind evinced in it; it was said that he freed a State  from its Tyrant  in the following way, and by the sacrifice of his life.

He entered into a plot to overthrow the Tyrant, but this was betrayed. 
 - HoP 1

The powerful remonstrances or the horrible tortures and death of Zeno aroused the citizens, inspired them with courage to fall upon the Tyrant, kill him, and liberate themselves. 
 - HoP 1

The manner of the end, and his violent and furious state of mind, is very variously depicted. 
 - HoP 1

He is said to have pretended to wish to say something into the Tyrants ear, and then to have bitten his ear, and thus held him fast until he was slain by the others. 
 - HoP 1

It has just been noticed that Zeno had the very important character of being the originator of the true objective dialectic. 
 - HoP 1

Xenophanes, Parmenides, and Melissus, start with the proposition: Nothing is nothing; the nothing does not exist at all, or the like is real existence,  that is, they make one of the opposed predicates to be existence. 
 - HoP 1

We have proceeded from a definite proposition; the nullity of the opposite does not appear in itself; it is not that it abrogates itself, ie that it contains a contradiction in itself. 
 - HoP 1

For instance, I assert of something that it is the null; then I show this by hypothesis in motion, and it follows that it is the null. 
 - HoP 1

But another consciousness does not assert this; I declare one thing to be directly true; another has the right of asserting something else as directly true, that is to say, motion. 
 - HoP 1

Similarly what seems to be the case when one philosophic system contradicts another, is that the first is pre-established, and that men starting from this point of view, combat the other. 
 - HoP 1

The matter is thus easily settled by saying: The other has no truth, because it does not agree with me,  and the other has the right to say the same. 
 - HoP 1

It does not help if I prove my system or my proposition and then conclude that thus the opposite is false; to this other proposition the first always seems to be foreign and external. 
 - HoP 1

Falsity must not be demonstrated through another, and as untrue because the opposite is true, but in itself; we find this rational perception in Zeno. 
 - HoP 1

Parmenides thus shows in his poems that All is One; Zeno, on the contrary, shows that the Many cannot be.

That is the special aim of objective dialectic, in which we no longer maintain simple thought for itself, but see the battle fought with new vigour within the enemys camp. 
 - HoP 1

Dialectic has in Zeno this negative side, but it has also to be considered from its positive side. 
 - HoP 1

According to the ordinary ideas of science, where propositions result from proof, proof is the movement of intelligence, a connection brought about by mediation. 
 - HoP 1

In regarding it thus, it shows from itself that it contains opposed determinations, and thus breaks up; this dialectic we more especially find in the ancients.

The subjective dialectic, which reasons from external grounds, is moderate, for it grants that: In the right there is what is not right, and in the false the true.

True dialectic leaves nothing whatever to its object, as if the latter were deficient on one side only; for it disintegrates itself in the entirety of its nature.

The result of this dialectic is null, the negative; the affirmative in it does not yet appear. 
 - HoP 1

This true dialectic may be associated with the work of the Eleatics. 
 - HoP 1

But in their case the real meaning and quality of philosophic understanding was not great, for they got no further than the fact that through contradiction the object is a nothing.

Zenos dialectic of matter has not been refuted to the present day; even now we have not got beyond it, and the matter is left in uncertainty. 
 - HoP 1

Simplicius, writing on the Physics of Aristotle , says: Zeno proves that if the many is, it must be great and small; if great, the many must be infinite in number. 
 - HoP 1

If small, it must be so small as to have no size,  like atoms. 
 - HoP 1

Here he shows that what has neither size, thickness nor mass, cannot be. 
 - HoP 1

For if it were added to another, it would not cause its increase; were it, that is to say, to have no size and be added thereto, it could not supplement the size of the other and consequently that which is added is nothing.

Similarly were it taken away, the other would not be made less, and thus it is nothing. 
 - HoP 1

But it is the same thing to say something once and to say it over and over again; in it nothing can be a last, nor will there not be another to the other. 
 - HoP 1

Thus if many are, they are small and great; small, so that they have no size; great, so that they are infinite. 
 - HoP 1

Aristotle  explains this dialectic further; Zenos treatment of motion was above all objectively dialectical. 
 - HoP 1

But the particulars which we find in the Parmenides of Plato are not his. 
 - HoP 1

For Zenos consciousness we see simple unmoved thought disappear, but become thinking movement; in that he combats sensuous movement, he concedes it. 
 - HoP 1

The reason that dialectic first fell on movement is that the dialectic is itself this movement, or movement itself the dialectic of all that is. 
 - HoP 1

The thing, as self-moving, has its dialectic in itself, and movement is the becoming another, self-abrogation.

If Aristotle says that Zeno denied movement because it contains an inner contradiction, it is not to be understood to mean that movement did not exist at all. 
 - HoP 1

The point is not that there is movement and that this phenomenon exists; the fact that there is movement is as sensuously certain as that there are elephants; it is not in this sense that Zeno meant to deny movement.

The point in question concerns its truth. 
 - HoP 1

Movement, however, is held to be untrue, because the conception of it involves a contradiction; by that he meant to say that no true Being can be predicated of it.

Zeno now brings forward four different arguments against motion; the proofs rest on the infinite divisibility of space and time. 
 - HoP 1

This is his first form of argument:-Movement has no truth, because what is in motion must first reach the middle of the space before arriving at the end. 
 - HoP 1

Aristotle expresses this thus shortly, because he had earlier treated of and worked out the subject at length. 
 - HoP 1

This is to be taken as indicating generally that the continuity of space is presupposed. 
 - HoP 1

What moves itself must reach a certain end, this way is a whole. 
 - HoP 1

Zeno here arrives at the infinite divisibility of space; because space and time are absolutely continuous, there is no point at which the division can stop. 
 - HoP 1

Every dimension  is again divisible into two halves, which must be measured off; and however small a space we have, the same conditions reappear. 
 - HoP 1

Movement would be the act of passing through these infinite moments, and would therefore never end; thus what is in motion cannot reach its end. 
 - HoP 1

It is known how Diogenes of Sinope, the Cynic, quite simply refuted these arguments against movement; without speaking he rose and walked about, contradicting them by action.

But when reasons are disputed, the only valid refutation is one derived from reasons; men have not merely to satisfy themselves by sensuous assurance, but also to understand.

Movement, this pure phenomenon, appears as something thought and shown forth in its real being-that is, in its distinction of pure self-identity and pure negativity, the point as distinguished from continuity.

To us there is no contradiction in the idea that the here of space and the now of time are considered as a continuity and length; but their Notion is self-contradictory. 
 - HoP 1

Movement is just the reality of time and space, and because this appears and is made manifest, the apparent contradiction is demonstrated, and it is this contradiction that Zeno notices.

In that we say into infinity,  we place before ourselves a beyond, outside of the ordinary conception, which cannot reach so far.

It is certainly an endless going forth, but in the Notion it is present, it is a progression from one opposed determination to others, from continuity to negativity, from negativity to continuity; but both of these are before us.

Of these moments one in the process may be called the true one; Zeno first asserts continuous progression in such a way that no limited space can be arrived at as ultimate, or Zeno upholds progression in this limitation.

The general explanation which Aristotle gives to this contradiction, is that space and time are not infinitely divided, but are only divisible. 
 - HoP 1

But it now appears that, because they are divisible-that is, in potentiality-they must actually be infinitely divided, for else they could not be divided into infinity.

That is the general answer of the ordinary man in endeavouring to refute the explanation of Aristotle.

Bayle  hence says of Aristotles answer that it is pitoyable: Cest se moquer du monde que de se servir de cette doctrine; car si la matiÃ¨re est divisible Ã  linfini, elle contient un nombre infini de parties.

Ce nest donc point un infini en puissance, cest un infini, qui existe rÃ©ellement, actuellement.

Mais quand-mÃªme on accorderait cet infini en puissance, qui deviendrait un infini par la division actuelle de ses parties, on ne perdrait pas ses avantages; car le mouvement est une chose, qui a la mÃªme vertu, que la division.

Il touche une partie de lespace sans toucher lautre, et il les touche toutes les unes aprÃ¨s les autres.

This si is good! Divisibility is, as potentiality, the universal; there is continuity as well as negativity or the point posited in it-but posited as moment, and not as existent in and for itself.

I can divide matter into infinitude, but I only can do so; I do not really divide it into infinitude.

This is the infinite, that no one of its moments has reality. 
 - HoP 1

It never does happen that, in itself, one or other-that absolute limitation or absolute continuity-actually comes into existence in such a way that the other moment disappears. 
 - HoP 1

There are two absolute opposites, but they are moments, ie in the simple Notion or in the universal, in thought, if you will; for in thought, in ordinary conception, what is set forth both is and is not at the same time.

What is represented either as such, or as an image of the conception, is not a thing; it has no Being, and yet it is not nothing. 
 - HoP 1

Space and time furthermore, as quantum, form a limited extension, and thus can be measured off; just as I do not actually divide space, neither does the body which is in motion. 
 - HoP 1

The partition of space as divided, is not absolute discontinuity PunktualitÃ¤t, nor is pure continuity the undivided and indivisible; likewise time is not pure negativity or discontinuity, but also continuity. 
 - HoP 1

Both are manifested in motion, in which the Notions have their reality for ordinary conception-pure negativity as time, continuity as space. 
 - HoP 1

Motion itself is just this actual unity in the opposition, and the sequence of both moments in this unity. 
 - HoP 1

To comprehend motion is to express its essence in the form of Notion, ie, as unity of negativity and continuity; but in them neither continuity nor discreteness can be exhibited as the true existence. 
 - HoP 1

But both these moments make their appearance as existent; if they are manifested indifferently, their Notion is no longer posited, but their existence. 
 - HoP 1

In them as existent, negativity is a limited size, and they exist as limited space and time; actual motion is progression through a limited space and a limited time and not through infinite space and infinite time. 
 - HoP 1

That what is in motion must reach the half is the assertion of continuity, ie the possibility of division as mere possibility; it is thus always possible in every space, however small. 
 - HoP 1

It is said that it is plain that the half must be reached, but in so saying, everything is allowed, including the fact that it never will be reached; for to say so in one case, is the same as saying it an infinite number of times. 
 - HoP 1

We mean, on the contrary, that in a larger space the half can be allowed, but we conceive that we must somewhere attain to a space so small that no halving is possible, or an indivisible, non-continuous space which is no space. 
 - HoP 1

This, however, is false, for continuity is a necessary determination; there is undoubtedly a smallest in space, ie a negation of continuity, but the negation is something quite abstract. 
 - HoP 1

Abstract adherence to the subdivision indicated, that is, to continuous bisection into infinitude, is likewise false, for in the conception of a half, the interruption of continuity is involved. 
 - HoP 1

We must say that there is no half of space, for space is continuous; a piece of wood may be broken into two halves, but not space, and space only exists in movement. 
 - HoP 1

It might equally be said that space consists of an endless number of points, ie of infinitely many limits and thus cannot be traversed. 
 - HoP 1

Men think themselves able to go from one indivisible point to another, but they do not thereby get any further, for of these there is an unlimited number.

Continuity is split up into its opposite, a number which is indefinite; that is to say, if continuity is not admitted, there is no motion. 
 - HoP 1

It is false to assert that it is possible when one is reached, or that which is not continuous; for motion is connection.

Thus when it was said that continuity is the presupposed possibility of infinite division, continuity is only the hypothesis; but what is exhibited in this continuity is the being of infinitely many, abstractly absolute limits.
