The second proof, which is also the presupposition of continuity and the manifestation of division, is called Achilles, the Swift. 
 - HoP 1

The ancients loved to clothe difficulties in sensuous representations. 
 - HoP 1

Of two bodies moving in one direction, one of which is in front and the other following at a fixed distance and moving quicker than the first, we know that the second will overtake the first. 
 - HoP 1

But Zeno says, The slower can never be overtaken by the quicker. 
 - HoP 1

And he proves it thus: The second one requires a certain space of time to reach the place from which the one pursued started at the beginning of the given period. 
 - HoP 1

Thus during the time in which the second reached the point where the first was, the latter went over a new space which the second has again to pass through in a part of this period; and in this way it goes into infinity. 
 - HoP 1

While B, in the next half hour, goes over the distance crossed by A of one mile , A has got half a mile  further, and so on into infinity. 
 - HoP 1

Aristotle, in speaking of this, puts it shortly thus. 
 - HoP 1

This proof asserts the same endless divisibility, but it is untrue, for the quick will overtake the slow body if the limits to be traversed be granted to it.

It has, however, this meaning, that what free thought is to attain must come out of itself and be personal conviction; it is then no longer believed but investigated-in short, it is the so-called enlightenment of modern times. 
 - HoP 1

Thought seeks general principles by which it criticizes everything which is by us esteemed, and nothing has value to us which is not in conformity with these principles. 
 - HoP 1

These aspects, which are properly not independent, but only moments of a whole, when detached from it, relate themselves to themselves, and in this way assume the form of universality. 
 - HoP 1

Any one of them can thus be elevated to a reason, ie to a universal determination, which is again applied to particular aspects. 
 - HoP 1

A man of culture thus knows how to say something of everything, to find points of view in all. 
 - HoP 1

Greece has to thank the Sophists for this culture, because they taught men to exercise thought as to what should have authority for them, and thus their culture was culture in philosophy as much as in eloquence. 
 - HoP 1

In order to reach this double end, the Sophists were one in their desire to be wise. 
 - HoP 1

To know what constitutes power amongst men and in the State, and what I have to recognize as such, is counted as wisdom; and because I know the power, I also know how to direct others in conformity with my end. 
 - HoP 1

Hence the admiration that Pericles and other statesmen excited, just because they knew their own standpoint, and had the power of putting others in their proper place. 
 - HoP 1

That man is powerful who can deduce the actions of men from the absolute ends which move them. 
 - HoP 1

Learned in the proper sense they hence were not, because there were as yet no positive sciences without Philosophy, such as in their aridity did not concern all mankind and mans essential aspects. 
 - HoP 1

They further had the most ordinary practical end, to give a consciousness of that which is involved in the moral world and which satisfies man. 
 - HoP 1

Religion taught that the gods are the powers which rule over men. 
 - HoP 1

Immediate morality recognized the rule of laws; man was to find satisfaction in conforming to laws, and was to assume that others also find satisfaction because they follow these laws. 
 - HoP 1

Thus the impulses and desires that man has, become his power; and only inasmuch as he affords them satisfaction does he become satisfied. 
 - HoP 1

Now the Sophists taught how these powers could be moved in empirical man, for the good as ordinarily recognized, no longer determined them. 
 - HoP 1

Rhetoric, however, teaches how circumstances may be made subject to such forces; it even makes use of the wrath and passions of the hearer in order to bring about a conclusion. 
 - HoP 1

This is the position taken up by the Sophists. 
 - HoP 1

But we find a perfectly definite picture of their further progress and procedure in Platos Protagoras. 
 - HoP 1

Plato here makes Protagoras express himself more precisely respecting the art of the Sophists. 
 - HoP 1

On the way, Socrates now asks Hippocrates what is this wisdom of the Sophists which he wishes to learn. 
 - HoP 1

Hippocrates at first replies Rhetoric, for the Sophist is one who knows how to make men clever  in speech. 
 - HoP 1

In fact, what is most striking in a man or people of culture is the art of speaking well, or of turning subjects round and considering them in many aspects. 
 - HoP 1

The uncultivated man finds it unpleasant to associate with people who know how to grasp and express every point of view with ease. 
 - HoP 1

 - HoP 1

Protagoras praises his discretion, and replies that they act wisely to make use of this precaution.

One section, like Homer and Hesiod, taught it in their poetry; others, like Orpheus and MusÃ¦us, through mysteries and oracles.

Some, I believe, like Iccus of Tarentum, and the Sophist now living and unsurpassed-Herodicus, of Selymbria-in gymnastics, but many more through music.

We see that Protagoras usually describes the end of mental culture as being to bring about morality, presence of mind, sense of order and general capacity. 
 - HoP 1

He adds: all those who feared envy arising against the sciences, required such veils and screens.

But I think that they do not attain their end, for men of penetration in the State see the end appearing through, while the people notice nothing, and only quote the others.

If people behave so, they make themselves more hated, and appear to be impostors. 
 - HoP 1

 - HoP 1

Hippocrates will not have the same experience that he would have with other teachers. 
 - HoP 1

These latter are at variance with  their pupils, for they take them against their wills straight back to the arts and sciences which they just wished to escape, inasmuch as they teach them arithmetic, geometry and music. 
 - HoP 1

Thus the youths came freely, with the wish to be made men of culture through his instruction, and in the hope that he, as teacher, knew the way to succeed in so doing.

Thus two interests are here apparent, that of the individual and that of the State.

Those who are masters of the art of politics cannot impart that art to others.

Similarly other great statesmen did not teach it to others, whether friends or strangers.

Impiety and injustice are of this description and, generally speaking, all that opposes public virtue.

Thus it is in this implied that virtue can be acquired through education and exercise.

In it no particular education from men of eminence is thus required. 
 - HoP 1

The children are from their earliest infancy exhorted and admonished to do what is good, and are accustomed to that which is right. 
 - HoP 1

Instruction in music and gymnastics contributes to temper the indulgence of self-will and pleasure, and to accustom men to conform to a law or rule; and the reading of the poets who enforce this does the same. 
 - HoP 1

But it might very well be the case that the son of an artist should be a bad player, for the distinction depends on particular talents, and a particularly good natural capacity.

This, the necessary course of free, thinking reflection, which with us has also been adopted by culture, must, however, necessarily lead beyond implicit trust and unrestricted faith in the current morality and religion.

Thus here there is a groundwork of a fixed spiritual principle which thus satisfies the needs of the subjective mind; and from this absolute principle all further relationships, duties, laws, &c, are established.

As to their outward lives, we know that the Sophists accumulated great riches;92 they became very proud, and some of them lived very luxuriously.

Socrates and Plato wished to bring forward this Notion as opposed to the consideration of things from points of view and reasonings which are always merely particular and individual, and thus opposed to the Notion itself. 
 - HoP 1

And just as utterances of the Sophists are adduced against which nothing can be said , men of our day are urged to all that is good for the very reasons that are reasons to the Sophists.

Thus it is said, do not cheat, else you lose your credit, hence your wealth,  or, be temperate, or you will spoil your appetite and have to suffer.

 - HoP 1

If duties and virtues are advocated as in sermons , we must hear such reasons given. 
 - HoP 1

Other speakers, such as those in parliament, likewise make use of arguments and counterarguments similar to these, through which they try to persuade and convince. 
 - HoP 1

Men likewise make use of good arguments, after the manner of the Sophists, against Philosophy. 
 - HoP 1

There are, they say, various philosophies, various opinions, and this is contrary to the one Truth; the weakness of human reason allows of no knowledge. 
 - HoP 1

What is Philosophy to the feelings, mind, and heart? Abstract thinking about such matters produces abstruse results which are of no use in the practical life of man. 
 - HoP 1

We no longer apply the word sophistry thus, but it is the way of the Sophists not to take things as they are, but to bring about their proofs by arguments derived from feelings as ultimate ends. 
 - HoP 1

We shall see this characteristic of the Sophists more clearly still in Socrates and Plato. 
 - HoP 1

Thus what has been considered the sin of the Sophists is that they taught men to deduce any conclusion required by others or by themselves; but that is not due to any special quality in the Sophists, but to reflective reasoning. 
 - HoP 1

In the worst action there exists a point of view which is essentially real; if this is brought to the front, men excuse and vindicate the action. 
 - HoP 1

In the crime of desertion in time of war, there is, for example, the duty of self-preservation. 
 - HoP 1

The educated man knows how to regard everything from the point of view of the good, to maintain in everything a real point of view. 
 - HoP 1

A man does not require to make great progress in his education to have good reasons ready for the worst action; all that has happened in the world since the time of Adam has been justified by some good reason. 
 - HoP 1

It appears that the Sophists were conscious of this reasoning, and knew, as educated men, that everything could be proved. 
 - HoP 1

Hence in Platos Gorgias it is said that the art of the Sophists is a greater gift than any other; they could convince the people, the senate, the judges, of what they liked.

The Sophists thus knew that on this basis nothing was secure, because the power of thought treated everything dialectically. 
 - HoP 1

Once it was highest and ultimate, then it was deposed.

 - HoP 1

This is either the good, the universal, or the individuality, the arbitrary will of the subject; and both may be united, as is shown later on in Socrates.

Here the danger lies. 
 - HoP 1

The real end of the State, the best administration and constitution, is likewise to demagogues very vague. 
 - HoP 1

On account of their formal culture, the Sophists have a place in Philosophy; on account of their reflection they have not. 
 - HoP 1

They are associated with Philosophy in that they do not remain at concrete reasoning, but go on, at least in part, to ultimate determinations. 
 - HoP 1

A chief part of their culture was the generalization of the Eleatic mode of thought and its extension to the whole content of knowledge and of action; the positive thus comes in as, and has become, utility. 
 - HoP 1

To go into particulars respecting the Sophists would lead us too far; individual Sophists have their place in the general history of culture. 
 - HoP 1

Protagoras, born at Abdera,97 was somewhat older than Socrates; little more is known of him, nor, indeed, could there be much known. 
 - HoP 1

For he led a uniform life, since he spent it in the study of the sciences; he appeared in Greece proper as the first public teacher. 
 - HoP 1

He read his writings98 like the rhapsodists and poets, the former of whom sang the verses of others, and the latter their own. 
 - HoP 1

The Sophists now gave, in place of a knowledge of the poets, an acquaintanceship with thought. 
 - HoP 1

Protagoras also came to Athens and there lived for long, principally with the great Pericles, who also entered into this culture. 
 - HoP 1

Indeed, the two once argued for a whole day as to whether the dart or the thrower or he who arranged the contest was guilty of the death of a man who thus met his death. 
 - HoP 1

Pericles was a powerful orator, and we see from Thucydides how deep a knowledge he had of the State and of his people. 
 - HoP 1

Protagoras had the same fate as Anaxagoras, in being afterwards banished from Athens. 
 - HoP 1

This book was also publicly burned in Athens by command of the State, and, so far as we know, it was the first to be treated so. 
 - HoP 1

At the age of seventy or ninety years Protagoras was drowned while on a voyage to Sicily. 
 - HoP 1

The main point in his system of knowledge he expressed thus: Man is the measure of all things; of that which is, that it is; of that which is not, that it is not. 
 - HoP 1

If the statement is taken in the former sense, all is self-seeking, all self-interest, the subject with his interests forms the central point; and if man has a rational side, reason is still something subjective, it is he. 
 - HoP 1

The same statement is brought forward in Socrates and Plato, but with the further modification that here man, in that he is thinking and gives himself a universal content, is the measure. 
 - HoP 1

Thus here the great proposition is enunciated on which, from this time forward, everything turns, since the further progress of Philosophy only explains it further: it signifies that reason is the end of all things. 
 - HoP 1

Since man, as subject, is the measure of everything, the existent is not alone, but is for my knowledge. 
 - HoP 1

Consciousness is really the producer of the content in what is objective, and subjective thinking is thus really active. 
 - HoP 1

God, the Platonic Good, is certainly at first a product of thought, but in the second place He is just as really in and for Himself. 
 - HoP 1

Since I, as existent, fixed and eternal, only recognize what is in its content universal, this, posited as it is by me, is likewise the implicitly objective, not posited by me. 
 - HoP 1

Protagoras himself shows us much more of what is implied in his theory, for he says, Truth is a manifestation for consciousness. 
 - HoP 1

Nothing is in and for itself one, but everything has a relative truth only,  ie it is what it is but for another, which is man. 
 - HoP 1

This relativity is by Protagoras expressed in a way which seems to us in some measure trivial, and belongs to the first beginnings of reflective thought. 
 - HoP 1

The insignificant examples which he adduces , by way of explanation, show that in Protagoras understanding what is determined is not grasped as the universal and identical with self. 
 - HoP 1

Hence the exemplifications are taken mostly from sensuous manifestation. 
 - HoP 1

In a wind it may be that one person is cold and another is not; hence of this wind we cannot tell whether in itself it is cold or hot. 
 - HoP 1

Or again, if we have here six dice, and place by them four others, we should say of the former that there are more of them. 
 - HoP 1

But, again, if we put twelve by them we say that these first six are the fewer. 
 - HoP 1

Plato, on the contrary, considered one and many, not like the Sophists in their distinction, but as being one and the same.

Plato says further on this point, that the white, warm, &c, or everything that we say of things, does not exist for itself, but that the eye, sensation, is necessary to make it for us. 
 - HoP 1

This objective relativity is expressed better in the following way. 
 - HoP 1

If the white were in itself, it would be that which brought forth the sensation of it; it would be the action or the cause, and we, on the contrary, the passive and receptive. 
 - HoP 1

But the object which thus requires to be active, is not active until it enters into  relation with the passive; similarly the passive is only in relation to the active. 
 - HoP 1

Thus what is said in defining anything never concerns the thing as in itself, but clearly only as being related to something else. 
 - HoP 1

Nothing is thus constituted in and for itself as it appears, but the truth is just this phenomenon to which our activity contributes. 
 - HoP 1

As things appear to the healthy man they are thus not in themselves, but for him; as they appear to the sick or deranged man, they are to him, without our being able to say that as they appear to him, they are not true. 
 - HoP 1

The phenomenon is, according to him, nothing but the fact of there being outside an impulse, an unknown x, which first receives these determinations through our feeling. 
 - HoP 1

Even if there were an objective ground for our calling one thing cold and another warm, we could indeed say that they must have diversity in themselves, but warmth and cold first become what they are in our feeling.

We see that Protagoras possesses great powers of reflective thought, and indeed reflection on consciousness came to consciousness with Protagoras. 
 - HoP 1

But this is the form of manifestation which was again taken by the later sceptics. 
 - HoP 1

The phenomenal is not sensuous Being, for because I posit this as phenomenal, I assert its nullity.

But the statements What is, is only for consciousness,  or The truth of all things is the manifestation of them in and for consciousness,  seem quite to contradict themselves. 
 - HoP 1

For it appears as though a contradiction were asserted-first that nothing is in itself as it appears, and then that it is true as it appears. 
 - HoP 1

During the Peloponnesian war he was, in Ol.

 - HoP 1

He was strong in the dialectic requisite for eloquence, but his preeminence lies in his pure dialectic respecting the quite universal categories of Being and non-being, which indeed is not like that of the Sophists. 
 - HoP 1

Tiedemann  says very falsely: Gorgias went much further than any man of healthy mind could go. 
 - HoP 1

Tiedemann could say of every philosopher that he went further than healthy human understanding, for what men call healthy understanding is not Philosophy, and is often far from healthy. 
 - HoP 1

Healthy human understanding possesses the modes of thought, maxims, and judgments of its time, the thought-determinations of which dominate it without its being conscious thereof. 
 - HoP 1

In this way Gorgias undoubtedly went further than healthy understanding. 
 - HoP 1

Before Copernicus it would have been contrary to all healthy human understanding if anyone had said that the earth went round the sun, or before the discovery of America, if it were said that there was a continent there.

In India or in China a republic would even now be contrary to all healthy understanding.

The dialectic of Gorgias moves more purely in Notion than that found in Protagoras. 
 - HoP 1

Since Protagoras asserted the relativity, or the non-implicit nature of all that is, this only exists in relation to another which really is essential to it; and this last, indeed, is consciousness.

Gorgias treatise On Nature,  in which he composes his dialectic, falls, according to Sextus Empiricus , into three parts. 
 - HoP 1

In the first he proves that   nothing exists, in the second  , that assuming that Being is, it cannot be known; and in the third place  , that were it to exist and be knowable, no communication of what is known would be possible.

Gorgias was a congenial subject to Sextus, but the former still proved, and this is what the Sceptics ceased to do. 
 - HoP 1

If anything is,  -then if it is   it is either the existent or the non-existent, or else existence and non-existence. 
 - HoP 1

It is now evident of these three that they are not. 
 - HoP 1

That which is not, is not; for if Being belonged to it, there would at the same time be existence and non-existence.

That is, in so far as it is thought of as non-existent, it is not; but in so far as it is the non-existent, it must exist. 
 - HoP 1

But it cannot at the same time be and not be. 
 - HoP 1

Again, if the non-existent is, the existent is not, for the two are opposed. 
 - HoP 1

Thus, if Being pertained to non-being, non-being would belong to Being. 
 - HoP 1

But if Being does not exist, no more does non-being.

But in proving,  Aristotle adds to the passages just quoted, that the existent is not, he follows Melissus and Zeno.

This is the dialectic already brought forward by them. 
 - HoP 1

If Being is, it is contradictory to predicate a quality to it, and if we do this, we express something merely negative about it.

 - HoP 1

 - HoP 1

The infinite is nowhere, for if it is anywhere, that in which it is, is different from it. 
 - HoP 1

Where it is, it is in another, but that is not infinite which is different from another, and contained in another. 
 - HoP 1

Just as little is it contained in itself, for then that in which it is, and that which is therein, would be the same. 
 - HoP 1

What it is in, is the place; that which is in this, is the body; but that both should be the same is absurd. 
 - HoP 1

The infinite does not thus exist. 
 - HoP 1

In the same way Being has not originated, because it must then have come either from the existent or from the non-existent. 
 - HoP 1

From the existent it did not arise, for then it would be already; just as little from the non-existent, because this cannot beget anything. 
 - HoP 1

The sceptics followed this up further. 
 - HoP 1

The object to be contemplated hence ever becomes posited under determinations with either or, which then contradict one another. 
 - HoP 1

 - HoP 1

For as one, it would have a certain magnitude, or continuity, or number, or body, but all this is not one, but different, divisible. 
 - HoP 1

Every sensuous one is, in fact, necessarily another, a manifold. 
 - HoP 1

If it is not one, it cannot be many, for the many is many ones. 
 - HoP 1

Similarly both, Being and non-being, cannot exist at the same time. 
 - HoP 1

If one exists as much as the other, they are the same, and therefore neither of them is, for the non-being does not exist, and hence neither does the Being, since it is identical with it. 
 - HoP 1

Nor can they, on the other hand, both exist, for if they are identical, I cannot express them both, 114 and thus both do not exist, for if I express both, I differentiate. 
 - HoP 1

This dialectic, which Aristotle  likewise designates as peculiar to Gorgias, has its truth. 
 - HoP 1

In speaking of Being and non-being, we always say the opposite to what we wish. 
 - HoP 1

Being and non-being are the same, just as they are not the same; if they are the same, I speak of the two as different: if different, I express the same predicate of them, diversity. 
 - HoP 1

Gorgias is conscious that they are vanishing moments, while the ordinary unconscious conception also has present to it this truth, but knows nothing about it. 
 - HoP 1

The relation of the conceiver to conception, the difference between conception and Being, is a subject which is in our mouths to-day. 
 - HoP 1

But if there is an is, it is unknowable and unthinkable, for what is presented is not the existent  but only a presentation. 
 - HoP 1

If what is presented is white, it is the case that white is presented; if what is presented is not the really existent, it is the case that what is, is not presented.

 - HoP 1

Further, if what is presented is the existent, the non-existent is not presented, for opposites are in opposition. 
 - HoP 1

But this non-existent is everywhere presented as it is in Scylla and the ChimÃ¦ra. 
 - HoP 1

We finally have the basis of the dialectic of Gorgias in respect of the third point, that knowledge cannot be imparted, in this: If the existent were presented, it could still not be expressed and imparted. 
 - HoP 1
