Aristotle has further declared the chief subject of investigation, or the most essential knowledge  to be the knowledge of end; but this is the good in each thing and, generally speaking, the best in the whole of nature. 
 - HoP 2

This also holds good with Plato and Socrates; yet the end is the true, the concrete, as against the abstract Platonic Idea. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle then says of the value of Philosophy, Men have begun to philosophize through wonder,  for in it the knowledge of something higher is at least anticipated. 
 - HoP 2

Thus since man, to escape from ignorance, began to philosophize, it is clear that for the sake of knowledge he followed after knowledge, and not for any utility which it might possess for him. 
 - HoP 2

This is also made evident by the whole course of its external history. 
 - HoP 2

For it was after men had done with all their absolute requirements, and with what concerns their comfort, that they first began to seek this philosophic knowledge. 
 - HoP 2

We hence seek it not for the sake of any outside utility that it may have. 
 - HoP 2

And thus as we say that a free man is he who exists on his own account and not for another, Philosophy is the only science that is free, because it alone exists for itself-it is knowledge on account of knowledge. 
 - HoP 2

Therefore in justice it will not be held to be a human possession,  in the sense that, as we said above,  it is not in the possession of a man. 
 - HoP 2

But if the poets were right, and envy characterized divinity, all who would aim higher must be unfortunate;  Nemesis punishes whatever raises itself above the commonplace, and makes everything again equal. 
 - HoP 2

But the divine cannot be jealous,  ie cannot refuse to impart that which it is, as if this knowledge should not come to man  and-according to the proverb-the poets utter many falsehoods. 
 - HoP 2

Nor ought we to consider that any science is more entitled to honour than the one we now investigate, for that which is most divine, is also most worthy of honour. 
 - HoP 2

That is to say, what has and imparts what is best is honoured: the gods are thus to be honoured because they have this knowledge. 
 - HoP 2

God is held to be the cause and principle of everything, and therefore God has this science alone, or for the most part. 
 - HoP 2

But for this reason it is not unworthy of man to endeavour to seek the highest good which is in conformity with him, this knowledge pertaining to God. 
 - HoP 2

All other sciences are, however, more requisite than Philosophy, but none more excellent. 
 - HoP 2

It is difficult to give a more detailed account of the Aristotelian philosophy, the universal Idea with the more important elements, for Aristotle is much more difficult to comprehend than Plato. 
 - HoP 2

In the latter there are myths, and we can pass over the dialectic and yet say that we have read Plato; but with Aristotle we enter at once upon what is speculative. 
 - HoP 2

This has nothing dazzling about it, for he does not appear to have risen to the Idea , nor to have led back to it the individual. 
 - HoP 2

It is as if we said, there are plants, animals, men, and also God, the most excellent of all. 
 - HoP 2

From the whole list of conceptions which Aristotle enumerates, we shall now select some for further examination, and I will first speak of his metaphysics and its determinations. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotles speculative Idea is chiefly to be gathered from his Metaphysics, especially from the last chapters of the twelfth book  which deal with the divine Thought. 
 - HoP 2

But this treatise has the peculiar drawback noticed above  of being a compilation, several treatises having been combined into one. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle and the ancients did not know this work by the name of the Metaphysics; it was by them called ÏÏÏÏÎ· ÏÎ¹Î»Î¿ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¯Î±. 
 - HoP 2

The main portion of this treatise has a certain appearance of unity given to it by the connection of the argument,88 but it cannot be said that the style is orderly and lucid. 
 - HoP 2

This pure philosophy Aristotle very clearly distinguishes  from the other sciences as the science of that which is, in so far as it is, and of what belongs to it implicitly and explicitly. 
 - HoP 2

The main object which Aristotle has in view  is the definition of what this substance  really is. 
 - HoP 2

These are determinations which occur repeatedly in Aristotle, especially in the ninth book of the Metaphysics, and which we must be familiar with, if we would understand him. 
 - HoP 2

The expression Î´ÏÎ½Î±Î¼Î¹Ï is with Aristotle the beginning, the implicit, the objective; also the abstract universal in general, the Idea, the matter, which can take on all forms, without being itself the form-giving principle. 
 - HoP 2

But with an empty abstraction such as the thing-in-itself Aristotle has nothing to do. 
 - HoP 2

It is first in energy or, more concretely, in subjectivity, that he finds the actualizing form, the self-relating negativity. 
 - HoP 2

When, on the other hand, we speak of Being, activity is not yet posited: Being is only implicit, only potentiality, without infinite form. 
 - HoP 2

To Aristotle the main fact about Substance is that it is not matter merely ; although in ordinary life this is what is generally taken to be the substantial. 
 - HoP 2

With Aristotle Î´ÏÎ½Î±Î¼Î¹Ï does not therefore mean force , but rather capacity which is not even undetermined possibility; á¼Î½Î­ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î± is, on the other hand, pure, spontaneous activity. 
 - HoP 2

These definitions were of importance throughout all the middle ages. 
 - HoP 2

From this definition we now see clearly the sort of opposition in which the Idea of Aristotle stands to that of Plato, for although the Idea of Plato is in itself essentially concrete and determined, Aristotle goes further. 
 - HoP 2

In so far, namely, as the Idea is determined in itself, the relation of the moments in it can be more closely specified, and this relation of the moments to each other is to be conceived of as nothing other than activity. 
 - HoP 2

It is easy for us to have a consciousness of what is deficient in the universal, that is, of that which is implicit only. 
 - HoP 2

The universal, in that it is the universal, has as yet no reality, for because implicitude is inert, the activity of realization is not yet posited therein. 
 - HoP 2

Reason, laws, etc, are in this way abstract, but the rational, as realizing itself, we recognize to be necessary, and therefore we take such universal laws but little into account. 
 - HoP 2

Now the standpoint of Plato is in the universal; what he does is to express Being rather as the objective, the Good, the end, the universal. 
 - HoP 2

To this, however, the principle of living subjectivity, as the moment of reality, seems to be lacking, or it appears at least to be put in the background. 
 - HoP 2

But with Aristotle this negativity, this active efficacy, is expressly characterized as energy; in that it breaks up itself-this independence-abrogating unity, and positing separation; for, as Aristotle says , actuality separates. 
 - HoP 2

The Platonic Idea, on the other hand, is rather that abrogation of opposites, where one of the opposites is itself unity. 
 - HoP 2

The principle of individualization, not in the sense of a casual and merely particular subjectivity, but in that of pure subjectivity, is peculiar to Aristotle. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle thus also makes the Good, as the universal end, the substantial foundation, and maintains this position against Heraclitus and the Eleatics. 
 - HoP 2

The Becoming of Heraclitus is a true and real determination, but change yet lacks the determination of identity with itself, the constancy of the universal. 
 - HoP 2

The stream is ever changing, yet it is nevertheless ever the same, and is really a universal existence. 
 - HoP 2

As he maintains the universal against the principle of mere change, he puts forward activity in opposition to the numbers of the Pythagoreans, and to the Platonic Ideas. 
 - HoP 2

He says also that Ideas, as abstract universal determinations, are only as far as numbers go equal to things, but are not on that account to be pointed out as their causes. 
 - HoP 2

Moreover, he maintains that there are contradictions involved in taking independent species, since in Socrates, for instance, there are several ideas included: man, biped, animal. 
 - HoP 2

This is the chief point which Aristotle deals with. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle distinguishes various moments in substance, in so far as the moments of activity and potentiality do not appear as one, but still in separation. 
 - HoP 2

The closer determination of this relation of energy to potentiality, of form to matter, and the movement of this opposition, gives the different modes of substance. 
 - HoP 2

Here Aristotle enumerates the substances; and to him they appear as a series of different kinds of substance, which he merely takes into consideration one by one, without bringing them together into a system. 
 - HoP 2

The three following are the chief among these:-  a. 
 - HoP 2

The sensuous perceptible substance is that in which the matter is still distinguished from the efficient form. 
 - HoP 2

Hence this substance is finite; for the separation and externality of form and matter are precisely what constitute the nature of the finite. 
 - HoP 2

Now the leading categories of change which Aristotle names are the four differences, in regard to the What , or in regard to quality , or in regard to quantity , or in regard to place where. 
 - HoP 2

The first change is the origination and decay of simple determinate Being ; the second change is that of the further qualities ; the third, increase and diminution; the fourth, motion. 
 - HoP 2

Matter is the dead substance on which take place the changes which matter passes through. 
 - HoP 2

The change itself is from potential into actual existence; possible whiteness transforms itself into actual whiteness. 
 - HoP 2

Thus things do not arise casually out of nothing, but all arises out of what exists, though it exists only in potentiality, not in actuality. 
 - HoP 2

The possible is thus really a general implicit existence, which brings about these determinations, without producing one out of the other. 
 - HoP 2

Matter is thus simple potentiality, which, however, is placed in opposition to itself, so that a thing in its actuality only becomes that which its matter was also in potentiality. 
 - HoP 2

But activity is the unity of form and matter; how these two are in the other, Aristotle does not, however, further explain. 
 - HoP 2

A higher kind of substance, according to Aristotle , is that into which activity enters, which already contains that which is about to be. 
 - HoP 2

This is understanding, absolutely determined, whose content is the aim which it realizes through its activity, not merely changing as does the sensuous form. 
 - HoP 2

For the soul is essentially actuality, a general determination which posits itself; not only formal activity, whose content comes from somewhere else. 
 - HoP 2

But while the active posits its content in reality, this content yet remains the same; there is an activity present which is different from matter, although substance and activity are allied. 
 - HoP 2

Thus here we still have a matter which understanding demands as its hypothesis. 
 - HoP 2

In these two moments themselves change does not take place, for they are the implicit universal in opposed forms. 
 - HoP 2

For matter as such is passive and affected by change, consequently it is not simply one with the pure activity of this substance. 
 - HoP 2

Here as elsewhere we certainly see an instance of merely denying a predicate, without saying what its truth is; but matter is nothing else than that moment of unmoved Being. 
 - HoP 2

If in later times it has seemed something new to define absolute Being as pure activity, we see that this arises from ignorance as to the Aristotelian conception. 
 - HoP 2

But the Schoolmen rightly looked upon this as the definition of God, since they define God as actus purus; and higher idealism than this there is none. 
 - HoP 2

In this Aristotle breaks away from Plato, and for this reason controverts number, the Idea, and the universal, because if this, as inert, is not defined as identical with activity, there is no movement. 
 - HoP 2

Platos inert Ideas and numbers thus bring nothing into reality; but far different is the case with the Absolute of Aristotle, which in its quiescence is at the same time absolute activity. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle further says on this subject : It may be that what has potentiality is not real; it is of no avail therefore to make substances eternal, as the idealists do, if they do not contain a principle which can effect change. 
 - HoP 2

And even this is insufficient, if it is not active, because in that case there is no change. 
 - HoP 2

Yea, even if it were active, but its substance only a potentiality, there would be in it no eternal movement, for it is possible that what is according to potentiality may not exist. 
 - HoP 2

We must therefore have a principle whose substance must be apprehended as activity. 
 - HoP 2

Thus in mind energy is substance itself. 
 - HoP 2

But here a doubt seems to spring up. 
 - HoP 2

For all that is active seems to be possible, but all that is possible does not seem to energize, so that potentiality seems to be antecedent,  for it is the universal. 
 - HoP 2

But if this were the case, no one of the entities would be in existence, for it is possible that a thing may possess a capacity of existence, though it has never yet existed. 
 - HoP 2

But energy is higher than potentiality. 
 - HoP 2

We must thus not assert, as theologians would have us do, that in the eternal ages there was first chaos or night  , nor must we say with natural philosophers that everything existed simultaneously. 
 - HoP 2

For how could the First be changed, if nothing in reality were cause? For matter does not move itself, it is the Master who moves it. 
 - HoP 2

Leucippus and Plato accordingly say that motion has always existed, but they give no reason for the assertion. 
 - HoP 2

Pure activity is, according to Aristotle , before potentiality, not in relation to time, but to essence. 
 - HoP 2

In the former assumption of a chaos and so on, an activity is posited which has to do with something else, not with itself, and has therefore a pre-supposition; but chaos is only bare possibility. 
 - HoP 2

That which moves in itself, and therefore, as Aristotle continues , that which has circular motion;  is to be posited as the true Being, and this is evident not merely from thinking reason, but also from the fact itself. 
 - HoP 2

From the definition of absolute Being as imparting motion, as bringing about realization, there follows that it exists in objectivity in visible nature. 
 - HoP 2

As the self-identical which is visible, this absolute Being is the eternal heavens. 
 - HoP 2

The two modes of representing the Absolute are thus thinking reason and the eternal heavens. 
 - HoP 2

The heavens are moved, but they also cause movement. 
 - HoP 2

Since the spherical is thus both mover and moved, there is a centre-point which causes movement but remains unmoved, and which is itself at the same time eternal and a substance and energy. 
 - HoP 2

He explains this as follows: Its motion is determined in the following manner. 
 - HoP 2

That moves which is desired and thought, whereas itself it is unmoved, and the original of both is the same. 
 - HoP 2

That is the end whose content is the desire and thought; such an end is the Beautiful or the Good. 
 - HoP 2

For the thing that is desired is that which appears beautiful  : whose first  , on which the will is set, is what is beautiful. 
 - HoP 2

But it is rather the case that we desire it because it appears beautiful, than that it appears beautiful because we desire it. 
 - HoP 2

For if that were so, it would be simply posited by activity, but it is posited independently, as objective Being, through which our desire is first awakened. 
 - HoP 2

But thought is the true principle in this, for thought is moved only by the object of thought. 
 - HoP 2

Such are the Beautiful and the Good, and the first is ever the absolutely best or the best possible. 
 - HoP 2

But the Notion shows that the final cause belongs to the unmoved. 
 - HoP 2

What is moved may also subsist in a different manner. 
 - HoP 2

Motion  is the first change; the first motion, again, is circular motion, but this is due to the above cause. 
 - HoP 2

Therefore, according to Aristotle, the Notion, principium cognoscendi, is also that which causes movement, principium essendi; he expresses it as God, and shows the relation of God to the individual consciousness. 
 - HoP 2

The First Cause is necessary. 
 - HoP 2

On such a principle of the unmoved the heavens depend and the whole of nature -the visible that is eternal, and the visible that changes. 
 - HoP 2

This system is ever-enduring. 
 - HoP 2

But to us  as individuals, there is granted, for a short time only, a sojourn therein of surpassing excellence. 
 - HoP 2

For the system continues ever the same, but for us that is impossible. 
 - HoP 2

Now this activity is in its very self enjoyment, and therefore vigilance, exercise of the senses, thinking in general, are most productive of enjoyment; and for the same reason hopes and memories bring pleasure. 
 - HoP 2

But thinking, in its pure essence, is a thinking of that which is absolutely the most excellent;  the thought is for itself absolute end. 
 - HoP 2

The object of thought is first produced in the activity of thinking, which in this way separates the thought as an object. 
 - HoP 2

The chief moment in Aristotles philosophy is accordingly this, that the energy of thinking and the object of thought are the same; for thought is that which is receptive of objects of perception and the existent. 
 - HoP 2

It is not the object of thought that is the more excellent, but the very energy of thinking; the activity of apprehension brings that to pass which appears as something that is being apprehended. 
 - HoP 2

Speculation  is thus the most pleasing and the best. 
 - HoP 2

If then God has eternally subsisted in such surpassing excellence as for a limited time pertains to us  , He is worthy of admiration; if He possesses it in a more eminent degree, His nature is still more admirable. 
 - HoP 2

But this is His mode of subsistence. 
 - HoP 2

Life is also inherent in Him, for the activity of thought is life. 
 - HoP 2

But He constitutes this efficient power; essential energy belongs to God as His most excellent and eternal life. 
 - HoP 2

We therefore say that with God there is life perfect and everlasting. 
 - HoP 2

From this substance Aristotle moreover excludes magnitude. 
 - HoP 2

With Aristotle it is thus no dry identity of the abstract understanding that is indicated, for he distinguishes subjective and objective precisely and decisively. 
 - HoP 2

Not dead identity such as this, but energy, is for him what is most to be reverenced, God. 
 - HoP 2

If Aristotle had made the jejune identity of understanding, or experience, his principle, he would never have risen to a speculative Idea like this, wherein individuality and activity are placed higher than universal potentiality. 
 - HoP 2

He does not say that it alone is truth, that all is summed up in Thought, but he says it is the first, the strongest, the most honourable. 
 - HoP 2

Thus, although Aristotle does not express himself in modern philosophic language, he has yet throughout the same fundamental theory; he speaks not of a special kind of reason, but of the universal Reason. 
 - HoP 2

The speculative philosophy of Aristotle simply means the direction of thought on all kinds of objects, thus transforming these into thoughts; hence, in being thoughts, they exist in truth. 
 - HoP 2

But in Nature the Notion does not exist explicitly as thought in this freedom, but has flesh and blood, and is oppressed by externalities; yet this flesh and blood has a soul, and this is its Notion. 
 - HoP 2

It is only in thought that there is present a true harmony between objective and subjective; that constitutes me. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle therefore finds himself at the highest standpoint; nothing deeper can we desire to know, although he has always the appearance of making ordinary conceptions his starting-point. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle  now solves many other doubtful questions, for instance, whether thought is compound, and whether science is the object of science itself. 
 - HoP 2

Some further doubts arise as to thought , which seems to be of all things the most divine; but it is only with difficulty that we can conceive under what conditions  it is a thing of this sort. 
 - HoP 2

In this way it would not be the highest substance; for it is   thought  that gives it its high rank. 
 - HoP 2

In the next place, something else would be more excellent than thought, namely that which is thought ; and thinking and thought  will be present to the mind in understanding what is most inferior. 
 - HoP 2

As this is to be avoided , thinking would not constitute the best. 
 - HoP 2

Thought is therefore this, to think itself, because it is the most excellent; and it is the thinking, which is the thinking of thinking. 
 - HoP 2

For understanding and sensation and opinion and deliberation seem always to have an object other than themselves, and to be their own objects only in a secondary sense. 
 - HoP 2

Further, if thinking and being thought of are different, in relation to which of the two is the Good inherent in thought? For the Notion92 of thinking and that of the object of thought are not the same. 
 - HoP 2

As therefore thought and the object of thought are not different, these opposites, so far as they involve no connection with matter, are the same thing, and there is only a thought of the thing thought of. 
 - HoP 2

Reason which thinks itself, is the absolute end or the Good, for it only exists for its own sake. 
 - HoP 2

There still remains a doubt whether that which thinks is of composite nature or not; for it might undergo change in the parts of the whole. 
 - HoP 2

But the Good is not in this or that part, for it is the best in the universe, as distinguished from it. 
 - HoP 2

In this way the Thought which is its own object subsists to all eternity. 
 - HoP 2

As this speculative Idea, which is the best and most free, is also to be seen in nature, and not only in thinking reason, Aristotle  in this connection passes on to the visible God, which is the heavens. 
 - HoP 2

God, as living God, is the universe; and thus in the universe God, as living God, shows Himself forth. 
 - HoP 2

He comes forth as manifesting Himself or as causing motion, and it is in manifestation alone that the difference between the cause of motion and that which is moved comes to pass. 
 - HoP 2

The principle and the first cause of that which is, is itself unmoved, but brings to pass the original and eternal and single motion,  that is, the heaven of the fixed stars. 
 - HoP 2

We see that besides the simple revolution of the universe, which is brought about by the first unmoved substance, there are other eternal motions, those of the planets. 
 - HoP 2

We must not, however, enter into further details on this subject. 
 - HoP 2

For all are co-ordinated into one system just as in a house it is by no means permitted to the free inmates to do freely whatever they like, but all that they do, or the most of it, is done according to orderly arrangement. 
 - HoP 2

By slaves and animals, on the contrary, little is done for the general good, but they do much that is casual. 
 - HoP 2

For the principle of each is his own nature. 
 - HoP 2

In the same way it is necessary that all should attain to a position where distinction is drawn   but there are some things so constituted that all participate in them for the formation of a whole. 
 - HoP 2

Amongst the special sciences treated by Aristotle, the Physics is contained in a whole series of physical treatises, which form a tolerably complete system of what constitutes the Philosophy of Nature in its whole extent. 
 - HoP 2

We shall try to give their general plan. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotles first work is his Treatise, in eight books, on Physics, or on the Principles. 
 - HoP 2

In this he deals, as is fitting, with the doctrine of the Notion of nature generally, with movement, and with space and time. 
 - HoP 2

Then follow the treatises on Production and Destruction, the physical process of change, while formerly the ideal process of movement was considered. 
 - HoP 2

Then comes the Meteorology; it represents the universal physical process in its most real forms. 
 - HoP 2

Nothing is forgotten, and yet the presentation is, on the whole, empiric. 
 - HoP 2

From this point Aristotle proceeds to organic nature, and here his works not only contain a natural history, but also a physiology and anatomy. 
 - HoP 2

To the anatomy pertain his works on the Locomotion of Animals, and on the Parts of Animals. 
 - HoP 2

Finally, there comes the History of Animals, not merely as a history of Nature, but also as the history of the animal in its entirety-what we may call a kind of physiologico-anatomical anatomy. 
 - HoP 2

There is likewise a botanical work On Plants  which is ascribed to him. 
 - HoP 2

Thus we here find natural philosophy in the whole extent of its outward content. 
 - HoP 2

As regards this plan, there is no question that this is not the necessary order in which natural philosophy or physics must be treated. 
 - HoP 2

But in regard to the content they express no better the truth of things, but only the sensuous manifestation. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle and the ancients understand by physics, on the other hand, the comprehension of nature-the universal; and for this reason Aristotle also calls it the doctrine of principles. 
 - HoP 2

For in the manifestation of nature this distinction between the principle and what follows it, manifestation, really commences, and it is abrogated only in genuine speculation. 
 - HoP 2

Yet if, on the one hand, what is physical in Aristotle is mainly philosophic and not experimental, he yet proceeded in his Physics in what may be called an empiric way. 
 - HoP 2

One part is not universal enough to embrace the other part, for each is independent. 
 - HoP 2

In regard to the general conception of nature, we must say that Aristotle represents it in the highest and truest manner. 
 - HoP 2

For in the Idea of nature Aristotle  really relies on two determinations: the conception of end and the conception of necessity. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle at once grasps the whole matter in its principles, and this constitutes the old contradiction and divergence of view existing between necessity  and end , which we have inherited. 
 - HoP 2

The first mode of consideration is that in accordance with external necessity, which is the same as chance-the conception that all that pertains to nature is determined from without by means of natural causes. 
 - HoP 2

The other mode of consideration is the teleological, but conformity to end is either inward or outward, and in the more recent culture the latter has long retained the supremacy. 
 - HoP 2

Thus men vibrate in their opinion between these two points of view, seek external causes, and war against the form of an external teleology which places the end outside of nature. 
 - HoP 2

These determinations were known to Aristotle, and he thoroughly investigates them and considers what they are and mean. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotles conception of nature is, however, nobler than that of to-day, for with him the principal point is the determination of end as the inward determinateness of natural things. 
 - HoP 2

In this doctrine Aristotle has before his eyes the inward immanent end, to which he considers necessity an external condition. 
 - HoP 2

In nature we usually think of necessity first, and understand as the essentially natural that which is not determined through end. 
 - HoP 2

For long men thought that they determined nature both philosophically and truly in limiting it to necessity. 
 - HoP 2

But the aspect of nature has had a stigma removed from it, because, by means of its conformity to the end in view, it is elevated above the commonplace. 
 - HoP 2

The two moments which we have considered in substance, the active form and matter, correspond with these two determinations. 
 - HoP 2

We must first consider the conception of adaptation to end as the ideal moment in substance. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle begins  with the fact that the natural is the self-maintaining, all that is difficult is its comprehension. 
 - HoP 2

The vapour driven upwards cools, and the water resulting from this cooling falls as rain, and it happens that the corn is thereby made to grow. 
 - HoP 2

In like manner, if the corn of any one is destroyed, it does not rain for the sake of this destruction, but this is an accidental circumstance. 
 - HoP 2

That is to say, there is a necessary connection which, however, is an external relation, and this is the contingency of the cause as well as of the effect. 
 - HoP 2

Without going back to the fabulous monstrosities of the ancients, we likewise know of a number of animal tribes which have died out, just because they could not preserve the race. 
 - HoP 2

Thus we also require to use the expression development , in our present-day natural philosophy. 
 - HoP 2

The conception that the first productions were, so to speak, attempts, of which those which did not show themselves to be suitable could not endure, is easily arrived at by natural philosophy. 
 - HoP 2

But nature, as entelecheia or realization, is what brings forth itself. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle hence replies: It is impossible to believe this. 
 - HoP 2

For what is produced in accordance with nature is always, or at least for the most part, produced  , but this is not so with what happens through fortune or through chance. 
 - HoP 2

Leaves, blossoms, roots thus bring the plant into evidence and go back into it; and that which they bring to pass is already present in the seed from which they took their origin. 
 - HoP 2

But the self-maintaining activity of life really brings forth this unity in all relationships. 
 - HoP 2

What has here been said is already contained in that which was asserted by those who do not represent nature in this way, but say, that which is constituted as though it were constituted for an end, will endure. 
 - HoP 2

For this is the self-productive action of nature. 
 - HoP 2

In the Kantian philosophy we for the first time have that conception once more awakened in us, for organic nature at least; life has there been made an end to itself. 
 - HoP 2

The fact that most recent times have brought back the rational view of the matter into our remembrance, is thus none else than a justification of the Aristotelian Idea. 
 - HoP 2

For this instinctive action exhibits an operation of self-preservation, as a means whereby natural existence becomes shut up and reflected into itself. 
 - HoP 2

For the active form has a content, which, as content of potentiality, contains the means which make their appearance as adapted for an end, ie as moments established through the determinate Notion. 
 - HoP 2

This activity in transformation thus does not depend in a contingent way on life; it is aroused through the outward powers, but only in as far as conformity with the soul of the animal permits. 
 - HoP 2

In passing, Aristotle here  makes a comparison between nature and art, which also connects what results with what goes before, in accordance with ends. 
 - HoP 2

Nature may commit an error as well as art; for as a grammarian sometimes makes a mistake in writing, and a physician in mixing a medicinal draught, nature, too, sometimes does not attain its ends. 
 - HoP 2

Its errors are monstrosities and deformities, which, however, are only the errors of that which operates for an end. 
 - HoP 2

In the production of animals and plants, an animal is not at first produced, but the seed, and even in it corruption is possible. 
 - HoP 2

For the seed is the mean, as being the not as yet established, independent, indifferent, free actuality. 
 - HoP 2

In this comparison of nature with art we ordinarily have before us the external adaptation to end, the teleological point of view, the making for definite ends. 
 - HoP 2

The understanding comes forward with the determination of this end, and with its instruments and tools, to operate on matter, and we carry this conception of an external teleology over into nature. 
 - HoP 2

But art also,  says Aristotle, does not deliberate. 
 - HoP 2

If the form of a ship were the particular inward principle of the timber, it would act as nature prompted. 
 - HoP 2

The action of nature is very similar to the exercise of the art whereby anyone heals himself. 
 - HoP 2

As Aristotle has hitherto combated an external teleology, he directs another equally applicable remark  against merely external necessity, and thus we come to the other side, or to how necessity exists in nature. 
 - HoP 2

But Aristotle thus explains the facts of the case. 
 - HoP 2

The house is certainly not made without these materials, but not on account of, or through them , but it is made for the sake of concealing and preserving certain things. 
 - HoP 2

The same takes place in everything which has an end in itself; for it is not without that which is necessary to its nature, and yet it is not on account of this, unless the matter so demands, but on account of an end. 
 - HoP 2

Hence the necessary is from hypothesis only, and not as end, for necessity is in matter, but end is in reason. 
 - HoP 2

Thus it is clear that matter and its movement are necessity in natural things; both have to be set forth as principle, but end is the higher principle. 
 - HoP 2

It undoubtedly requires necessity, but it retains it in its own power, does not allow it to give vent to itself, but controls external necessity. 
 - HoP 2

The principle of matter is thus turned into the truly active ground of end, which means the overthrow of necessity, so that that which is natural shall maintain itself in the end. 
 - HoP 2

Necessity is the objective manifestation of the action of its moments as separated, just as in chemistry the essential reality of both the extremes-the base and the acid-is the necessity of their relation. 
 - HoP 2

This is the main conception of Aristotelian Physics. 
 - HoP 2

Thus he at first  proceeds from this point to movement , and says that it is essential that a philosophy of nature should speak of it, but that it is difficult to grasp; in fact, it is one of the most difficult conceptions. 
 - HoP 2

He explains this thus: Brass is in capacity a statue; yet the motion to become a statue is not a motion of the brass so far as it is brass, but a motion of itself, as the capacity to become a statue. 
 - HoP 2

Hence this activity is an imperfect one ,  ie it has not its end within itself, for mere capacity, whose activity is movement, is imperfect. 
 - HoP 2

The absolute substance, the moving immovable, the existent ground of heaven which we saw as end, is, on the contrary, both activity itself and the content and object of activity. 
 - HoP 2

But Aristotle distinguishes from this what falls under the form of this opposition, That moving is also moved which has movement as a capacity, and whose immobility is rest. 
 - HoP 2

That in which movement is present has immobility as rest; for activity in rest, as such, is movement. 
 - HoP 2

That is to say, rest is capacity for motion. 
 - HoP 2

Hence movement is the activity of that which is movable ,93 so far as it is movable; but this happens from the contact of that which is motive , so that at the same time it is posited as passive likewise. 
 - HoP 2

Thus, too, it is evident that movement is in the movable thing: for it is the activity of this, and is derived from that which is motive. 
 - HoP 2

The activity of that which is motive is likewise not different, for both are necessarily activity. 
 - HoP 2

It is motive because it has the capacity for being so; but it causes motion because it energizes. 
 - HoP 2

Activity and passivity are not originally  the same, but in what they are inherent, in motion, they are the same. 
 - HoP 2

In Being  they are identical, but activity, in so far as it is activity of this in this  , and the activity of this from this  , is different as regards its conception. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle subsequently deals with the infinite. 
 - HoP 2

In like manner it is necessary,  says Aristotle , that the natural philosopher should consider the subject of place. 
 - HoP 2

Here come various definitions and determinations under which space generally and particular space or place appear. 
 - HoP 2

Is place a body? It cannot be a body, for then there would be in one and the same, two bodies. 
 - HoP 2

But in truth there is no difference between the point and the place of the point, so that if place is not different from the other forms of limitation, neither is it something outside of them. 
 - HoP 2

It is not an element, and neither consists of corporeal nor of incorporeal elements, for it possesses magnitude, but not body. 
 - HoP 2

The elements of bodies are, however, themselves bodies, and no magnitude is produced from intelligible elements. 
 - HoP 2

Place is not the material of things, for nothing consists of it-neither the form, nor the Notion, nor the end, nor the moving cause; and yet it is something. 
 - HoP 2

The uttermost ends of what comprehends and of what is comprehended are identical, for both are bounds; but they are not bounds of the same, for form is the boundary of the thing, place is that of the embracing body. 
 - HoP 2

Place, as the comprehending, remains unchangeably passive while the thing which is moved is moved away; from which we see that place must be separable from the thing. 
 - HoP 2

Or place, according to Aristotle, is the boundary, the negation of a body, the assertion of difference, of discretion; but it likewise does not merely belong to this body, but also to that which comprehends. 
 - HoP 2

There is thus no difference at all, but unchangeable continuity. 
 - HoP 2

Place is neither the universal  in which all bodies are  , nor the particular , in which they are as the first. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle also speaks of above and below in space, in relation to heaven as that which contains, and earth as what is beneath. 
 - HoP 2

That body, outside of which is a comprehending body, is in space. 
 - HoP 2

But the whole heavens are not anywhere, since no body comprehends them. 
 - HoP 2

Outside the universe nothing is, and hence everything is in the heavens, for the heavens are the whole. 
 - HoP 2

Place, however, is not the heavens, but its external quiescent boundary which touches the body moved. 
 - HoP 2

Hence the earth is in water, water in air, air in ether, but ether in the heavens. 
 - HoP 2

Vacuum, according to ordinary ideas, is a space in which there is no body, and, fancying that all Being is body, they say that vacuum is that in which there is nothing at all. 
 - HoP 2

The other argument in favour of a vacuum is found in the compression of bodies, in which the parts press into the empty spaces. 
 - HoP 2

This is the conception of varying density and the alteration of the same, in accordance with which an equal weight might consist of an equal number of parts, but these, as being separated by vacuum, might present a greater volume. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle confutes these reasonings most adroitly, and first of all in this way; The plenum could be changed, and bodies could yield to one another even if no interval of vacuum separated them. 
 - HoP 2

Liquids as well as solids are not condensed into a vacuum; something that they contained is expelled, just as air is expelled if water is compressed. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle deals more thoroughly, in the first place , with the erroneous conception that the vacuum is the cause of movement. 
 - HoP 2

For, on the one hand, he shows that the vacuum really abolishes motion, and consequently in vacuum a universal rest would reign. 
 - HoP 2

He calls it perfect indifference as to the greater or less distance to which a thing is moved; in vacuum there are no distinctions. 
 - HoP 2

It is pure negation without object or difference; there is no reason for standing still or going on. 
 - HoP 2

But body is in movement, and that, indeed, as distinguished; it has a positive relation, and not one merely to nothing. 
 - HoP 2

On the other hand, Aristotle refutes the idea that movement is in vacuum because compression is possible. 
 - HoP 2

But this does not happen in a vacuum; there would be established in it not one movement, but a movement towards all sides, a general annihilation, an absolute yielding, where no cohesion would remain in the body. 
 - HoP 2

The difference in velocity is in inverse ratio to the specific gravity of the medium, air and water, so that if the medium has only half the density, the rate of progress will be double as quick. 
 - HoP 2

But vacuum has to body no such relation of differences of specific gravity. 
 - HoP 2

Body can no more contain a vacuum within its dimensions than a line can contain a point, unless the line were composed of points. 
 - HoP 2

The vacuum has no ratio to the plenum. 
 - HoP 2

This point of view is quite correct, and it is mainly directed against a number of conceptions that prevail in our physics. 
 - HoP 2

The conception of equal movement of the heavy and the light, as that of pure weight, pure matter, is an abstraction, being taken as though they were inherently like, only differing through the accidental resistance of the air. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle  now comes to the second point, to the proof of the vacuum because of the difference in specific gravity. 
 - HoP 2

Now if, as they say, the less dense were that which has many separate void spaces, it is evident that since a vacuum cannot be separated any more than a space can have intervals, neither can the rare subsist in this manner. 
 - HoP 2

But if it is not separable, and yet a vacuum is said to exist in the body, in the first place movement could thus only be upwards; for the rare is the light, and hence they say that fire is rare,  because it always moves upwards. 
 - HoP 2

In the next place the vacuum cannot be the cause of motion as that in which something moves, but must resemble bladders that carry up that which adheres to them. 
 - HoP 2

But how is it possible that a vacuum can move, or that there can be a place where there is a vacuum? For that into which it is carried would be the vacuum of a vacuum. 
 - HoP 2

In short, as there can be no movement in vacuum, so also a vacuum cannot move. 
 - HoP 2

And again, the matter of a small body and a large is the same, because at one time a greater proceeds from a smaller, and at another time a smaller from a greater. 
 - HoP 2

If air is generated from water it is expanded, but the matter remains the same and without taking to itself anything else; for that which it was in capacity it becomes in actuality. 
 - HoP 2

In a similar way if air is compressed from a greater into a less volume, the process will be reversed, and air will similarly pass into water, because the matter which is in capacity both air and water, also becomes both. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle likewise asserts that increase and decrease of warmth, and its transition into cold, is no addition or otherwise of warm matter, and also one and the same is both dense and rare. 
 - HoP 2

This is very different from the physical conceptions which assert more or less matter to correspond with more or less density, thus comprehending the difference in specific weight as the external addition of matter. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle, on the contrary, takes this dynamically, though certainly not in the sense in which dynamics are to-day understood, viz. 
 - HoP 2

Undoubtedly the difference must also be taken as a difference in amount, but not as an increase and decrease, or as an alteration in the absolute quantity of the matter. 
 - HoP 2

If the intensity is again directed outwards, and compared with other things, it undoubtedly becomes degree, and therefore magnitude immediately enters in. 
 - HoP 2

For one part of it was and is not: another part will be and is not as yet; but of these parts infinite and everlasting , time is composed. 
 - HoP 2

But it now appears that time, if composed of things that are not, may be incapable of existence. 
 - HoP 2

And also as regards everything divisible, if it exists, either some or all of its parts must be. 
 - HoP 2

Time is certainly divisible; but some of the parts are past, others are future, and no part is present. 
 - HoP 2

For the now is no part, since a part has a measure, and the whole must consist of the parts; but time does not appear to consist of the Now. 
 - HoP 2

That is to say, because the Now is indivisible, it has no quantitative determination which could be measured. 
 - HoP 2

Besides it is not easy to decide whether the Now remains, or always becomes another and another. 
 - HoP 2

Again, time is not a movement and change, for movement and change occur in that which is moved and changed, or accompany time in its course; but time is everywhere alike. 
 - HoP 2

Besides change is swifter and slower, but time is not. 
 - HoP 2

But it is not without change and motion   for when we perceive no change, it appears as if no time had elapsed, as in sleep. 
 - HoP 2

Time is hence in motion but not motion itself. 
 - HoP 2

Now when we understand that the extremes of the conclusion are different from the middle, and the soul says that the Now has two instants, the one prior and the other posterior, then we say that this is time. 
 - HoP 2

What is determined through the Now, we call time, and this is the fundamental principle. 
 - HoP 2

But when we are sensible of the Now as one, and not as a prior and posterior in motion, nor as the identity of an earlier or later, then there does not appear to us to have been any time, because neither was there any motion. 
 - HoP 2

Tedium is thus ever the same. 
 - HoP 2

Time is hence the number of motion, according to priority and posteriority; it is not motion itself, unless so far as motion has number. 
 - HoP 2

We judge of the more or less through number, but of a greater or less motion by time. 
 - HoP 2

But we call number that which can be numbered, as well as that with which we number; but time is not the number with which we number, but that which is numbered, and, like motion, always is changing. 
 - HoP 2

The Now is, which is the unity of number, and it measures time. 
 - HoP 2

The whole of time is the same, for the Now which was is the same   but in Being it is another. 
 - HoP 2

Time thus is through the Now both continuous  and discrete. 
 - HoP 2

It thereby resembles the point, for that also is the continuity of the line and its division, its principle and limit; but the Now is not an enduring point. 
 - HoP 2

As continuity of time the Now connects the past and the future, but it likewise divides time in capacity,  the Now is only divisibility and the moments only ideal. 
 - HoP 2

And in as far as it is such, it is always another; but, in as far as it unites, it is ever one and the same. 
 - HoP 2

Similarly, in as far as we divide the line, other and yet other points always arise for thought; but in as far as it is one, there is only one point. 
 - HoP 2

Thus the Now is both the division of time in capacity, and the limit and union of both  ie of the prior and posterior. 
 - HoP 2

The universally dividing point is only one as actual; but this actual is not permanently one, but ever and again another, so that individuality has universality, as its negativity, within it. 
 - HoP 2

But division and union are the same, and similarly related; however their Notion 95 is different. 
 - HoP 2

Thus the identity of the understanding is not a principle with Aristotle, for identity and non-identity to him are one and the same. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle  then goes on to movement as realized in a thing, to change  or to the physical processes-while before we had pure movement. 
 - HoP 2

In movement there is first something which moves, also something which is moved, and the time in which it is moved; besides these, that from which, and that into which it is moved. 
 - HoP 2

For all motion is from something and into something; but there is a difference between that which is first moved and that into which and from which it is moved, as, for instance, wood, warmth and cold. 
 - HoP 2

The motion is in the wood and not in the form; for neither form nor place, nor quantity moves or is moved, but   there is that which is moved and that which moves, and that into which it is moved. 
 - HoP 2

That to which movement is made, more than that out of which movement is made, is named change. 
 - HoP 2

Hence to pass into non-being is also change, although what passes away is changed from Being: and generation is a mutation into Being, even though it is from non-being. 
 - HoP 2

The remark is to be interpreted as meaning that for the first time in real becoming motion, ie in change, the relation whereto enters, while the relation wherefrom is that in which change is still the mere ideal motion. 
 - HoP 2

The fourth, from a non-subject into a non-subject,  which may also appear in the general division, is no mutation, for it contains no opposition. 
 - HoP 2

It may certainly be merely thought or ideal, but Aristotle indicates the actual phenomenon. 
 - HoP 2

This opposition of the materialized motion as mutation, and of merely formal motion, is noteworthy. 
 - HoP 2

In the sixth book Aristotle comes to the consideration of the dialectic of this motion and change as advanced by Zeno, that is, to the endless divisibility which we have already  considered. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle solves it through the universal. 
 - HoP 2

Of the further details into which Aristotle enters, I shall only give the following. 
 - HoP 2

As against atoms and their motion, he remarks  that the indivisible has no motion and mutation, which is the direct opposite of the proposition of Zeno that only simple indivisible Being and no motion exists. 
 - HoP 2

For as Zeno argues from the indivisibility of atoms against motion, Aristotle argues from motion against atoms. 
 - HoP 2

Everything which moves or changes is in the first division of this time partly here and partly there. 
 - HoP 2

The atom, as simple indivisible Being, can, however, not have any part of it in both points in space, because it then would be divisible. 
 - HoP 2

The indivisible could thus only move if time consisted of the Now; this is, however, impossible, as we proved before. 
 - HoP 2

Because atoms thus neither have change in themselves, nor can this come to them from without through impulse, &c, they are really without truth. 
 - HoP 2

The determination of the pure ideality of change is important. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle says of this , That which is changed is alone the sensuous and perceptible ; and forms and figures, as also capacities, are not changed, they arise and disappear in a thing only, without being themselves changed. 
 - HoP 2

In other words: the content of change is unchangeable; change as such belongs to mere form. 
 - HoP 2

Virtues or vices belong, for example, to habits acquired. 
 - HoP 2

Virtue is the perfection  in which something has reached the end of its nature. 
 - HoP 2

Vice, however, is the corruption and non-attainment of this. 
 - HoP 2

They are not changes, for they only arise and pass away while another alters. 
 - HoP 2

Or the difference becomes a difference of Being and non-being, ie a merely sensuous difference. 
 - HoP 2

From these conceptions Aristotle now comes nearer to the first real or physical motion : The first principle of motion is itself unmoved. 
 - HoP 2

An endless motion in a straight line is an empty creation of thought; for motion is necessarily an effort after something. 
 - HoP 2

The absolute motion is the circular, because it is without opposition. 
 - HoP 2

For because movement has to be considered in regard to the starting-place and the end in view, in the straight movement the directions from A to B and from B to A are opposed, but in motion in a circle they are the same. 
 - HoP 2

The idea that heavenly bodies would of themselves have moved in a straight line, but that they accidentally came into the sphere of solar attraction, is an empty reflection which is far from occurring to Aristotle. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle then shows  that the whole heavens neither arose nor can pass away, for they are one and eternal: they neither have beginning nor end in eternal time, for they contain infinite time shut up within them. 
 - HoP 2

All the other ideas are sensuous which try to speak of essential reality, and in them there always is that present which they think they have excluded. 
 - HoP 2

But in fact a thing does not exist before its origination, ie in movement there is something to move, and where reality is, there is motion. 
 - HoP 2

They do not, however, bring together that vacuum, the self-identical, the un-originated matter and this nothing. 
 - HoP 2

That which has this absolute circular movement is neither heavy nor light; for the heavy is what moves downwards, and the light what moves upwards. 
 - HoP 2

In modern physics the heavenly bodies, on the other hand, are endowed with weight, and seek to rush into the sun, but cannot do so on account of another force. 
 - HoP 2

It is indestructible and ungenerated, without decrease or increase, without any change. 
 - HoP 2

It is different from earth, fire, air and water; it is what the ancients called ether, as the highest place, from its continuous course  in infinite time. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle  shows further that the elements do not proceed from one body, but from one another; for in generation they neither proceed from what is incorporeal, nor from what is corporeal. 
 - HoP 2

In the first case they would have sprung from the vacuum, for the vacuum is the immediate incorporeal; but in that case the vacuum must have existed independently as that in which determinate corporeality arose. 
 - HoP 2

But neither do the elements arise from a corporeal, for else this body itself would be a corporeal element before the elements. 
 - HoP 2

Thus it only remains that the elements must spring from one another. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle does not consider the universal as it contains the negative within it; else the universal would be the absolute matter whose universality, as negativity, is set forth, or is real. 
 - HoP 2

From this point Aristotle comes  to a kind of deduction of the elements, which is noteworthy. 
 - HoP 2

He shows that there must be four of them, in the following way-because he starts from the fundamental conceptions of weight and of lightness, or what we should call attraction and centrifugal force. 
 - HoP 2

The corporeal, he says, in its motion is neither light nor heavy, and, indeed, it is not only relative but also absolute. 
 - HoP 2

The relatively light and heavy is what, while equal in volume, descends more slowly or quickly. 
 - HoP 2

Absolute lightness goes up to the extremity of the heavens, absolute weight down into the middle. 
 - HoP 2

These extremes are fire and earth. 
 - HoP 2

Between these there are mediums, other than they, which relate to one another like them; and these are air and water, the one of which has weight, and the other lightness, but only relatively. 
 - HoP 2

For water is suspended under everything except earth, and air over everything except fire. 
 - HoP 2

Hence,  Aristotle concludes, there now are these four matters, but they are four in such a way that they have one in common; more particularly, because they arise out of one another, but exist as different. 
 - HoP 2

Yet it is not the ether that Aristotle designates as this common matter. 
 - HoP 2

But however removed Aristotle may be from understanding simplicity as an abstraction, just as little does he recognize here the arid conception of consisting of parts. 
 - HoP 2

Quite the contrary. 
 - HoP 2

He strives enough against this, as, for instance, in relation to Anaxagoras. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle excludes the relations which concern sight, smell, &c, and brings forward the others as being those which are of sensible weight or lightness. 
 - HoP 2

He gives as these fundamental principles-warmth and cold, dryness and moisture; they are the sensible differences for others, while weight and lightness are different for themselves. 
 - HoP 2

And these connections follow those first elements, so that thus fire is warm and dry, air warm and moist , water cold and moist, earth cold and dry. 
 - HoP 2

From this Aristotle now makes the reciprocal transformation of the elements into one another comprehensible thus: Origination and decay proceed from the opposite and into the opposite. 
 - HoP 2

All elements have a mutual opposite; each is as non-being to the Being of the other, and one is thus distinguished from the other as actuality and capacity. 
 - HoP 2

Now amongst these some have an equal part in common; fire and water, for example, have warmth; thus if in fire dryness were overcome by moisture, out of fire air would arise. 
 - HoP 2

On the contrary, as regards those which have nothing in common with one another, like earth, which is cold and dry, and air, which is warm and moist, the transition goes more slowly forward. 
 - HoP 2

The transition of all elements into one another, the whole process of nature, is thus to Aristotle the constant rotation of their changes. 
 - HoP 2

This is unsatisfactory, because neither are the individual elements comprehended nor is the remainder rounded into a whole. 
 - HoP 2

As a matter of fact, Aristotle now goes on, in meteorology, to the consideration of the universal process of nature. 
 - HoP 2

But here we have reached his limits. 
 - HoP 2

Here, in the natural process, the simple determination as such-this system of progressive determination-ceases to hold good, and its whole interest is lost. 
 - HoP 2

For it is in the real process that these determinate conceptions always lose their signification again and become their opposite, and in it also this contingent succession is forced together and united. 
 - HoP 2

But still more must the following moments, moisture, warmth, &c, themselves come back under the conception of process. 
 - HoP 2

But the sensuous manifestation here begins to obtain the upper hand; for the empirical has the nature of the isolated form, which is to fall out of relation. 
 - HoP 2

As regards the other side from the Philosophy of Nature, the Philosophy of Mind, we find that Aristotle has constituted in it also a separation into special sciences, in a series of works which I shall name. 
 - HoP 2

Thus there are several different treatises, viz. 
 - HoP 2

The manner of treatment is almost invariably speculative, and sound understanding is displayed throughout. 
 - HoP 2

In Aristotles teaching on this subject we must not expect to find so-called metaphysics of the soul. 
 - HoP 2

For metaphysical handling such as this really pre-supposes the soul as a thing, and asks, for example, what sort of a thing it is, whether it is simple, and so on. 
 - HoP 2

According to the one view, anger, for instance, is looked on as an eager desire for retaliation or the like; according to the other view it is the surging upward of the heart-blood and the warm element in man. 
 - HoP 2

The soul is substance, as being the form of the physical organic body which is possessed potentially of life; but its substance is energy , the energy of a body such as has been described. 
 - HoP 2

This energy appears in twofold form: either as knowledge  or as active observation. 
 - HoP 2

But it is evident that here it is to be regarded as the former of these. 
 - HoP 2

For the soul is present with us both when we sleep and when we wake; waking corresponds with active observation, and sleep with possession and passivity. 
 - HoP 2

But knowledge is in origination prior to all else. 
 - HoP 2

The soul is thus the first energy of a physical but organic body. 
 - HoP 2

It is in respect of this that Aristotle gives to the soul the definition of being the entelechy. 
 - HoP 2

In the same chapter Aristotle comes to the question of the mutual relation of body and soul. 
 - HoP 2

For this reason   we must no more ask if soul and body are one than we ask if wax and its form are one, or, in general, if matter and its forms are one. 
 - HoP 2

For though unity and Being are used in various senses. 
 - HoP 2

Being is essentially energy. 
 - HoP 2

The only question that now arises is whether activity and the organ it employs are one; and our idea is to answer in the affirmative. 
 - HoP 2

The more definite explanation of this relation is to be found in the following; The soul is substance, but only according to the Notion ; but that is the substantial form 96 for such and such a body. 
 - HoP 2

But soul is not the substantial form and Notion of such a body as an axe, but of a body which has within itself the principle of movement and of rest. 
 - HoP 2

The axe has not the principle of its form in itself, it does not make itself an axe, nor does its form, its Notion, in itself constitute its substance, as its activity is not through itself. 
 - HoP 2

If, for instance, the eye were in itself a living thing, vision would be its soul, for vision is the reality which expresses the Notion of the eye. 
 - HoP 2

But the eye, as such, is only the material instrument of vision, for if vision were lost, the eye would be an eye only in name, like an eye of stone or a painted eye. 
 - HoP 2

Thus to the question, What is the substance of the eye? Aristotle answers: Are the nerves, humours, tissues, its substance? On the contrary, sight itself is its substance, these material substances are only an empty name. 
 - HoP 2

As this is the case in the part, so it also holds good of the body as a whole. 
 - HoP 2

The potentiality of life is not in any such thing as has lost its soul, but in that which still possesses it. 
 - HoP 2

The seed or the fruit is such and such a body potentially. 
 - HoP 2

Like hewing and seeing,  in the axe and the eye, waking  in general is activity; but the corporeal is only potentiality. 
 - HoP 2

But as the  living eye is both vision and the eyeball  , so also are soul and body the living animal, the two are not to be separated. 
 - HoP 2

But it is not yet clear whether the soul is the activity of the body in the same way as the steersman is of the ship. 
 - HoP 2

That the active form is the true substance, while matter is so only potentially, is a true speculative Notion. 
 - HoP 2

As settling the question asked in the above-mentioned metaphor, we may quote what Aristotle says later : As the principle of motion and as end , and as substance of living bodies, the soul is the cause. 
 - HoP 2

For substance is to all objects the cause of their existence, but life is the existence of the living, and its cause and principle is the soul; and further, its energy is the existing Notion of what has potential existence. 
 - HoP 2

The soul is cause also as end,  that is, as self-determining universality, for nature, like thought, acts for the sake of an object, which object is its end, but in living beings this is soul. 
 - HoP 2

All the parts of the body are thus the organs of the soul, and hence exist for its sake. 
 - HoP 2

In like manner Aristotle shows that the soul is the cause of motion. 
 - HoP 2

Aristotle  further states that the soul is to be determined in three ways, namely as nutrient or vegetable, as sensitive, and as intelligent, corresponding with plant life, animal life and human life. 
 - HoP 2

The nutrient soul, when it is alone, belongs to plants; when it is at the same time capable of sense-perception, it is the animal soul; and when at once nutrient, sensitive and intelligent, it is the mind of man. 
 - HoP 2

That difference has also been revived in recent times in the observation of the organic, and it is highly important to keep these sides separate. 
 - HoP 2

The only question  is how far these, as parts, are separable. 
 - HoP 2

This is a profound observation, by means of which truly speculative thought marks itself out from the thought which is merely logical and formal. 
 - HoP 2

On the other hand, the triangle is the first, the truly universal figure, which appears also in the square, &c, as the figure which can be led back to the simplest determination. 
 - HoP 2

Therefore, on the one hand, the triangle stands alongside of the square, pentagon, &c, as a particular figure, but-and this is Aristotles main contention-it is the truly universal figure. 
 - HoP 2
