Evil is no absolute principle independent of God, as the ManichÃ¦ans held it to be. 
 - HoP 2

It is not non-existent in the same way that motion and rest are existent, but is like an image of the existent, or non-existent in an even greater degree; it is the sensuous universe. 
 - HoP 2

Thus evil has its root in the non-existent. 
 - HoP 2

In the eighth book of the first Ennead Plotinus says : But how is evil recognized? It is owing to thought turning away from itself that matter arises; it exists only through the abstraction of what is other than itself. 
 - HoP 2

What remains behind when we take away the Ideas is, we say, matter; thought accordingly becomes different, the opposite of thought, since it dares to direct itself on that which is not within its province. 
 - HoP 2

This abstract other is nothing but matter, and it is also evil; the seeing of the less measure is nothing but a non-seeing. 
 - HoP 2

The sensuous in regard to measure, or the limited, is the less measure, the boundless, the undefined, unresting, insatiable, the utterly deficient; such is not accidental to it, but its substance. 
 - HoP 2

Its aim is always Becoming; we cannot say that it is, but only that it is always about to be. 
 - HoP 2

The soul which makes Î½Î¿á¿¦Ï its aim is pure, holds off matter and all that is indeterminate and measureless. 
 - HoP 2

But why then, when there is the Good, is there also necessarily Evil? Because there must be matter in the whole, because the whole necessarily consists of opposites. 
 - HoP 2

It would not be there, if matter were not present; the nature of the world is compounded of Î½Î¿á¿¦Ï and necessity. 
 - HoP 2

To be with the gods means to be in thought; for they are immortal. 
 - HoP 2

We may also apprehend the necessity of evil in this wise: As the Good cannot exist alone, matter is a counterpart to the Good, necessary to its production. 
 - HoP 2

Or we might also say that Evil is that which by reason of constant deterioration and decay has sunk until it can sink no lower; but something is necessary after the first, so that the extreme is also necessary. 
 - HoP 2

But that is matter, which has no longer any element of good in it; and this is the necessity of evil. 
 - HoP 2

With Plotinus, as with Pythagoras, the leading of the soul to virtue is also an important subject. 
 - HoP 2

For no purpose is served by saying,243 Look unto God; it must also be shown how we can succeed in causing man thus to behold God. 
 - HoP 2

The Gnostics limit truth to the mental and intellectual; to this mere intellectuality Plotinus declares himself distinctly opposed, and holds firmly to the essential connection of the intelligible and the real. 
 - HoP 2

Plotinus honoured the heathen gods, attributing to them a deep meaning and a profound efficacy. 
 - HoP 2

He says in the same treatise , It is not by despising the world and the gods in it, and all else that is beautiful, that man attains to goodness. 
 - HoP 2

The wicked man holds the gods in contempt, and it is only when he has completely reached this stage that he becomes utterly depraved. 
 - HoP 2

He who loves anything loves also all things related to the same, therefore also the children of the father whom he loves. 
 - HoP 2

Every soul is the daughter of this father. 
 - HoP 2

But souls in the heavenly spheres are more intelligible, and better, and far more nearly related to the higher Power than our souls are. 
 - HoP 2

For how could this world of reality be cut off from that higher sphere? Those who despise that which is related thereto know it only in name. 
 - HoP 2

If He is at a distance from the world, He is at a distance also from us, and you could say nothing of Him or of what He produces. 
 - HoP 2

This world also partakes of Him, and is not forsaken by Him, and never will be so. 
 - HoP 2

For the whole partakes of the divine much more than the part does, and the world-soul shares in it to a still greater degree. 
 - HoP 2

The Being and the rationality of the world are a proof of this. 
 - HoP 2

In this we have the main ideas on which the intellectualism of Plotinus is based, the general conceptions to which everything particular is led back; the instances in which this is done are often, however, figurative. 
 - HoP 2

What, in the first place, is lacking in them, as we have already remarked, is the Notion. 
 - HoP 2

Severance, emanation, effluence or process, emergence, occurrence, are words which in modern times have also had to stand for much, but in fact nothing is expressed by them. 
 - HoP 2

Scepticism and dogmatism, as consciousness or knowledge, establish the opposition of subjectivity and objectivity. 
 - HoP 2

I quote one example only: our soul belongs not only to the sphere of the finite understanding, where it was perfect, happy, lacking nothing; its power of thought alone belongs to the first, the finite understanding. 
 - HoP 2

Its power of motion, or itself looked on as life, had as its source the intelligent world-soul, but sensation had its source in the soul of the world of sensation. 
 - HoP 2

This world-soul has power to originate; from it again there flows an entirely sensuous soul. 
 - HoP 2

The desire of the individual and particular soul separated from the whole gives it a body; this it receives in the higher region of the heavens. 
 - HoP 2

With this body it obtains fancy and memory. 
 - HoP 2

At last it repairs to the soul of the sensible world; and from this it acquires sensation, desires, and the life that is vegetative in nature. 
 - HoP 2

In such a way as this Plotinus makes into a particular existence for the spiritual the very things that he declares to be, on the one hand, intelligible moments. 
 - HoP 2

The soul which only has desires is the beast; that which only vegetates, which has only power of reproduction, is the plant. 
 - HoP 2

When they in their potency are expressed as moments of the soul, this is not a whit better than when each of them was supposed to express a particular metal. 
 - HoP 2

The above is a comparison with a thing that in like manner does not express a Notion, but is apparent to the senses, which is laid hold of out of the air, or rather indeed from the ground. 
 - HoP 2

Porphyry and Iamblichus, who have already been mentioned as the biographers of Pythagoras , are distinguished followers of Plotinus. 
 - HoP 2

Amongst other works by Porphyrius, we possess an Introduction to the Organon of Aristotle on Genera, Species, and Judgments,  in which his logic is propounded in its principal elements. 
 - HoP 2

The fact that Porphyry devoted himself to logic shows that a determinate form of thought was coming into favour with the Neo-Platonists; but this is something pertaining altogether to the understanding and very formal. 
 - HoP 2

It was likewise in the Pythagorean philosophy that the Neo-Platonists gloried, and more particularly they revived the form of number-determination which pertains to it. 
 - HoP 2

In Iamblichus thought sinks into imagination, the intellectual universe to a kingdom of demons and angels with a classification of the same, and speculation comes down to the methods of magic. 
 - HoP 2

The Neo-Platonists called this theurgy ; for in the miracle speculation, the divine Idea, is, so to speak, brought into immediate contact with actuality, and not set forth in a universal way. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus, a later Neo-Platonist who has still to be mentioned, is more important. 
 - HoP 2

His life is written by Marinus, in a style similar to that of the biographies just mentioned. 
 - HoP 2

According to this his parents came from Xanthus in Lycia, a district of Asia Minor; and since Apollo and Minerva were the tutelary deities of this town, he rendered grateful worship to them. 
 - HoP 2

They, themselves, vouchsafed to him, as their favourite, particular regard and personal manifestations; indeed, he was healed of an illness by Apollo touching his head; by Minerva, however, he was called upon to go to Athens. 
 - HoP 2

First of all he went to Alexandria to study rhetoric and philosophy, and then to Athens, to be with Plutarchus and Syrianus, the Platonists. 
 - HoP 2

Here he first studied Aristotelian and then Platonic philosophy. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus is said to have had himself initiated into all the pagan mysteries. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus himself composed many hymns-of which we still possess some that are very beautiful-both in honour of the better known divinities and of those whose fame is entirely local. 
 - HoP 2

He considered Orpheus to be the originator of all Greek theology, and set a specially high value on the Orphic and Chaldaic oracles. 
 - HoP 2

It was in Athens that he taught. 
 - HoP 2

Of course his biographer, Marinus, relates the most marvellous things about him, that he brought down rain from heaven and tempered great heat, that he stilled the earthquake, healed diseases, and beheld visions of the divine. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus led a most intellectual life; he was a profoundly speculative man, and the scope of his knowledge was very great. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus left behind him a great number of writings, many of which we now possess; he was the author of several mathematical works which we also have, such as that on the Sphere. 
 - HoP 2

His more important philosophic works are the Commentaries on Platos Dialogues, certain of which have been published from time to time; that on the TimÃ¦us was the most famous. 
 - HoP 2

But several were only found in manuscript, and of these Cousin issued in Paris the Commentaries on the Alcibiades , and the Parmenides  for the first time. 
 - HoP 2

The first volume of Cousins edition contains some writings by Proclus which now exist only in Latin, on Freedom, Providence, and Evil. 
 - HoP 2

Works separately published are his important writings, The Platonic Theology  and his Theological Elements ; the latter short work Creuzer has had re-published, as also some of the before-mentioned Commentaries. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus lived, so to speak, in the worship of science. 
 - HoP 2

His philosophy, like that of Plotinus, has the form of a Commentary on Plato; his book On the Theology of Plato,  is in this respect his most interesting work. 
 - HoP 2

The main ideas of his philosophy may easily be recognized from this work, which possesses many difficulties for this reason in particular, that in it the pagan gods are considered, and philosophic significations derived from them. 
 - HoP 2

His philosophy is an intellectual system; we must see how we can work it out. 
 - HoP 2

His way of putting it is not perfectly clear, but leaves much to be desired. 
 - HoP 2

But the self-development of this unity is not made the necessity of the Notion with Proclus any more than with Plotinus; we must once for all give up seeking here for the Notion of disunion. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus  says, The one is in itself inexpressible and unknowable; but it is comprehended from its issuing forth and retiring into itself. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus in the same place  defines this self-differentiation, the first characteristic of unity, as a production , a going forth , and also as a representation or demonstration. 
 - HoP 2

The relation to difference of the unity which brings forth is, however, not an issuing forth from self, for an issuing forth would be a change, and unity would be posited as no more self-identical. 
 - HoP 2

As far as this goes, the Notion is, properly speaking, no clearer than with Plotinus. 
 - HoP 2

What distinguishes Plotinus is his more profound study of the Platonic dialectic; in this way he occupies himself in his Platonic theology with the most acute and far-reaching dialectic of the One. 
 - HoP 2

It is necessary for him to demonstrate the many as one and the one as many, to show forth the forms which the One adopts. 
 - HoP 2

But it is a dialectic which to a greater or less extent is externally worked out, and which is most wearisome. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus now shows, according to the Platonic dialectic, how all determinations, and particularly that of multiplicity, are resolved into themselves and return into unity. 
 - HoP 2

But since we now ascribe no substantiality, no proper Being to a thought, all such determinations are only moments of a thing in thought. 
 - HoP 2

Respecting these negations  Proclus now says  that they do not signify an abrogation of the content  of which they are predicated, but are the creation of determinatives in accordance with their opposites. 
 - HoP 2

Thus if Plato shows that the first is not many, this has the significance that the many proceed from the first; if he shows that it is not a whole, it proves that the fact of being a whole proceeds from it. 
 - HoP 2

The mode  of negations is thus to be taken as perfection which remains in unity, issues forth from everything, and is in an inexpressible and ineffable preponderance of simplicity. 
 - HoP 2

On the other hand, God must likewise be derived from these negations; else there would be no Notion  of them, and also no negation. 
 - HoP 2

The Notion of the inexpressible revolves round itself, never resting, and it strives with itself;  ie the one implies its determinations ideally, the whole is contained in the one. 
 - HoP 2

Multiplicity is not taken empirically and then merely abrogated; the negative, as dividing, producing, and active, not merely contains what is privative, but also affirmative determinations. 
 - HoP 2

In this way the Platonic dialectic wins for Proclus a positive significance; through dialectic he would lead all differences back to unity. 
 - HoP 2

With this dialectic of the one and many Proclus makes much ado, more especially in his famous elementary doctrines. 
 - HoP 2

The submersion of everything in unity remains, however, merely beyond this unity, instead of which this very negativity must really be grasped as signifying its production. 
 - HoP 2

That which brings forth, according to Proclus, furthermore brings forth through a superfluity of power. 
 - HoP 2

There certainly also is a bringing forth through want; all need, all desire, for example, becomes cause through want; and its bringing forth is its satisfaction. 
 - HoP 2

The end here is incomplete, and the energy arises from the endeavour to complete itself, so that only in production the need becomes less, the desire ceases to be such, or its abstract Being-for-self disappears. 
 - HoP 2

Unity, on the other hand, goes forth out of itself through the superfluity of potentiality, and this superabundant potentiality is actuality generally: this reflection of Proclus is quite Aristotelian. 
 - HoP 2

Hence the coming forth of the unity consists in the fact that it multiplies itself, pure number comes forth; but this multiplication does not negate or diminish that first unity, but rather takes place in the method of unity. 
 - HoP 2

The many partakes of the unity, but the unity does not partake of multiplicity. 
 - HoP 2

The absolute unity which multiplies itself into many ones has consequently generated multiplicity as it is in these ones. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus makes use of a many-sided dialectic to show that the many does not exist in itself, is not the creator of the many, that everything goes back into unity, and thus unity is also the originator of the many. 
 - HoP 2

It is, however, not made clear how this is the negative relation of the one to itself; what we see is then a manifold dialectic, which merely passes backwards and forwards over the relationship of the one to the many. 
 - HoP 2

To Proclus an important characteristic of this progression is the fact that it takes place through analogy, and what is dissimilar to the truth is the further removed from the same. 
 - HoP 2

The many partakes of unity, but it is in a measure likewise not one, but dissimilar to one. 
 - HoP 2

But since the many is also similar to what produces it, it likewise has unity as its essence; hence the many are independent unities. 
 - HoP 2

They contain the principle of unity within themselves, for if as being many they are likewise different, they are, so to speak, only many for a third, being in and for themselves unities. 
 - HoP 2

These unities again beget others which must, however, be less perfect, for the effect is not exactly like the cause, that which is brought forth is not quite similar to what brings it forth. 
 - HoP 2

These next unities are wholes, ie, they are no longer real unities, unities in themselves, since in them the unity is only an accident. 
 - HoP 2

But because things themselves are in their synthetic nature merely wholes because their souls bind them together, they are dissimilar to the first unity, and cannot be immediately united to it. 
 - HoP 2

The abstractly conceived multiplicity is thus their mean; multiplicity is analogous to absolute unity, and is that which unites unity with the whole universe. 
 - HoP 2

Pure multiplicity makes the different elements like one another, and hence unites them to unity; but things only have similarity to unity. 
 - HoP 2

Thus things that are begotten ever remove themselves more and more from unity, and partake of it less and less. 
 - HoP 2

The further determination of the Idea is known as the trinity. 
 - HoP 2

Of this Proclus  first of all gives the abstract definition that its three forms are three gods, and now we have more especially to find out how he defined the trinity. 
 - HoP 2

This trinity is certainly interesting in the Neo-Platonists, but it is specially so in the case of Proclus, because he did not leave it in its abstract moments. 
 - HoP 2

For he again considers these three abstract determinations of the absolute, each on its own account, as a totality of triunity, whereby he obtains one real trinity. 
 - HoP 2

It will be shown directly which orders these are, and Proclus occupies himself much with these, because he tries to demonstrate the different powers again in them. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus is hence much more detailed, and he went much further than did Plotinus; it may indeed be said that in this respect we find in him the most excellent and best that was formulated by any of the Neo-Platonists. 
 - HoP 2

This unity is the super-substantial , and in the second place its first production is the many ones  of things, pure numbers. 
 - HoP 2

To this Proclus refers the forms of ancient mythology. 
 - HoP 2

That is to say, as he calls that first unity God, he calls these numerous unities of thought that flow from it, gods, but the following moments are likewise so called. 
 - HoP 2

He says, : The gods are named in accordance with what depends upon the orders ; hence it is possible to know from this their unknowable substances, which constitute their determinate nature. 
 - HoP 2

For everything divine is inexpressible on its own account and unknowable as forming part of the inexpressible one; but from differentiation, from change, it comes to pass that we know its characteristics. 
 - HoP 2

Thus there are gods capable of being known, which radiate true Being; hence true Being is the knowable divine, and the incommunicable is made manifest for the Î½Î¿á¿¦Ï. 
 - HoP 2

But there always remains a compulsion to represent mythology in the determinateness of the Notion. 
 - HoP 2

These gods or unities do not correspond to the order of things in such a way that there are just as many and such unities  or gods as there are things; for these unities only unite things with the absolute unity. 
 - HoP 2

The third is just the limit which holds these unities  together, and constitutes their unity with the absolute unity; the limit asserts the unity of the many and the one. 
 - HoP 2

But to such abstractions the name gods is not applicable, for it is as returning that we first of all see them as divine. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus says : From that first limit ,  the absolute one, things have  union, entirety and community,  the principle of individuality, and divine measure. 
 - HoP 2

In all opposition which is found in species that are divine, what is more excellent belongs to limitation, and what is less excellent to the infinite. 
 - HoP 2

From these two principles everything derives its progress until it steps forth into Being. 
 - HoP 2

Thus the eternal, in so far as it is measure as intellectual, partakes of limitation, but in so far as it is the cause of unceasing effort after Being, of infinitude. 
 - HoP 2

Thus the understanding in so far as it has the standard  within it, is a product of limitation; in so far as it eternally produces everything, it has undiminished capacity for infinitude. 
 - HoP 2

Multiplicity as Notion, not as the many, is itself unity; it is duality, or the determinateness which stands over against indeterminateness. 
 - HoP 2

Now according to Proclus  the third is a whole, the unity of determinate and indeterminate, or that which is mingled. 
 - HoP 2

This is first of all everything existent, a monad of many possibilities, a completed reality, a many in one. 
 - HoP 2

Now if we consider further the nature of what is mingled we find the three triads likewise, for each of those three abstract principles is itself a similar complete triad, but under one or these particular forms. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus says ; The first Being  is the mingled, the unity of the triad with itself; it is the Being of the life as well as of the understanding. 
 - HoP 2

The first of what is mingled is the first of all existence, the life and the spirit are the two other orders; everything is consequently in triads. 
 - HoP 2

These three triads determine themselves thus as absolute Being, life and spirit; and they are spiritual and to be grasped in thought. 
 - HoP 2

According to this only the intelligible world is true for Proclus. 
 - HoP 2

But that Proclus did not make the understanding proceed immediately from the unity, is the second point in which he differs from Plotinus; in this Proclus is more logical, and he follows Plato more closely. 
 - HoP 2

As a matter of fact we find more distinction and clearness in Proclus than in the turbidity of Plotinus; he is quite correct in recognizing the Î½Î¿á¿¦Ï as the third, for it is, that which turns back. 
 - HoP 2

The life that is grasped by thought is the very centre-point of existence. 
 - HoP 2

But the understanding is the limit of the existent, and it is thought as known , for in what is thought is thinking, and in thinking what is thought. 
 - HoP 2

But in what is thought thinking is in the mode of thought , in thinking what is thought is in the mode of thinking. 
 - HoP 2

Substance is the enduring element in existence and that which is interwoven with the first principles and which does not proceed from the one. 
 - HoP 2

The second, the life, is however that which proceeds from the principles and is born with infinite capacity;  it is itself the whole totality in the determination of infinitude, so that it is a concrete manifold. 
 - HoP 2

The understanding is, again, the limit which leads back once more to the principles, brings about conformity with the principle, and accomplishes an intellectual circle. 
 - HoP 2

That is the first reality. 
 - HoP 2

Excellent! I call it substance, since the first substance  is supreme over all existence and is, so to speak, the monad of everything. 
 - HoP 2

The understanding itself is that which knows, but life is thinking, and Being is just what is thought. 
 - HoP 2

Now if the whole of what exists is mingled, but the first existence  is substance, the substance that comes from the three principles  is mingled. 
 - HoP 2

What is mingled is thus substance as thought; it is from God, from whom also come the infinite and limitation. 
 - HoP 2

There are thus four moments, since what is mingled is the fourth. 
 - HoP 2

The first is the monad, the absolute one, then come the many which themselves are units, the infinite of Plato; the third is limitation. 
 - HoP 2

This united one is not only derived from those principles which are according to the one, but it also goes forth from them and is three-fold. 
 - HoP 2

It is one trinity and three trinities. 
 - HoP 2

The limit and the infinite are, according to Proclus , before substance and again in it; and this unity of moments is what comes first in all existence. 
 - HoP 2

In the abstract trinity everything is thus contained in itself. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus says : The truly existent has the trinity of Beauty, Truth, and Symmetry in itself  , Beauty for order, Truth for purity, and Symmetry for the unity of what is joined together. 
 - HoP 2

Symmetry gives the cause that the existent is unity; Truth, that it is Being; Beauty, that it is thought. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus shows that in each of the three triads, limit, the unlimited, and that which is mingled, are contained; each order is thus the same, but set forth in one of the three forms which constitute the first triad. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus says : Now this is the first triad of all that is thought-the limit, the infinite, and that which is mingled. 
 - HoP 2

The limit is God going forth to the culminating point of thought from the uncommunicable and first God, measuring and determining everything, admitting all that is paternal and coherent, and the unblemished race of gods. 
 - HoP 2

But the infinite   is the inexhaustible potentiality of this God, that which makes all productions and orders to appear, and the whole infinitude, the primeval essence as well as the substantial, and even the ultimate matter. 
 - HoP 2

The first order is thus in its culminating point the abstract substance in which the three determinations as such are shut up without development and maintained in strict isolation; this pure reality is in so far the undisclosed. 
 - HoP 2

This second triad is placed in the determination of the infinite. 
 - HoP 2

As the first unity begets the culminating point of existence, the middle unity begets the middle existence; for it is likewise begetting and self-retaining. 
 - HoP 2

In the second order three moments again appear as before: Here the principle or the first is the substance which was the completion of the first triad; the second, which was there the infinite, is here potentiality. 
 - HoP 2

The unity of both these is Life ,  the centre, or what gives determinateness to the whole order; the second existence is life as thought, for in the most external thought Ideas have their subsistence. 
 - HoP 2

The second order is a triad analogous to the first, for the second is likewise a God. 
 - HoP 2

Limitation determines the first trinity, the unlimited the second, the concrete  the third. 
 - HoP 2

Each determination of unity, the one placed beside the other, also explains the intelligible order of gods; each contains all three moments subordinate to itself, and each is this trinity set forth under one of these moments. 
 - HoP 2

These three orders are the highest gods; later on, we find in Proclus  four orders of gods appearing. 
 - HoP 2

This third triad does not resemble cause , like the first existence, nor does it reveal the all like the second; but it is all as act and expression ; hence it is also the limit of all that is thought. 
 - HoP 2

The first triad remains concealed in limit itself, and has all subsistence of intellectuality fixed in it. 
 - HoP 2

The second is likewise enduring, and at the same time steps forward;  the living appears, but is in so doing led back to unity. 
 - HoP 2

The third after progression shifts and turns the intelligible limit back to the beginning, and bends the order back into itself; for the understanding is the turning back to what is thought  , and the giving of conformity with it. 
 - HoP 2

And all this is one thought, one Idea: persistence, progression and return. 
 - HoP 2

Each is a totality on its own account, but all three are led back into one. 
 - HoP 2

In the Î½Î¿á¿¦Ï the first two triads are themselves only moments; for spirit is just the grasping in itself of the totality of the first two spheres. 
 - HoP 2

In this the mystic element is that these differences which are determined as totalities, as gods, become comprehended as one. 
 - HoP 2

The expression mystic  often appears with the Neo-Platonists. 
 - HoP 2

Thus Proclus for example says : Let us once more obtain initiation into the mysteries  of the one. 
 - HoP 2

Mysticism is just this speculative consideration of Philosophy, this Being in thought, this self-satisfaction and this sensuous perception. 
 - HoP 2

However, Î¼ÏÏÏÎ®ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ has not to the Alexandrians the meaning that it has to us, for to them it indicates speculative philosophy generally. 
 - HoP 2

The mysteries in Christianity have likewise been to the understanding an incomprehensible secret, but because they are speculative, reason comprehends them, and they are not really secret, for they have been revealed. 
 - HoP 2

In conclusion, Proclus institutes a comparison between these triads. 
 - HoP 2

In the first order the concrete is itself substance, in the second it is life, and in the third the thought that is known. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus calls substance likewise á¼ÏÏÎ¯Î±, the fixed, the principle. 
 - HoP 2

These three are thus clearly the absolute one, and this then constitutes one absolute concrete God. 
 - HoP 2

God knows the divided as undivided, what pertains to time as timeless, what is not necessary as necessary, the changeable as unchangeable, and, speaking generally, all things more excellently than in accordance with their order. 
 - HoP 2

Whose are the thoughts, his also are the substances, because the thought of every man is identical with the existence of every man, and each is both the thought and the existence,  and so on. 
 - HoP 2

These are the principal points in the theology of Proclus, and it only remains to us to give some external facts. 
 - HoP 2

The individuality of consciousness is partially in the form of an actuality, as magic and theurgy; this often appears among the Neo-Platonists and with Proclus, and is called making a god. 
 - HoP 2

The element of theurgy is thus brought into relation with the heathen divinities: The first and chief names of the gods, one must admit, are founded in the gods themselves. 
 - HoP 2

Divine thought makes names of its thoughts, and finally shows the images of the gods; each name gives rise, so to speak, to an image of a god. 
 - HoP 2

Thus the statues and pictures of artists show the inward speculative thought, the being replete with the divinity that brings itself into externality; thus the consecration of images is likewise represented. 
 - HoP 2

This connecting fact-that the Neo-Platonists have even inspired the mythical element with the divine-is thereby expressed, so that in images, &c, the divine power is present. 
 - HoP 2

Nevertheless I have only wished to call this moment to mind because it plays a great part at this particular time. 
 - HoP 2

In Proclus we have the culminating point of the Neo-Platonic philosophy; this method in philosophy is carried into later times, continuing even through the whole of the Middle Ages. 
 - HoP 2

Proclus had several successors who were scholarchs at Athens-Marinus, his biographer, and then Isidorus of Gaza, and finally Damascius. 
 - HoP 2

Of the latter we still possess some very interesting writings; he was the last teacher of the Neo-Platonic philosophy in the Academy. 
 - HoP 2

They sought and found protection and freedom in Persia under ChosroÃ¯s. 
 - HoP 2

After some time they ventured to return to the Roman Empire, but they could no longer form any school at Athens; thus as far as its external existence is concerned, the heathen philosophy went utterly to ruin. 
 - HoP 2

Eunapius treats of this last period, and Cousin has dealt with it in a short treatise. 
 - HoP 2

A particular description of Arabian philosophy has in some parts but little interest; in other parts it will be found that the main dogmas of this philosophy have much in common with those of the Scholastics. 
 - HoP 3

We may say of the Arabians that their philosophy constitutes no characteristic stage in the development of philosophy.

The Medabberim are specially mentioned by Moses Maimonides as a widely extended philosophic school or sect of considerable eminence. 
 - HoP 3

They insisted on that, and that alone, which concurred with their opinions, even though it were in the most remote degree, through a hundred links of reasoning. 
 - HoP 3

The earliest of their learned men adopted this practice, though professing that they reached these reflections through speculation alone, without reference to any preconceived opinion. 
 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

Besides this they in the majority of instances confound imagination with understanding, and give to the former the name of the latter. 
 - HoP 3

They adopted as a principle, atoms and empty space,  where all connection appears as something contingent. 
 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

In this way nothing but the atom really exists. 
 - HoP 3

They have thus in the more advanced cultivation of thought brought to consciousness the main standpoint, then as now the standpoint of the Orientals-that of substance, the one substance. 
 - HoP 3

This pantheism, or Spinozism, if you like to call it so, is thus the universal view of Oriental poets, historians and philosophers. 
 - HoP 3

The Medabberim go on to say: Substances, ie individuals, which,  for the rest, are created by God, have many accidental qualities, as in snow every particle is white. 
 - HoP 3

But no quality can endure for two moments; as it comes, it goes again, and God creates another and yet another in its place. 
 - HoP 3

All determinations are thus fleeting or perishable; the individual alone is permanent. 
 - HoP 3

If it pleases God to create another quality in a substance, it continues; but if He ceases to create, the substance perishes. 
 - HoP 3

Thereby all necessary connection is done away with, so that Nature has no meaning. 
 - HoP 3

They therefore deny that anything exists by nature, likewise that the nature of this or that body necessitates that it should have certain qualities rather than others. 
 - HoP 3

But they say that God creates all qualities instantaneously, without natural means and without the help of anything else. 
 - HoP 3

General permanence is substance, and the particular is altered every moment, and so exists through the substance. 
 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

In this way God alone is in truth the operative cause; but He might have made everything differently.

Their eighth proposition is to the effect that nothing but substance or accident exists, and natural forms are themselves accidents; substances alone are individuals. 
 - HoP 3

The ninth proposition is that accidents have nothing to do with one another; they have no causal connection or other relation; in every substance all accidents may exist. 
 - HoP 3

The tenth proposition is transition :  All that we can fancy may also pass over into the understanding, ie be possible. 
 - HoP 3

But in this way everything is possible,  since there are no laws of the understanding; this transition of thought is thus perfectly accidental. 
 - HoP 3

A man as large as a mountain, a flea as large as an elephant, are possible.

Everything may just as well be something else as what it is, and there is no reason at all why anything should be one way rather than another.

 - HoP 3

We thus see an utter inconstancy of everything; and this whirl of all things is essentially Oriental.

But at the same time this is certainly also a complete dissolution of all that pertains to reasonableness, in harmony of course with Eastern exaltation of spirit, which allows of nothing definite. 
 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

Many of these commentaries are still extant.

We find in these Jewish philosophers proofs brought forward that God is One, that the world was created, and that matter is not eternal; Maimonides also speaks of the nature of God.

The unity of God is dealt with as it was among the ancient Eleatics and the Neo-Platonists; to prove, namely, that not the Many, but the self-begetting and self-abrogating One is the truth. 
 - HoP 3

These were the first make-shifts or expedients for carrying on Philosophy; in them the most external and most formal reasoning is applied. 
 - HoP 3

The whole effect of the scholastic philosophy is a monotonous one. 
 - HoP 3

In vain have men hitherto endeavoured to show in this theology, which reigned from the eighth or even sixth century almost to the sixteenth, particular distinctions and stages in development. 
 - HoP 3

It is not interesting by reason of its matter, for we cannot remain at the consideration of this; it is not a philosophy. 
 - HoP 3

The name, however, properly speaking indicates a general manner rather than a system-if we may speak of a philosophic system. 
 - HoP 3

Scholasticism is not a fixed doctrine like Platonism or Scepticism, but a very indefinite name which comprehends the philosophic endeavours of Christendom for the greater part of a thousand years.

The more general acceptance of the Aristotelian writings has merely brought forth a difference of degree and caused no real scientific progress. 
 - HoP 3

Here there is indeed a history of men, but speaking properly none of scientific knowledge; the men are noble, pious, and in all respects most distinguished. 
 - HoP 3

The study of the scholastic philosophy is a difficult one, even if its language only be considered. 
 - HoP 3

The Scholastics certainly make use of a barbaric Latin, but this is not the fault of the Scholastics but of their Latin culture. 
 - HoP 3

It cannot be expected of anyone to know at first hand this philosophy of the Middle Ages, for it is as comprehensive and voluminous as it is barren and ill-expressed. 
 - HoP 3

Abstracts of them are to be found in various works.

We shall limit ourselves to general points of view. 
 - HoP 3

The name finds its origin in this way. 
 - HoP 3

In the monasteries he who was the most advanced instructed the monks. 
 - HoP 3

In place of the patres ecclesiÃ¦ there thus arose later on the doctores. 
 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

All these matters, however, do not pertain to the nature of God and its relation to mankind. 
 - HoP 3

The one essential object of theology as the doctrine of God, is the nature of God, and this content is in its nature really speculative; those theologians who consider this are therefore nothing less than philosophers. 
 - HoP 3

The science of God is nothing but Philosophy. 
 - HoP 3

Down to the Middle Ages, on the contrary, it was held as fundamental that there should be but one truth. 
 - HoP 3

Their philosophy, and much in them that is excellent, is found in Aristotle, only in a simpler and purer form; and to them too the whole lay beyond actuality and mingled with Christian actuality as it is represented to us. 
 - HoP 3

From Christianity, within whose bounds we now have our place, Philosophy has to re-establish its position. 
 - HoP 3

In heathendom the root of knowledge was external nature as thought devoid of self, and subjective nature as the inward self. 
 - HoP 3

Both Nature and the natural self of mankind, and likewise thought, there possessed affirmative significance; hence all this was good. 
 - HoP 3

In Christianity the root of truth has, however, quite another meaning; it was not only the truth as against the heathen gods, but as against Philosophy also, against nature, against the immediate consciousness of man. 
 - HoP 3

Nature is there no longer good, but merely a negative; self-consciousness, the thought of man, his pure self, all this receives a negative position in Christianity. 
 - HoP 3

Nature has no validity, and affords no interest; its universal laws, as the reality under which the individual existences of nature are collected, have likewise no authority: the heavens, the sun, the whole of nature is a corpse. 
 - HoP 3

Nature is given over to the spiritual, and indeed to spiritual subjectivity; thus the course of nature is everywhere broken in upon by miracles. 
 - HoP 3

With this surrender of natural necessity we have the fact associated that all further content, all that truth which constitutes the universal of that nature, is given and revealed. 
 - HoP 3

The one starting-point, the contemplation of nature, is thus for knowledge undoubtedly not present. 
 - HoP 3

Then this fact is likewise set aside that I am present as a self. 
 - HoP 3

The self as this immediate certainty has to be abrogated; it must also merge itself in another self, but in one beyond, and only there does it have its value. 
 - HoP 3

A real sense of self is thus abandoned, but what self-consciousness on the other hand gains is not a universal, a thought. 
 - HoP 3

In thought I have real affirmative significance, not as an individual, but as universal I; the content of truth is now, however, plainly individualized, and thus the thought of the I falls away. 
 - HoP 3

This absolute is itself this first of all as this concrete, not as abstraction, but as the unity of universal and individual; this concrete consciousness is for the first time truth. 
 - HoP 3

The reason of the former content being also true, comes to me as something not pertaining to myself, but as a thing received outside of self. 
 - HoP 3

The Spirit which bears witness is further itself distinguished from me as an individual; my testifying spirit is another, and there only remains to me the empty shell of passivity. 
 - HoP 3

Conditioned by this inflexible standpoint, Philosophy had to go forth once more. 
 - HoP 3

The first working up of this content, the inward operation of universal thought in the same, is the task scholastic philosophy has to undertake. 
 - HoP 3

We must now speak of the methods and manners of the scholastics. 
 - HoP 3

In this scholastic activity thought pursues its work quite apart from all regard to experience; we no longer hear anything of taking up actuality and determining it through thought. 
 - HoP 3

Still less, in the second place, was the greater part of the content permeated by Notions, for this content was taken up superficially into the form of thought-more especially with the Stoics and Epicureans. 
 - HoP 3

The scholastic philosophy altogether dissociates itself from any such endeavours; it leaves actuality to exist alongside itself as if it were despised and had no interest. 
 - HoP 3

For reason found its true existence, its actualization, in another world and not in this; the whole progress of the cultivated world goes, however, to the re-instalment of a faith in the present world. 
 - HoP 3

Nevertheless, at first all knowledge and action, and whatever relates to an interest in this world, were entirely banished. 
 - HoP 3

Likewise law and right, the recognition of the actual man, were not esteemed as pertaining to the social relationships of life, but to some other sphere. 
 - HoP 3

Now thought as sundered has a content, the intelligible world, as an actuality existent for itself, to which thought applies itself. 
 - HoP 3

The scholastics are thus decried on account of the endless distinctions which they draw. 
 - HoP 3

For the sake of these determinations through the abstract Notion the Aristotelian philosophy was predominant, though not in its whole extent. 
 - HoP 3

It was the Aristotelian Organon that was held in such favour, and that indeed just as much for its laws of thought as for its metaphysical conceptions-the categories. 
 - HoP 3

These abstract Notions constituted in their determinateness the understanding of the scholastic philosophy, which could not pass beyond itself and attain to freedom, nor seize upon the freedom given by reason. 
 - HoP 3

With this finite form a finite content is likewise directly associated. 
 - HoP 3

From one determination we pass on to another, and such determinations, as particular, are finite; the determination there relates itself externally and not as self-comprehensive and self-embracing. 
 - HoP 3

The result of this determination is that thought will really act as if it brought about conclusions, for to draw conclusions is the mode of formal logical progression. 
 - HoP 3

Philosophy thus consists of a methodical and syllogistic reasoning. 
 - HoP 3

Just as the Sophists of Greece wandered about amongst abstract conceptions on behalf of actuality, so did the scholastics on behalf of their intellectual world. 
 - HoP 3

To the former Being had validity; it they had rescued and delivered as against the negativity of the Notion, while along with that they had justified it through the same. 
 - HoP 3

The principal endeavour of the scholastics was in the same way to vindicate the Christian intellectual world as against the confusion of the Notion, and through the latter to demonstrate its conformity with the same. 
 - HoP 3

The universal form of the scholastic philosophy thus consisted in this-that a proposition was laid down, the objections to it brought forward, and these contradicted through counter-propositions and distinctions. 
 - HoP 3

Philosophy was hence not separated from theology, as it is not in itself, for Philosophy is the knowledge of absolute existence, that is to say, theology. 
 - HoP 3

But to that theology the Christian absolute world was a system which was held to be an actuality, as was ordinary actuality for the Greek sophists. 
 - HoP 3

Of Philosophy proper there thus remained only the laws of thought and abstractions. 
 - HoP 3

Philosophy with the scholastics had consequently the same quality of want of independence as it had before this with the Christian Fathers and the Arabians. 
 - HoP 3

The Church as already constituted established itself amongst the Teutonic nations, and through its constitution it conditioned philosophy. 
 - HoP 3

But the Church in time became dominant, and the Roman emperors, both of the East and of the West, embraced Christianity. 
 - HoP 3

Thus the Church attained to a position openly recognized and undisturbed, from which it exercised much influence upon the world. 
 - HoP 3

The political world, however, fell into the hands of the Teutonic nations, and thereby a new form arose, and to this the scholastic philosophy pertains. 
 - HoP 3

We know the revolution by the name of the Migration of the Nations. 
 - HoP 3

Fresh races inundated the ancient Roman world and established themselves therein; they thus erected their new world on the ruins of the old-a picture which Rome in its present aspect still presents. 
 - HoP 3

There the splendour of the Christian temples is due in part to the remnants of the ancient, and new palaces are built on ruins and have ruins all around. 
 - HoP 3

The principal feature in the Middle Ages is found in this disunion, the two sides here present; there are revealed in it two nations, two manners of speech. 
 - HoP 3

Hence these people have in this way represented in themselves the nature of the spiritual process. 
 - HoP 3

Hence in the Roman as in the Byzantine world, Christianity has triumphed as a Church; but neither of these worlds was capable of effectuating the new religion in itself and of bringing forth a new world from this principle. 
 - HoP 3

For in both there was a character already present-customs, laws, a juridical system, a constitution , a political condition, capacities, art, science, spiritual culture-in short, everything was there. 
 - HoP 3

These conquerors have thus established themselves in a foreign sphere, and have become the rulers over it; but at the same time they have come under the dominion of a new spirit which has been imposed upon them. 
 - HoP 3

Although on the one hand predominant, on the other they have come under the dominion of the spiritual element, because they conducted themselves passively in regard to it.

The spiritual Idea or spirituality has become imposed upon the dulness, both in mind and spirit, of these rough barbarians; their hearts were thereby pricked.

The rough nature has in this way become immanent in the Idea as an eternal opposition, or there is kindled in them infinite pain, the most terrible suffering-such that it may even be represented as a crucified Christ.

They had to sustain this conflict within themselves, and one side of it is found in the philosophy which later on made its appearance amongst them, and was first of all received as something given.

Culture here begins from the most terrible contradiction, and this has to be by it resolved.

The dominion that exists must take up this position, that spirit is in subjective spirit in harmony with itself.

And hence the consequent development is only this, that mind as reconciliation attains the mastery.

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

But this severe and wearisome service has an end, an object; infinite spring and infinite elasticity, the freedom of spirit, is the prize. 
 - HoP 3

Knowledge is thus limited to the Church, but in this very knowledge a positive authority is firmly rooted, and it is a prominent feature of this philosophy, whose first quality is consequently that of lack of freedom.

In theological form it may be said that, in general, the Middle Ages signify the dominion of the Son and not of Spirit; for this last is still in the possession of the priesthood. 
 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

Of this one side is that the Idea is grasped by the heart, if we call the individual man the heart.

The Cartesian substance, as Idea, has certainly Being included in its Notion; but it is only Being as abstract, not as real Being or as extension.
