With Descartes corporeality and the thinking I are altogether independent Beings; this independence of the two extremes is done away with in Spinozism by their becoming moments of the one absolute Being. 
 - HoP 3

This expression signifies that Being must be grasped as the unity of opposites; the chief consideration is not to let slip the opposition and set it aside, but to reconcile and resolve it. 
 - HoP 3

The pure thought of Spinoza is therefore not the simple universal of Plato, for it has likewise come to know the absolute opposition of Notion and Being. 
 - HoP 3

Taken as a whole, this constitutes the Idea of Spinoza, and it is just what Ïá½¸ á½Î½ was to the Eleatics. 
 - HoP 3

It is therefore worthy of note that thought must begin by placing itself at the standpoint of Spinozism; to be a follower of Spinoza is the essential commencement of all Philosophy. 
 - HoP 3

The difference between our standpoint and that of the Eleatic philosophy is only this, that through the agency of Christianity concrete individuality is in the modern world present throughout in spirit. 
 - HoP 3

But in spite of the infinite demands on the part of the concrete, substance with Spinoza is not yet determined as in itself concrete. 
 - HoP 3

As the concrete is thus not present in the content of substance, it is therefore to be found within reflecting thought alone, and it is only from the endless oppositions of this last that the required unity emerges. 
 - HoP 3

Of substance as such there is nothing more to be said; all that we can do is to speak of the different ways in which Philosophy has dealt with it, and the opposites which in it are abrogated. 
 - HoP 3

The difference depends on the nature of the opposites which are held to be abrogated in substance. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza begins  with a series of definitions, from which we take the following. 
 - HoP 3

Spinozas first definition is of the Cause of itself. 
 - HoP 3

He says: By that which is causa sui, its own cause, I understand that whose essence   involves existence, or which cannot be conceived except as existent. 
 - HoP 3

The unity of existence and universal thought is asserted from the very first, and this unity will ever be the question at issue. 
 - HoP 3

The establishing of itself as an other is loss or degeneration, and at the same time the negation of this loss; this is a purely speculative Notion, indeed a fundamental Notion in all speculation. 
 - HoP 3

The cause in which the cause is identical with the effect, is the infinite cause ; if Spinoza had further developed what lies in the causa sui, substance with him would not have been rigid and unworkable. 
 - HoP 3

The second definition is that of the finite. 
 - HoP 3

That thing is said to be finite in its kind which can be limited by another of the same nature,  For it comes then to an end, it is not there; what is there is something else. 
 - HoP 3

That is the affirmative side of the limit. 
 - HoP 3

Thus a thought is  only limited by another thought, a body by another body, but thoughts are not limited by bodies nor  conversely bodies by thoughts. 
 - HoP 3

We saw this  with Descartes: thought is an independent totality and so is extension, they have nothing to do with one another; they do not limit each other, each is included in itself. 
 - HoP 3

The third definition is that of substance. 
 - HoP 3

What cannot have a conception formed of it without the aid of something else, is not independent, but is dependent upon that something else. 
 - HoP 3

In the fourth place Spinoza defines attributes, which, as the moment coming second to substance, belong to it. 
 - HoP 3

By attribute I understand that which the mind perceives as constituting the essence of substance;  and to Spinoza this alone is true. 
 - HoP 3

This is an important determination; the attribute is undoubtedly a determinateness, but at the same time it remains a totality. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza, like Descartes, accepts only two attributes, thought and extension. 
 - HoP 3

The understanding grasps them as the reality of substance, but the reality is not higher than the substance, for it is only reality in the view of the understanding, which falls outside substance. 
 - HoP 3

This is the true completion; but where substance passes over into attribute is not stated. 
 - HoP 3

The fifth definition has to do with what comes third in relation to substance, the mode. 
 - HoP 3

By mode I understand the affections of substance, or that which is in something else, through the aid of which also it is conceived. 
 - HoP 3

The mode is the individual, the finite as such, which enters into external connection with what is other. 
 - HoP 3

In this Spinoza only descends to a lower stage, the mode is only the foregoing warped and stunted. 
 - HoP 3

Spinozas defect is therefore this, that he takes the third moment as mode alone, as a false individuality. 
 - HoP 3

True individuality and subjectivity is not a mere retreat from the universal, not merely something clearly determinate; for, as clearly determinate, it is at the same time Being-for-itself, determined by itself alone. 
 - HoP 3

The individual, the subjective, is even in being so the return to the universal; and in that it is at home with itself, it is itself the universal. 
 - HoP 3

The return consists simply and solely in the fact of the particular being in itself the universal; to this return Spinoza did not attain. 
 - HoP 3

Rigid substantiality is the last point he reached, not infinite form; this he knew not, and thus determinateness continually vanishes from his thought. 
 - HoP 3

In the sixth place, the definition of the infinite is also of importance, for in the infinite Spinoza defines more strictly than anywhere else the Notion of the Notion. 
 - HoP 3

The infinite has a double significance, according as it is taken as the infinitely many or as the absolutely infinite. 
 - HoP 3

The infinite in its kind is not such in respect of all possible attributes; but the absolutely infinite is that to whose essence all belongs that expresses an essence and contains no negation. 
 - HoP 3

In the same sense Spinoza distinguishes in the nine-and-twentieth Letter  the infinite of imagination from the infinite of thought , the actual  infinite. 
 - HoP 3

An infinite numerical series in mathematics is exactly the same thing. 
 - HoP 3

If a certain fraction is represented as a decimal fraction, it is incomplete; â is, on the contrary, the true infinite, and therefore not an incomplete expression, although the content here is of course limited. 
 - HoP 3

It is infinity in the incorrect sense that one usually has in view when infinity is spoken of; and even if it is looked on as sublime, it yet is nothing present, and only goes ever out into the negative, without being actual. 
 - HoP 3

Philosophic infinity, that which is infinite actu, Spinoza therefore calls the absolute affirmation of itself. 
 - HoP 3

This is quite correct, only it might have been better expressed as: It is the negation of negation. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza here also employs geometrical figures as illustrations of the Notion of infinity. 
 - HoP 3

In his Opera postuma, preceding his Ethics, and also in the letter quoted above, he has two circles, one of which lies within the other, which have not, however, a common centre. 
 - HoP 3

Illustration  The inequalities of the space between A B and C D exceed every number; and yet the space which lies between is not so very great. 
 - HoP 3

That is to say, if I wish to determine them all, I must enter upon an infinite series. 
 - HoP 3

Or a finite line consists of an infinite number of points; and yet the line is present here and determined; the beyond  of the infinite number of points, which are not complete, is in it complete and called back into unity. 
 - HoP 3

The infinite should be represented as actually present, and this comes to pass in the Notion of the cause of itself, which is therefore the true infinity. 
 - HoP 3

As soon as the cause has something else opposed to it-the effect-finitude is present; but here this something else is at the same time abrogated and it becomes once more the cause itself. 
 - HoP 3

The affirmative is thus negation of negation, since, according to the well-known grammatical rule, duplex negatio affirmat. 
 - HoP 3

In the same way Spinozas earlier definitions have also the infinite already implied in them, for instance in the case of the just mentioned cause of itself, inasmuch as he defines it as that whose essence involves existence. 
 - HoP 3

Notion and existence are each the Beyond of the other; but cause of itself, as thus including them, is really the carrying back of this beyond  into unity. 
 - HoP 3

Or  Substance is that which is in itself and is conceived from itself;  that is the same unity of Notion and existence. 
 - HoP 3

The infinite is in the same way in itself and has also its Notion in itself; its Notion is its Being, and its Being its Notion; true infinity is therefore to be found in Spinoza. 
 - HoP 3

Finally Spinoza says in the seventh place: God is a Being absolutely infinite, ie a substance consisting of infinite attributes, each of which expresses an eternal and infinite essence. 
 - HoP 3

The whole of Spinozas philosophy is contained in these definitions, which, however, taken as a whole are formal; it is really a weak point in Spinoza that he begins thus with definitions. 
 - HoP 3

In mathematics this method is permitted, because at the outset we there make assumptions, such as that of the point and line; but in Philosophy the content should be known as the absolutely true. 
 - HoP 3

Such a question is not asked in the case of geometrical propositions, but in philosophic investigation it is the very thing to be first considered, and this Spinoza has not done. 
 - HoP 3

Instead of only explaining these simple thoughts and representing them as concrete in the definitions which he makes, what he ought to have done was to examine whether this content is true. 
 - HoP 3

To all appearance it is only the explanation of the words that is given; but the content of the words is held to be established. 
 - HoP 3

All further content is merely derived from that, and proved thereby; for on the first content all the rest depends, and if it is established as a basis, the other necessarily follows. 
 - HoP 3

The attribute is that which the understanding thinks of God. 
 - HoP 3

These definitions are followed by axioms and propositions in which Spinoza proves a great variety of points. 
 - HoP 3

He descends from the universal of substance through the particular, thought and extension, to the individual. 
 - HoP 3

He has thus all three moments of the Notion, or they are essential to him. 
 - HoP 3

But the mode, under which head falls individuality, he does not recognize as essential, or as constituting a moment of true existence in that existence; for it disappears in existence, or it is not raised into the Notion. 
 - HoP 3

The main point then is that Spinoza proves from these Notions that there is only One Substance, God. 
 - HoP 3

It is a simple chain of reasoning, a very formal proof. 
 - HoP 3

Fifth Proposition: There cannot be two or more substances of the same nature or of the same attribute. 
 - HoP 3

This is implied already in the definitions; the proof is therefore a useless and wearisome toil, which only serves to render Spinoza more difficult to understand. 
 - HoP 3

If there were several   they must be distinguished from one another either by the diversity of their attributes or by the diversity of their affections. 
 - HoP 3

If they are distinguished by their attributes, it would be directly conceded that there is only one substance having the same attribute. 
 - HoP 3

For the attributes are simply what the understanding grasps as the essence of the one substance, which is determined in itself, and not through anything else. 
 - HoP 3

Eighth Proposition: All substance is necessarily infinite. 
 - HoP 3

Proof: For otherwise it must be limited by another substance of the same nature, in which case there would be two substances of the same attribute, which is contrary to the fifth proposition. 
 - HoP 3

Every attribute must be conceived for itself,  as determination reflected on itself. 
 - HoP 3

For attribute is what the mind conceives of substance as constituting its essence, from which it follows that it must be conceived through itself,  ie substance is what is conceived through itself. 
 - HoP 3

Substance is indivisible. 
 - HoP 3

For if the parts retained the nature of the substance, there would be several substances of the same nature, which is contrary to the fifth proposition. 
 - HoP 3

If not, infinite substance would cease to exist, which is absurd. 
 - HoP 3

Consequently the substance would not have its own being, but that of God, and therefore would not be a substance. 
 - HoP 3

Or if it were still to be substance, then there would necessarily follow the possibility of there being two substances with the same attribute, which according to the fifth proposition is absurd. 
 - HoP 3

From this it then follows that the thing extended and the thing that thinks  are not substances, but are either attributes of God, or affections of His attributes. 
 - HoP 3

By these proofs and others like them not much is to be gained. 
 - HoP 3

Fifteenth, proposition: What is, is in God, and cannot exist or be conceived without God. 
 - HoP 3

Sixteenth proposition: By the necessity of the divine nature infinite things must follow in infinite modes, ie, all that can fall under the infinite understanding. 
 - HoP 3

God is therefore the absolute First Cause. 
 - HoP 3

There is no cause which inwardly or outwardly moves Him to act, except the perfection of His nature. 
 - HoP 3

That is to say, His Being is His absolute power; actus and potentia, Thought and Being, are in Him one. 
 - HoP 3

God has not therefore any other thoughts which He could not have actualized. 
 - HoP 3

God is the immanent cause of all things, not the transient ,  ie, external cause. 
 - HoP 3

His essence and His existence are the same, namely, the truth. 
 - HoP 3

A thing which is determined to perform some action, is, since God is cause, necessarily determined thereto by God; and a thing which is thus determined cannot render itself undetermined. 
 - HoP 3

In nature nothing is contingent. 
 - HoP 3

Will is not a free cause, but only a necessary cause, only a mode; it is therefore determined by another. 
 - HoP 3

God acts in accordance with no final causes. 
 - HoP 3

Those who assert that He does so, appear to establish something apart from God, which does not depend on God, and which God in His working keeps in view, as though it were an end. 
 - HoP 3

If this view is taken, God is not a free cause, but is subject to fate. 
 - HoP 3

It is equally inadmissible to subject all things to the arbitrary pleasure of God, ie, to His indifferent will. 
 - HoP 3

He is then absolute power in contrast to wisdom, which sets up definite aims, and consequently limitations; particular aims, thoughts of what is about to come to pass, and the like are therefore put out of the question. 
 - HoP 3

But beyond this universal, no advance is made; for it must be noticed as specially singular, that Spinoza in the fiftieth Letter  says that every determination is a negation. 
 - HoP 3

Moreover, if God is the cause of the world, it is implied that He is finite; for the world is here put beside God as something different from Him. 
 - HoP 3

The greatest difficulty in Spinoza is, in the distinctions to which he comes, to grasp the relation of this determinate to God, at the same time preserving the determination. 
 - HoP 3

God is an extended Being for the same reason. 
 - HoP 3

This means that the same substance, under the attribute of thought, is the intelligible world, and under the attribute of extension, is nature; nature and thought thus both express the same Essence of God. 
 - HoP 3

Or, as Spinoza says, The order and system of natural things is the same as the order of the thoughts. 
 - HoP 3

Thus, for instance, the circle which exists in nature, and the idea of the existing circle, which is also in God, are one and the same thing  , which is  merely expressed by means of different attributes. 
 - HoP 3

If we therefore regard nature either under the attribute of extension or of thought, or under any other attribute whatever, we shall find one and the same connection of causes, ie, the same sequence of things. 
 - HoP 3

But Spinoza does not demonstrate how these two are evolved from the one substance, nor does he prove why there can only be two of them. 
 - HoP 3

The differences are not in themselves, but the different aspects from which the Absolute is regarded are matters external to it. 
 - HoP 3

We take a higher tone in saying that nature and mind are rational; but reason is for us no empty word, for it means the totality which develops itself within itself. 
 - HoP 3

Again, it is the standpoint of reflection to regard aspects only, and nothing in itself. 
 - HoP 3

Absolute substance, attribute and mode, Spinoza allows to follow one another as definitions, he adopts them ready-made, without the attributes being developed from the substance, or the modes from the attributes. 
 - HoP 3

And more especially in regard to the attributes, there is no necessity evident, why these are thought and extension in particular. 
 - HoP 3

Of the modes he says : In every attribute there are two modes; in extension, these are rest and motion, in thought they are understanding and will. 
 - HoP 3

They are mere modifications which only exist for us apart from God; therefore whatever refers to this difference and is specially brought about by it, is not absolute, but finite. 
 - HoP 3

From God proceeds nothing, for all things merely return to the point whence they came, if from themselves the commencement is made. 
 - HoP 3

These then are Spinozas general forms, this is his principal idea. 
 - HoP 3

Some further determinations have still to be mentioned. 
 - HoP 3

He gives definitions of the terms modes, understanding, will, and of the affections, such as joy and sadness. 
 - HoP 3

Its development is extremely simple, or rather it is not developed at all; Spinoza begins directly with mind. 
 - HoP 3

The essence of man consists of certain modifications of the attributes of God ; these modifications are only something related to our understanding. 
 - HoP 3

If we, therefore, say that the human mind perceives this or that, it means nothing else than that God has this or that idea, not in so far as He is infinite, but in so far as He is expressed by the idea of the human mind. 
 - HoP 3

Truth is for Spinoza, on the other hand, the adequate. 
 - HoP 3

The object of the idea which constitutes the human mind is body, or a certain mode of extension. 
 - HoP 3

If, then, the object of the idea which constitutes the human mind, is the body, there can happen nothing in the body which is not perceived by the mind. 
 - HoP 3

Otherwise the ideas of the affections of the body would not be in God, in so far as He constitutes our mind, but the idea of another thing: that is to say, the ideas of the affections of our body would not be likewise in our mind. 
 - HoP 3

Mind knows itself only in so far as it perceives the ideas of the affections of body,  it has only the idea of the affections of its body; this idea is synthetic combination, as we shall immediately see. 
 - HoP 3

The ideas, whether of the attributes of God or of individual things, do not recognize as their efficient cause their objects themselves, or the things perceived, but God Himself, in so far as He is that which thinks. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza, however, also accepts both in their separation from one another. 
 - HoP 3

The idea of body, he writes , includes only these two in itself, and does not express any other attributes. 
 - HoP 3

The body which it represents is regarded under the attribute of extension; but the idea itself is a mode of thought. 
 - HoP 3

Here we see a dividing asunder; mere identity, the undistinguishable nature of all things in the Absolute, is insufficient even for Spinoza. 
 - HoP 3

Here we are at the extreme limit of Spinozas system, and it is here that his weak point appears. 
 - HoP 3

Individuation, the one, is a mere synthesis; it is quite a different thing from the Ichts or self-hood of Boehme , since Spinoza has only universality, thought, and not self-consciousness. 
 - HoP 3

If, before considering this in reference to the whole, we take it from the other side, namely from the understanding, the distinction really falls under that head; it is not deduced, it is found. 
 - HoP 3

Thus, as we have already seen  the understanding in act , as also will, desire, love, must be referred to natura naturata, not to natura naturans. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza is unacquainted with an infinity of form, which would be something quite different from that of rigid, unyielding substance. 
 - HoP 3

What is requisite is to recognize God as the essence of essences, as universal substance, identity, and yet to preserve distinctions. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza goes on to say: What constitutes the real  existence of the human mind is nothing else than the idea of a particular   thing, that actually exists,  not of an infinite thing. 
 - HoP 3

The essence of man involves no necessary existence, ie according to the order of nature a man may just as well be as not be. 
 - HoP 3

For the human consciousness, as it does not belong to essence as an attribute, is a mode-a mode of the attribute of thought. 
 - HoP 3

The body can neither determine the mind to thought, nor can the mind determine the body to motion, or rest, or anything else. 
 - HoP 3

For all modes of thought have God as Cause, in so far as He is a thinking thing, and not in so far as He is revealed by means of another attribute. 
 - HoP 3

What therefore determines the mind to thought, is a mode of thought and not of extension; similarly motion and rest of the body must be derived from another body. 
 - HoP 3

If, therefore, the body can perceive no qualities of a thing, the soul also can come to no knowledge of it. 
 - HoP 3

The souls consciousness expresses a certain determinate form of a Notion, as the Notion itself expresses a determinate form of an individual thing. 
 - HoP 3

But the individual thing, its Notion, and the Notion of this Notion are altogether and entirely one and the same thing, only regarded under different attributes. 
 - HoP 3

As the soul is nothing else than the immediate Notion of the body, and is one and the same thing with this, the excellence of the soul can never be anything else than the excellence of the body. 
 - HoP 3

The capacities of the understanding are nothing but the capacities of the body, if they are looked at from the corporeal point of view, and the decisions of the will are likewise determinations of the body. 
 - HoP 3

We have now to speak of Spinozas system of morals, and that is a subject of importance. 
 - HoP 3

Its great principle is no other than this, that the finite spirit is moral in so far as it has the true Idea, ie in so far as it directs its knowledge and will on God, for truth is merely the knowledge of God. 
 - HoP 3

It may be said that there is no morality loftier than this, since its only requisite is to have a clear idea of God. 
 - HoP 3

The first thing Spinoza speaks of in this regard is the affections: Everything strives after self-preservation. 
 - HoP 3

This striving is the actual essence of the thing, and involves only indefinite time; when referred exclusively to mind, it is termed will; when referred to both mind and body together, it is called desire. 
 - HoP 3

Determination of the will  and Idea are one and the same thing. 
 - HoP 3

The sense of liberty rests on this, that men do not know the determining causes of their actions. 
 - HoP 3

The affection is a confused idea; the more clearly and distinctly, therefore, we know the affection, the more it is under our control. 
 - HoP 3

The more a man recognizes Gods existence and loves Him, the less does he suffer from evil affections and the less is his fear of death. 
 - HoP 3

The second kind of knowledge is for Spinoza that which we derive from general conceptions and adequate ideas of the properties of things. 
 - HoP 3

The third is intuitive knowledge  which rises from the adequate idea of the formal essence of certain attributes of God to the adequate knowledge of the essence of things. 
 - HoP 3

For the necessity of things is the necessity of the eternal nature of God Himself. 
 - HoP 3

Every idea of an individual thing necessarily includes the eternal and infinite essence of God in itself. 
 - HoP 3

For individual things are modes of an attribute of God; therefore they must include in themselves His eternal essence. 
 - HoP 3

Our mind, in so far as it knows itself and the body under the form of eternity, has to that extent necessarily the knowledge of God, and knows that it is itself in God and is conceived through God. 
 - HoP 3

All Ideas, in so far as they are referable to God, are true. 
 - HoP 3

With Spinoza this is not a knowledge arrived at through philosophy, but only knowledge of a truth. 
 - HoP 3

The mind can succeed in tracing back all affections of the body or images of things to God. 
 - HoP 3

In proportion as the mind regards all things as necessary, it has a greater power over its affections,  which are arbitrary and contingent. 
 - HoP 3

This is the return of the mind to God, and this is human freedom; as mode, on the other hand, the spirit has no freedom, but is determined from without. 
 - HoP 3

From the third kind of knowledge there arises the repose of the mind; the supreme good of the mind is to know God, and this is its highest virtue. 
 - HoP 3

This knowledge necessarily produces the intellectual love of God; for it produces a joyfulness accompanied by the Idea of God as cause-ie the intellectual love of God. 
 - HoP 3

God Himself loves Himself with an infinite intellectual love. 
 - HoP 3

This is therefore the purest, but also a universal morality. 
 - HoP 3

In the thirty-sixth Letter  Spinoza speaks of Evil. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza says in answer to this: I assert the fact that God absolutely and truly   is the cause of everything that has an essential content   be it what it may. 
 - HoP 3

Now if you can prove to me that evil, error, crime, etc, are something that expresses an essence, I will freely admit to you that God is the originator of crime and evil and error. 
 - HoP 3

But I have elsewhere abundantly demonstrated that the form of evil cannot subsist in anything that expresses an essence, and therefore it cannot be said that God is the cause of evil. 
 - HoP 3

Evil is merely negation, privation, limitation, finality, mode-nothing in itself truly real. 
 - HoP 3

Neros murder of his mother, in so far as it had positive content, was no crime. 
 - HoP 3

For Orestes did the same external deed, and had in doing it the same end in view-to kill his mother; and yet he is not blamed,  and so on. 
 - HoP 3

The affirmative is the will, the intention, the act of Nero. 
 - HoP 3

Wherein then consists Neros criminality? In nothing else but that he proved himself ungrateful, merciless, and disobedient. 
 - HoP 3

But it is certain that all this expresses no essence, and therefore God was not the cause of it, though He was the cause of Neros action and intention. 
 - HoP 3

These last are something positive, but yet they do not constitute the crime as such; it is only the negative element, such as mercilessness, etc that makes the action a crime. 
 - HoP 3

It is all very well to say this, but it does not meet the case. 
 - HoP 3

For in this way God and the respect to our understanding are different. 
 - HoP 3

But in this philosophy it may with justice be objected that God is conceived only as Substance, and not as Spirit, as concrete. 
 - HoP 3

The independence of the human soul is therein also denied, while in the Christian religion every individual appears as determined to salvation. 
 - HoP 3

Here, on the contrary, the individual spirit is only a mode, an accident, but not anything substantial. 
 - HoP 3

This brings us to a general criticism of the philosophy of Spinoza, in the course of which we shall consider it from three different points of view. 
 - HoP 3

Those who speak against Spinoza do so as if it were on Gods account that they were interested; but what these opponents are really concerned about is not God, but the finite-themselves. 
 - HoP 3

Or, in the second place, God alone exists; the finite has no reality, it is only phenomena, appearance. 
 - HoP 3

To say, in the third place, that God exists and we also exist is a false synthetic union, an amicable compromise. 
 - HoP 3

It is the popular view of the matter that the one side has as much substantiality as the other; God is honoured and supreme, but finite things also have Being to exactly the same extent. 
 - HoP 3

Reason cannot remain satisfied with this also,  with indifference like this. 
 - HoP 3

The philosophic requisite is therefore to apprehend the unity of these differences in such a way that difference is not let slip, but proceeds eternally from substance, without being petrified into dualism. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza is raised above this dualism; religion is so also, if we turn its popular conceptions into thoughts. 
 - HoP 3

It has been already remarked  that undoubtedly Substance with Spinoza does not perfectly fulfil the conception of God, since it is as Spirit that He is to be conceived. 
 - HoP 3

But if Spinoza is called an atheist for the sole reason that he does not distinguish God from the world, it is a misuse of the term. 
 - HoP 3

Spinoza maintains that there is no such thing as what is known as the world; it is merely a form of God, and in and for itself it is nothing. 
 - HoP 3

The world has no true reality, and all this that we know as the world has been cast into the abyss of the one identity. 
 - HoP 3

There is therefore no such thing as finite reality, it has no truth whatever; according to Spinoza what is, is God, and God alone. 
 - HoP 3

Therefore the allegations of those who accuse Spinoza of atheism are the direct opposite of the truth; with him there is too much God. 
 - HoP 3

They say: If God is the identity of mind and nature, then nature or the individual man is God. 
 - HoP 3

This is quite correct, but they forget that nature and the individual disappear in this same identity: and they cannot forgive Spinoza for thus annihilating them. 
 - HoP 3

Those who defame him in such a way as this are therefore not aiming at maintaining God, but at maintaining the finite and the worldly; they do not fancy their own extinction and that of the world. 
 - HoP 3

Spinozas system is absolute pantheism and monotheism elevated into thought. 
 - HoP 3

Spinozism is therefore very far removed from being atheism in the ordinary sense; but in the sense that God is not conceived as spirit, it is atheism. 
 - HoP 3

However, in the same way many theologians are also atheists who speak of God only as the Almighty Supreme Being, etc, who refuse to acknowledge God, and who admit the validity and truth of the finite. 
 - HoP 3

They are many degrees worse than Spinoza. 
 - HoP 3

Even Descartes made it his starting-point that philosophic propositions must be mathematically handled and proved, that they must have the very same evidence as mathematics. 
 - HoP 3

The mathematical method is, however, ill-adapted for speculative content, and finds its proper place only in the finite sciences of the understanding. 
 - HoP 3

It may be conceded to Jacobi that the method of demonstration leads to Spinozism, if we understand thereby merely the method of knowledge belonging to the understanding. 
 - HoP 3

But the fact is that Spinoza is made a testing-point in modern philosophy, so that it may really be said: You are either a Spinozist or not a philosopher at all. 
 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

The triplicity, this ancient form of the Pythagoreans, Neo-Platonists and of the Christian religion, although it here reappears as a quite external schema only, conceals within itself the absolute form, the Notion. 
 - HoP 3

But since Kant says that a conception can determine itself in me as accidental, as cause, effect, unity, plurality, &c, we thereby have the whole of the metaphysics of the understanding. 
 - HoP 3

Kant does not follow up further the derivation of these categories, and he finds them imperfect, but he says that the others are derived from them. 
 - HoP 3

Kant thus accepts the categories in an empiric way, without thinking of developing of necessity these differences from unity. 
 - HoP 3

Just as little did Kant attempt to deduce time and space, for he accepted them likewise from experience-a quite unphilosophic and unjustifiable procedure. 
 - HoP 3

For the laws of the heavens are not immediately perceived, but merely the change in position on the part of the stars. 
 - HoP 3

It is only when this object of immediate perception is laid hold of and brought under universal thought-determinations that experience arises therefrom, which has a claim to validity for all time. 
 - HoP 3

Our finding both these elements in experience demonstrates indeed that a correct analysis has been made. 
 - HoP 3

For the first component part of experience, sensation, is doubtless subjective, since it is connected with our organs. 
 - HoP 3

The matter of perception is only what it is in my sensation. 
 - HoP 3

I know of this sensation only and not of the thing. 
 - HoP 3

Neither the one nor the other is consequently anything in itself, nor are both together, knowledge, anything in itself, for it only knows phenomena-a strange contradiction. 
 - HoP 3

This is dealt with by the transcendental faculty of judgment. 
 - HoP 3

The connection of these two is again one of the most attractive sides of the Kantian philosophy, whereby pure sensuousness and pure understanding, which were formerly expressed as absolute opposites, are now united. 
 - HoP 3

Thus, for example, the conception of substance in the schema becomes permanent in time,340 ie the pure conception of the understanding, the pure category, is brought into unity with the form of pure sensuous perception. 
 - HoP 3

In as far as we have to deal with our own determinations only and as we do not reach the implicit, the true objective, the Kantian philosophy called itself Idealism. 
 - HoP 3

But in this connection Kant  brings forward a refutation of empirical or material idealism, thus: I am conscious of my existence as determined in time. 
 - HoP 3

But all time-determination presupposes something permanent in perception. 
 - HoP 3

This permanence cannot be  a sensuous perception in me. 
 - HoP 3

Or I am conscious of my existence as of an empirical consciousness which is only capable of being determined in relation to something which is outside of me; ie I am conscious of something external to me. 
 - HoP 3

Conversely it may be said: I am conscious of external things as determined in time and as changing; these hence presuppose something constant which is not in them but outside of them. 
 - HoP 3

And this is I, the transcendental ground of their universality and necessity, of their implicitude, the unity of self-consciousness. 
 - HoP 3

On another occasion Kant regards it thus : These moments confuse themselves, because the constant element is itself a category. 
 - HoP 3

The truth or untruth does not rest in their being things or conceptions, but in their limitation and contingency, whether as conceptions or things. 
 - HoP 3

The refutation of this idealism is nothing more than calling attention to the fact that this empirical consciousness does not exist in itself-just as those empiric things do not exist in themselves. 
 - HoP 3

But the knowing subject does not with Kant really arrive at reason, for it remains still the individual self-consciousness as such, which is opposed to the universal. 
 - HoP 3

As a matter of fact there is described in what we have seen only the empirical finite self-consciousness which requires a material from outside, or which is limited. 
 - HoP 3

We do not ask whether these facts of knowledge are in and for themselves true or untrue; the whole of knowledge remains within subjectivity, and on the other side there is the thing-in-itself as an external. 
 - HoP 3

This subjectivity is however concrete in itself; even the determinate categories of the thinking understanding are concrete, and much more is experience so-the synthesis of the sensation and the category. 
 - HoP 3

It would make no difference if there had been no Reason there, just as with physicists it is a matter of perfect indifference whether, for instance, there is such a thing as magnetism or not. 
 - HoP 3

But the categories are themselves particular. 
 - HoP 3

The principle of reason, according to Kant, is really the universal, inasmuch as it finds the unconditioned involved in the conditioned knowledge of the understanding. 
 - HoP 3

Understanding is hence for him thought in finite relations; reason, on the contrary, is thought which makes the unconditioned its object. 
 - HoP 3

Since Kants time it has become customary in the language of philosophy to distinguish understanding and reason, while by earlier philosophers this distinction was not drawn. 
 - HoP 3

The product of reason is, according to Kant, the Idea-a Platonic expression-and he understands by it the unconditioned, the infinite. 
 - HoP 3

It is a great step forward to say that reason brings forth Ideas; with Kant, however, the Idea is merely the abstract universal, the indeterminate. 
 - HoP 3

This, the unconditioned, must now be grasped as concrete, and therein lies the main difficulty. 
 - HoP 3

For to know the unconditioned means to determine it and to deduce its determinations. 
 - HoP 3

Much has been written and said on the subject of knowledge, without a definition of it ever having been offered. 
 - HoP 3

But it is the business of Philosophy to see that what is taken for granted as known is really known. 
 - HoP 3

Now on this point Kant says that reason has certainly the desire to know the infinite, but has not the power. 
 - HoP 3

It depends, however, on how the world is looked at; but experience and observation of the world mean nothing else for Kant than a candlestick standing here, and a snuff-box standing there. 
 - HoP 3

But no one wishes to demand a sensuous proof in verification of the infinite; spirit is for spirit alone. 
 - HoP 3

Although reason, says Kant, becomes transcendent by the exhibition of these contradictions, it still retains its claim to trace perception, experience, and knowledge pertaining to the understanding, back to the infinite. 
 - HoP 3

This union of the infinite, the unconditioned, with the finite and conditioned as existing in the knowledge given by the understanding, or even in perception, would signify that the acme of concreteness had been reached. 
 - HoP 3

Of this Unconditioned there are several kinds, objects having special features of their own and proceeding from reason, transcendental Ideas; they are thus themselves particular in their nature. 
 - HoP 3

The manner in which Kant arrives at these Ideas is again derived from experience, from formal logic, according to which there are various forms of the syllogism. 
 - HoP 3

Because, says Kant, there are three forms of the syllogism, categorical, hypothetical, and disjunctive, the Unconditioned is also three-fold in its nature: Firstly, an Unconditioned of the categorical synthesis in a subject. 
 - HoP 3

Synthesis is the concrete; but the expression is ambiguous, since it indicates an external association of independent elements. 
 - HoP 3

In the second place, an Unconditioned of the hypothetical synthesis of the members of a series will have to be looked for; and in the third place, an Unconditioned of the disjunctive synthesis of the parts in a system. 
 - HoP 3

When brought to an ultimate point, the question which meets us is whether Reason can bring these objects to reality, or whether they remain confined to subjective thought. 
 - HoP 3

Now, according to Kant, Reason is not capable of procuring reality for its Ideas-otherwise it would be transcendent, its limits would be overstepped; it produces only paralogisms, antinomies, and an ideal without reality. 
 - HoP 3

Since Reason credits with reality that mode of the Unconditioned which constitutes the categorical synthesis in a subject, and therefore the thinking subject, it is termed substance. 
 - HoP 3

Now is the thinking ego a substance, a soul, a soul-thing? Further questions are whether it is permanent, immaterial, incorruptible, personal and immortal, and such as to have a real community with the body. 
 - HoP 3

The falsity of the syllogism consists in this, that the idea of the unity of the transcendental subject essential to Reason is expressed as a thing; for it is only in this way that the permanency of the same becomes substance. 
 - HoP 3

Otherwise I find myself permanent in my thought, of course, but only within perceiving consciousness, not outside of that. 
 - HoP 3

The ego is therefore the empty, transcendental subject of our thoughts, that moreover becomes known only through its thoughts; but of what it is in itself we cannot gather the least idea. 
 - HoP 3

We therefore know very well that the ego is a subject, but if we pass beyond self-consciousness, and say that it is substance, we go farther than we are entitled to do. 
 - HoP 3

I cannot therefore assign any reality to the subject. 
 - HoP 3

We here see Kant fall into contradiction, what with the barbarity of the conceptions which he refutes, and the barbarity of his own conceptions which remain behind when the others are refuted. 
 - HoP 3

But, in the second place, Kant does not assert the contrary of this, namely that the ego, as this universal or as self-thinking, has in itself the true reality which he requires as an objective mode. 
 - HoP 3

For he does not get clear of the conception of reality in which reality consists in the possession of a sensuous present existence; accordingly, because the ego is given in no outward experience, it is not real. 
 - HoP 3

For self-consciousness, the ego as such, is not, according to Kant, reality; it is only our thought, or in other words he regards self-consciousness as being itself simply and entirely sensuous. 
 - HoP 3

The form which Kant accordingly bestows on Being, thing, substance, would seem to indicate that these categories of the understanding were too high for the subject, too high to be capable of being predicated of it. 
 - HoP 3

But really such determinations are too poor and too mean, for what possesses life is not a thing, nor can the soul, the spirit, the ego, be called a thing. 
 - HoP 3

Being is the least or lowest quality that one can assign to spirit, its abstract, immediate identity with itself; Being thus no doubt pertains to spirit, but it must be considered as a determination scarcely worth applying to it. 
 - HoP 3

In the second place we have the antinomy, ie the contradiction in Reasons Idea of the Unconditioned, an Idea applied to the world in order to represent it as a complete summing-up of conditions. 
 - HoP 3

If now this completeness is expressed as existing, an antinomy is alone presented, and Reason is presented only as dialectic: ie in this object there is on every side a perfect contradiction found. 
 - HoP 3

Reason demands a perfectly complete synthesis, an absolute beginning; but in phenomena we have, on the contrary, a succession of causes and effects, which never come to an end. 
 - HoP 3

Kant here points out four contradictions , which, however, is not enough; for in each Notion there are antinomies, since it is not simple but concrete, and therefore contains different determinations, which are direct opposites. 
 - HoP 3

These antinomies in the first place involve our making the one determination, limitation, just as valid as non-limitation. 
 - HoP 3

Thesis: The world has a beginning and an end in time, and it is limited in regard to space. 
 - HoP 3

Antithesis: It has no beginning and no end in time, and also no limits in space. 
 - HoP 3

The one, says Kant, can be proved just as easily as the other; and indeed he does prove each indirectly, though his are not advocates proofs. 
 - HoP 3

The world, as the universe, is the whole; it is thus a universal idea, and therefore unlimited. 
 - HoP 3

The completion of the synthesis in progression as regards time and space is, however, a first beginning of time and space. 
 - HoP 3

If therefore the categories of limited and unlimited are applied to the world in order to attain to a knowledge of it, we fall into contradictions, because the categories are not applicable to things-in-themselves. 
 - HoP 3

The second antinomy is that atoms, from which substance is composed, must necessarily be admitted to exist, therefore simplicity can be proved; but just as easy is it to prove incompleteness, the endless process of division. 
 - HoP 3

The thesis is accordingly stated thus: Every compound substance consists of simple parts,  and the antithesis is as follows: There exists nothing simple. 
 - HoP 3

The one is here the limit, a material self-existence, the point which is likewise the enclosing surface; the other is divisibility ad infinitum. 
 - HoP 3

The third antinomy is the opposition between freedom and necessity. 
 - HoP 3

The first is the self-determining, the point of view pertaining to infinity: causality according to the laws of freedom is the only causality. 
 - HoP 3

The other is: Determinism alone is to be found: everything is determined by means of an external ground or reason. 
 - HoP 3

The absolute necessity of the conditioned world is therefore on the one hand maintained thus: To the world belongs an absolutely necessary Being. 
 - HoP 3

The opposite to this is, There exists no absolutely necessary Being, either as part of the world or outside of the world. 
 - HoP 3

One of these opposites is just as necessary as the other, and it is superfluous to carry this further here. 
 - HoP 3

The necessity of these contradictions is the interesting fact which Kant  has brought to consciousness; in ordinary metaphysics, however, it is imagined that one of these contradictions must hold good, and the other be disproved. 
 - HoP 3

The most important point involved in this assertion of Kants is, however, unintentional on his part. 
 - HoP 3

If such determinations belonged to the world, to God, to free agents, there would be an objective contradiction; but this contradiction is not found as absolute, it pertains only to us. 
 - HoP 3

Or, in other words, this transcendental idealism lets the contradiction remain, only it is not Being in itself that is thus contradictory, for the contradiction has its source in our thought alone. 
 - HoP 3

Thus the same antinomy remains in our mind; and as it was formerly God who had to take upon Himself all contradictions, so now it is self-consciousness. 
 - HoP 3

But the Kantian philosophy does not go on to grapple with the fact that it is not things that are contradictory, but self-consciousness itself. 
 - HoP 3

Experience teaches that the ego does not melt away by reason of these contradictions, but continues to exist; we need not therefore trouble ourselves about its contradictions, for it can bear them. 
 - HoP 3

Nevertheless Kant shows here too much tenderness for things: it would be a pity, he thinks, if they contradicted themselves. 
 - HoP 3

But that mind, which is far higher, should be a contradiction-that is not a pity at all. 
 - HoP 3

The contradiction is therefore by no means solved by Kant; and since mind takes it upon itself, and contradiction is self-destructive, mind is in itself all derangement and disorder. 
 - HoP 3

The true solution would be found in the statement that the categories have no truth in themselves, and the Unconditioned of Reason just as little, but that it lies in the unity of both as concrete, and in that alone. 
 - HoP 3

Kant now goes on to the Idea of God; this third idea is the Being of Beings, which the other ideas presupposed. 
 - HoP 3

Kant says , that according to the definition of Wolff, God is the most real of all Beings; the object then comes to be to prove that God is not only Thought, but that He is, that He has reality, Being. 
 - HoP 3

This Kant calls the Ideal of Reason, to distinguish it from the Idea, which is only the sum of all possibility. 
 - HoP 3

The Ideal is thus the Idea as existent; just as in art we give the name of ideal to the Idea realized in a sensuous manner. 
 - HoP 3

Here Kant takes into consideration the proof of the existence of God, as he asks whether reality can be assigned to this Ideal. 
 - HoP 3

The ontological proof proceeds from the absolute Notion, in order from it to argue up to Being. 
 - HoP 3

With Anselm, Descartes, and Spinoza the transition to Being is thus made; and all of them assume in so doing the unity of Being and thought. 
 - HoP 3

But Kant says : To this Ideal of Reason just as little reality can be assigned: there is no transition from the Notion to Being. 
 - HoP 3

Being is not a real predicate,  like any other, a Notion of something which might be added to the Notion of a thing. 
 - HoP 3

A hundred real dollars do not contain in the very least more than a hundred possible dollars,  they are the same content, ie the same Notion; they are also a hundred exactly. 
 - HoP 3

The one is the Notion, or rather the conception, the other is the object; Being is no new determination of the Notion, otherwise my Notion of a hundred real dollars would contain something different from a hundred real dollars. 
 - HoP 3

But the object, as real, is not contained in my Notion alone; or to my Notion the real hundred dollars are synthetically added. 
 - HoP 3

Being cannot therefore be derived from the Notion, because it is not contained therein, but must be added to it. 
 - HoP 3

We must go out of the Notion in order to arrive at existence. 
 - HoP 3

With regard to objects of pure thought, there are no means of coming to know of their existence, because it had to be known a priori; but our consciousness of all existence belongs entirely to experience. 
 - HoP 3

The content is no doubt the same for him in what exists and in the Notion: but since Being is not involved in the Notion, the attempt to derive the one from the other is unavailing. 
 - HoP 3

Of course the determination of Being is not found as positive and ready-made in the Notion; the Notion is something different from reality and objectivity. 
 - HoP 3

If we therefore abide by the Notion, we abide by Being as something different from the Notion, and adhere to the separation of the two; we then have conception, and not Being at all. 
 - HoP 3

But in a like popular fashion it might be said that one must leave off imagining, for that is mere conception: ie what is merely imaginary is untrue, the hundred imaginary dollars are and remain imaginary. 
 - HoP 3

Therefore to believe in them is a proof of an unsound understanding, and is of no manner of use; and he is a foolish fellow who indulges in such fancies and wishes. 
 - HoP 3

This subjective side is not the ultimate or the absolute; the true is that which is not merely subjective. 
 - HoP 3

If I possess a hundred dollars, I have them actually, and at the same time I form a conception of them to myself. 
 - HoP 3

But according to Kants representation we come to a deadlock at the difference; dualism is ultimate, and each side has independent validity as an absolute. 
 - HoP 3

There is no man so foolish as that philosophy; when a man feels hungry, he does not call up the imagination of food, but sets about satisfying his hunger. 
 - HoP 3

All activity is a conception which does not yet exist, but whose subjectivity is abrogated. 
 - HoP 3

Moreover the imaginary hundred dollars become real, and the real ones imaginary: this is a frequent experience, this is their fate; it depends on circumstances entirely outward whether a hundred dollars become my property or not. 
 - HoP 3

Of course the mere conception is of no good, if I obstinately hold by it: for I can imagine what I will, but that does not make it exist. 
 - HoP 3

The only important point is what I conceive to myself, and then whether I think or comprehend the subjective and Being; by means of this each passes into the other. 
 - HoP 3

Thought, the Notion, of necessity implies that the Notion does not remain subjective; this subjective is on the contrary abrogated and reveals itself as objective. 
 - HoP 3

Now that unity is expressly affirmed by Descartes solely in reference to the Notion of God, for it is just that which is God; he speaks of no hundred dollars, as these are not an existence which has a Notion in itself. 
 - HoP 3

That opposition does away with itself absolutely and entirely, ie the finite passes away; it holds good only in the philosophy of finitude. 
 - HoP 3

If, therefore, there is not a Notion of existence formed, we have in it a notionless, sensuous object of perception; and what is notionless is certainly not a Notion,-therefore sensation, handling, are not Notions. 
 - HoP 3

Such existence has of course no Absolute, no real essence: or such existence has no truth, it is only a vanishing moment. 
 - HoP 3

This useless thrashing of the empty grainless straw of the common logic is termed philosophizing: it is like Issachar the strong ass, which could not be made to move from the spot where it was. 
 - HoP 3

People of this kind say: We are good for nothing, and because we are good for nothing, we are good for nothing, and wish to be good for nothing. 
 - HoP 3

But it is a very false idea of Christian humility and modesty to desire through ones abjectness to attain to excellence; this confession of ones own nothingness is really inward pride and great self-conceit. 
 - HoP 3

But for the honour of true humility we must not remain in our misery, but raise ourselves above it by laying hold of the Divine. 
 - HoP 3

The fact to which Kant clings most strongly  is this, that Being cannot be extracted from the Notion. 
 - HoP 3

The result of this is the proposition that to have the thought of the Infinite is certainly Reason; but that from the Idea of Reason is separated determination in general, and especially the determination which is known as Being. 
 - HoP 3

The Ideas of Reason cannot be proved from experience, or obtain from it their verification: if they are defined by means of categories, contradictions arise. 
 - HoP 3

If the Idea in general is to be defined as existent only, it is nothing more or less than the Notion; and the Being of the existent is still distinguished from it. 
 - HoP 3

Abstract thinking is adhered to; it is said that the understanding can only bring about order in things; but order is nothing in and for itself, it is only subjective. 
 - HoP 3

I, as Reason or conception, and the things external to me, are both absolutely different from one another; and that, according to Kant, is the ultimate standpoint. 
 - HoP 3

The animal does not stop at this standpoint, but practically brings about unity. 
 - HoP 3

This is the critique of theoretical Reason which Kant gives, and in which he states the a priori and determinate character of Reason in itself, without bringing it to the determinateness of individuality. 
 - HoP 3

For Kant assumes all such conceptions as that matter has motion and also a power of attraction and repulsion,352 instead of demonstrating their necessity. 
 - HoP 3

Density, for instance, is looked on by physical science as a variable quantity, as a mere quantum in space: instead of this Kant asserted it to be a certain degree of occupation of space, ie energy, intensity of action. 
 - HoP 3

He demands accordingly  a construction of matter from powers and activities, not from atoms; and Schelling still holds to this without getting further. 
 - HoP 3

Religion within pure Reason  is also a demonstration of dogmas as aspects of Reason, just as in Nature. 
 - HoP 3

He is much more reasonable than the AusklÃ¤rung, which thinks it beneath its dignity to speak of such matters. 
 - HoP 3

These are the principal points in respect to the theoretical part of Kants philosophy. 
 - HoP 3

As practical, on the contrary, Reason is independent in itself; as a moral Being man is free, raised above all natural law and above all phenomena. 
 - HoP 3

The will determines itself within itself; all that is right and moral rests on freedom; in this man has his absolute self-consciousness. 
 - HoP 3

Here we have the Notion which is sensible of its own deficiency; this theoretic Reason could not be, as in it the Notion had to remain the Notion. 
 - HoP 3

Thus we have the standpoint of absoluteness revealed, since there is an infinite disclosed within the human breast. 
 - HoP 3

The satisfying part in Kants philosophy is that the truth is at least set within the heart; and hence I acknowledge that, and that alone, which is in conformity with my determined nature. 
 - HoP 3

Kant divides will into lower and higher faculties of desire; this expression is not inapt. 
 - HoP 3

The lower faculties of desire are impulses, inclinations, etc; the higher faculty is the will as such, which has not external, individual aims, but universal. 
 - HoP 3

All morality of action now rests upon the conviction that the act is done with consciousness of the law, for the sake of the law and out of respect for the law and for itself, without any regard to what makes for happiness. 
 - HoP 3

As a moral Being man has the moral law in himself, the principle of which is freedom and autonomy of the will; for the will is absolute spontaneity. 
 - HoP 3

But the essence of the will is to determine itself from itself; for practical Reason gives itself laws. 
 - HoP 3

But the empirical will is heteronomous, for it is determined by desires; and they belong to our nature, not to the realm of freedom. 
 - HoP 3

It is a highly important point in the Kantian philosophy that what self-consciousness esteems reality, law, and implicit Being, is brought back within itself. 
 - HoP 3

Great popularity has from one point of view been won for Kantian philosophy by the teaching that man finds in himself an absolutely firm, unwavering centre-point; but with this last principle it has come to a standstill. 
 - HoP 3

But even if it is stated that it is concrete in itself, there is the further consideration that this freedom is at first only the negative of everything else; no bond, nothing external, lays me under an obligation. 
 - HoP 3

It is to this extent indeterminate; it is the identity of the will with itself, its at-homeness with itself. 
 - HoP 3

But what is the content of this law? Here we at once come back to the lack of content. 
 - HoP 3

For the sole form of this principle is nothing more or less than agreement with itself, universality; the formal principle of legislation in this internal solitude comes to no determination, or this is abstraction only. 
 - HoP 3

The universal, the non-contradiction of self, is without content, something which comes to be reality in the practical sphere just as little as in the theoretical. 
 - HoP 3

The universal moral law Kant therefore expresses thus : Act from maxims  , which are capable of becoming universal laws. 
 - HoP 3

Thus for the determination of duty  Kant has contributed nothing but the form of identity, which is the law of abstract Understanding. 
 - HoP 3

The content as such is indeed not what holds good universally in the moral law, because it contradicts itself. 
 - HoP 3

For benevolence, for instance, enjoins: Give your possessions to the poor,  but if all give away what they have, beneficence is done away with. 
 - HoP 3

Even with abstract identity, however, we do not get a step further, for every content which is put into this form is by being so put freed from self-contradiction. 
 - HoP 3

But nothing would be lost if it were not put into this form at all. 
 - HoP 3

With regard to property, for instance, the law of my actions is this: Property ought to be respected, for the opposite of this cannot be universal law. 
 - HoP 3

That is correct, but it is quite a formal determination: If property is, then it is. 
 - HoP 3

Property is here presupposed, but this determination may also in the same way be omitted, and then there is no contradiction involved in theft: If there is no such thing as property, then it is not respected. 
 - HoP 3

This is the defect in the principle of Kant and Fichte, that it is really formal; chill duty is the final undigested lump left within the stomach, the revelation given to Reason. 
 - HoP 3

The first postulate in practical Reason is thus free, independent will which determines itself, but this concrete is still abstract. 
 - HoP 3

The second and third are forms which remind us that the will is concrete in a higher sense. 
 - HoP 3

The second point is the connection of the Notion of the will with the particular will of the individual; the concrete is here the fact that my particular will and the universal will are identical, or that I am a moral human being. 
 - HoP 3

The unity, that man should be moral, is postulated; but beyond the should  and this talk of morality, no advance is made. 
 - HoP 3

It is not said what is moral; and no thought is given to a system of the self-realizing spirit. 
 - HoP 3

For really, as theoretic Reason stands opposed to the objective of the senses, so practical Reason stands opposed to the practical sensuousness, to impulses and inclinations. 
 - HoP 3

Perfected morality must remain a Beyond; for morality presupposes the difference of the particular and universal will. 
 - HoP 3

It is a struggle, the determination of the sensuous by the universal; the struggle can only take place when the sensuous will is not yet in conformity with the universal. 
 - HoP 3

The particular will is certainly something other than the universal will; but it is not ultimate or really permanent. 
 - HoP 3

The third point is the highest concrete, the Notion of the freedom of all men, or the natural world has to be in harmony with the Notion of freedom. 
 - HoP 3

That is the postulate of the existence of God, whom Reason, however, does not recognize. 
 - HoP 3

Will has the whole world, the whole of the sensuous, in opposition to it, and yet Reason insists on the unity of Nature or the moral law, as the Idea of the Good, which is the ultimate end of the world. 
 - HoP 3

Since, however, it is formal, and therefore has no content on its own account, it stands opposed to the impulses and inclinations of a subjective and an external independent Nature. 
 - HoP 3

For happiness is only ones own sensuous consciousness, or the actuality of a particular individual, not universal reality in itself. 
 - HoP 3

The unification spoken of itself therefore remains only a Beyond, a thought, which is not actually in existence, but only ought to be. 
 - HoP 3

The postulate itself is always there, because the Good is a Beyond with respect to Nature; the law of necessity and the law of liberty are different from one another, and placed in this dualism. 
 - HoP 3

Nature would remain Nature no longer, if it were to become conformed to the Notion of the Good; and thus there remains an utter opposition between the two sides, because they cannot unite. 
 - HoP 3

It is likewise necessary to establish the unity of the two; but this is never actual, for their separation is exactly what is presupposed. 
 - HoP 3

Kant employs popular language thus: evil ought to be overcome, but yet must not have been overcome. 
 - HoP 3

God is to him, therefore, only a faith, an opinion, which is only subjectively, and not absolutely true. 
 - HoP 3

This result is also of a very popular character. 
 - HoP 3

These postulates express nothing but the synthesis, devoid of thought, of the different moments which contradict each other on every hand; they are therefore a nest 359 of contradictions. 
 - HoP 3

For instance, the immortality of the soul is postulated on account of imperfect morality, ie because it is infected with sensuousness. 
 - HoP 3

But the sensuous is implied in moral self-consciousness; the end, perfection, is what really destroys morality as such. 
 - HoP 3

Similarly the other aim, the harmony of the sensuous and the rational, to an equal extent abrogates morality; for that consists in this very opposition of Reason to the sensuous. 
 - HoP 3

The ground on which God is accepted-that by the conception of a holy law-giver the moral law may acquire additional reverence-contradicts the fact that morality really consists in reverence for the law simply for its own sake. 
 - HoP 3

It is hard for man to believe that Reason actually exists: but there is nothing real except Reason; it is the absolute power. 
 - HoP 3

The vanity of man aspires to have an ideal before him, in order to be able to find fault with everything alike. 
 - HoP 3

What we pass in rapid review when we recall it, stretched itself out in reality to this great length of time.

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3

 - HoP 3
